description:
I visited Aliment all by my lonesome on a work trip (I couldn't tell you the last time I had dinner alone in public, so it was quite an adventure) and had a great experience. They sat me right at the bar with all the other lonely business folks, and service was incredibly quick. I ordered a beer and the ricotta gnocchi and before I'd taken a few sips of beer, the gnocchi had already arrived! 

The gnocchi was pretty good, although a bit less al dente than I'd prefer. The overall taste was good, and it was a plentiful portion. The bartenders were very attentive and the ambiance was nice. Definitely a great spot for my intro to the world of solo-dining. :)
author: Krystin T.

description:
Pretty decent happy hour prices. Fried chickpea meatball has amazing sauce; definitely the best of their dishes. Brussels sprouts were ok, but the sprouts were too large and didn't fully cook; outside was crisp and nicely done; but due to size they were also under seasoned.
Mussels were solid, but I don't get the French fries on top that results in a beautiful French fry getting soggy from water and steam of the mussels.   The fries were perfectly cooked and seasoned. Mussels were a little bit gritty and needed a better cleaning, flavor was good. 
Service was soli and quick. A little more polishing would make this place a 5.
author: Chris G.

description:
Jose the bartender provided exceptional service during happy hour (literally I think we were there for exactly an hour). We ordered the mac and cheese, bbq wings, blueberry ale and pale ale, brussels sprouts, and tacos. Everything was delicious and it all came out to about $40+tip. Mac and cheese was homemade, bbq wings were meaty and flavorful, sprouts were charred and sweet, and the tacos had a great portion of meat and toppings.

Really happy I was able to find this place an hour before I had to leave for my flight! I would definitely recommend coming here for dinner or happy hour. I will come back to try the ricotta gnocchi!
author: Mia C.

description:
I came here during their 5-7pm happy hour to take advantage of their bar-only specials, including $6 brussels sprouts and $7 chickpea "meatballs", which aren't on their regular menu. The three chickpea meatballs were delicious and filling, and the brussels were nice and crispy. It's unfortunate that happy hour extends only to those seated at the bar, because there aren't many seats there. 

The bartender was friendly, service was quick, and the food was good. I'll be back!
author: Kirsten H.

description: Do not go here.  My wife and I walked in at 8:30- we are from out of town but the food sounded good and they were listed as open till 10PM.  They told us they were closed.  When we pleaded with them, it made no difference.  There were still people eating.  When I told the owner I was going to give a bad review and tell our hotel not to recommend this restaurant- the owner used the f bomb and cursed at me.
author: Robert B.

description:
Very nice cool hip spot with great happy hour!  
Bar foods were very cheap and really delicious!  Very freshly made, promptly served, and great service.
The drinks were also really good.  They had a good decent number of beer, mixed drinks, and wine.  

I would definitely be back for happy hour!
author: Jang N.

description: My wife and I enjoyed an extended weekend getaway in the city and tried the Aliment for the first time for dinner. Although their menu was not extensive, the choices were appealing. I got the pork chops which were amazing!! Very tender, served with kale, yams and a sauce which was delicious!  My wife got the salmon which was cooked to perfection because they asked how you wanted it cooked (ie, medium, medium well, etc). The salmon had a delicious Greek yogurt and cucumber sauce. The Cheese and Charcuterie also was well appointed and tasty.
author: Gary R.

description:
This place is usually not packed unless it's happy hour, which makes sense. Who can resist $5 small bites and $8 wines/cocktails? My friend and I came around 6:30 and the bar was full, but we crowded up next to it anyway and ordered the cocktail of the week, a Paloma (both $8), and fries ($4). 

The bartender was a jokester and would push our fries closer to us if he saw we weren't eating them, although he was a bit too quick to clear our food and drinks at the end. The fries were a great deal; the bowl was pretty big and they were thin and crispy. The drinks were super refreshing; the tequila comes through pretty strongly in the Paloma. 

It's a really nice restaurant with lots of natural light and would be a great place to catch up with some friends after work!
author: Sophie W.

description:
All our orders were cooked to perfection! We loved their Beet Salad, Mussels a, and grilled pork chop.

The salad was delicious! 

They give generous amount of mussels. Love dipping/soaking the French fries in its the broth.

Pork chop was tender & just the right amount of salt.

The only comment is the dessert (I forgot what it's called). I think a bit too sweet for me, although others might the level of sweetness. I do like the white round crunchy stuff.
author: Ariene S.

description:
Food is solid here. The ambience is pretty bare. Can be a bit cold on a wintry night. 

Best dish that we tried was curried squash soup (non-dairy vegan). A bit of spice with softness of the squash soup. Not too thick. Well put together. 

The Brussels Sprouts was a good rendition. Pretty crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. 

The burger was lackluster. Even though we asked for it medium rare, the meat came out well done. And the bun was burnt as well. They were nice enough to redo the burger which came out ok - the bun was too thick for my taste.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Great double date spot. Quality food, but not cheap. Appetizers are around $15 and mains are $20-30 bucks. Recently, got the mussels, brussel sprouts and spicy korean fried chicken. 

The mussels were really tender and I typically don't like 'em. The associated fries and sauce were good. The brussel sprouts were standard and good for the extra veges in the diet. The spicy fried chicken was mostly 3 big pieces of white meat and 1 leg. I wish it had more dark meat personally. 

There are 2 floors and probably seats around 40 people. Reservations are recommended. The staff feels like folks who aren't local to the bay area so that's a nice change. Our waiter this time was from Ireland and he had a thick accent.
author: Young Y.

description: Was in the market for a nice bite to eat on a Saturday night. I was alone, and was on foot, and discovered Aliment after the first place I chose on Yelp had a line around the block. Aliment was booked, too, but they had a seat available in the window, which suited me and my people-watching inclination just fine. The waitstaff were very helpful and personable, and I got in just under the wire for happy hour. I had the Brussel sprouts, the chickpea meatballs and the French fries. All were excellent, served nicely and complemented well by my vodka and soda(s). Next time in the neighborhood, I will definitely be back.
author: Steve M.

description: Business must be so good they can turn away customers and close when they want.  Supposed to be open to 10 but turned us away at 8:30.  Said we would write a bad review and the guy dropped the f bomb on my husband while eating his dinner at the bar. Anyone who knows us can attest this is not something we would normally do but felt it worthy to mention.  There are so many great restaurants -- don't chance this one will be closed when you here there -- just go somewhere else to begin with.
author: Connie B.

description:
Happy hour 5-7, including Saturday! 
I really wish we'd known that. We ordered our first round at the bar 2 minutes before happy hour ended. They were nice enough to allow us. The red wine was, eh... the Paloma was fantastic. 

We dined upstairs and it was uncomfortably hot. I was hesitant about dining up their for this reason but took a chance. 

We ordered the Brussels sprouts to start and they came out quickly. They weren't fully cooked though which was a bummer. I guess they do not steam them first. 

My girlfriend ordered the steak burger which was definitely the winner. The entree presentation was cute on the tray but I think she wanted some more fries. Also the burger continuously slipped off the bun. I think the bun wasn't perfect for such a fatty piece of beef. Half way through it was pretty soaked with the fat of the beef & soggy. That burger patty though was outstanding and had delicious cheese on top. 

My spinach salad was really good, with I think strips of radishes and tasty clementine oranges. The chicken was nicely cooked but unseasoned. Tender but mild in taste. The light, mild oil based dressing lightly covered it. The tomatoes were fantastic and an usual yellow variety. Super juicy. I enjoyed it.

My 2nd glass of wine was from Napa. At $15 per glass it was one of the more expensive glasses. It was fabulous Cabernet Sauvignon. Well worth it. 

The hostess and our server were both terrific. I really liked them.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Aliment has the very good and the very disappointing. In a city with so many options, I was wildly disappointed.  I should have known that day of reservations were too good to be true.

The eatery itself is very attractive.  It is a lovely neighborhood restaurant on the corner of Mason and Bush.  There are four booths on the first floor that accommodate 4-6, a few high tops and a full bar with seating of six.  There were also tables on the second floor. They are doing the modern bistro - kitchen towel napkins, no tablecloths, little plants, etc. You know the vibe.  FYI: Ventilation is an issue; hot on the second floor and cold on the first floor.

We ordered the burger for the LOs to split, which they were nice enough to do in the back. The $18 burger was slightly overcooked (more medium than medium rare) and underseasoned. It had nice aged cheddar but the bacon jam and chipotle aioli were undetectable. It was served with fries and spicy pickles. It was totally edible but not at all wow.

Meanwhile, we had cocktails, DM had a Kentucky Mule and I had the spice table. The Ketucky Mule was a-ok - lots of lime with bourbon and a bit of ginger beer. It was bartender's choice - not very imaginative but a-ok.  I ordered the Spice Trail, which was a bourbon based drink with a ginger turmeric elixir with lemon. It was not a very balanced drink - a little cloudy and bitter. Drinkable (who wastes good bourbon?!?!) but definitely not my fave.

The Brussels Sprouts were the highlight of the evening and are worth a trip on their own. Super crunchy sprouts in fish sauce that stay crunchy. OMG. These were heavenly. The cauliflower saute was okay.  The first couple of bites that I had (and the last couple of bites that DM had) were off. We suspect it was rancid oil that was drizzled at center. Otherwise,the caramelized cauliflower with golden raisins, capers and Parmesan were very good.

Things went downhill. Nothing here is inedible,but I have had so much better. The mussels had only one piece of chorizo - false advertising - and half of them were chock full of grit. The lager sauce and braised red cabbage were a nice alternative preparation to the dish.  The New York Strip requested rare was more like flank steak cooked medium rare. The roasted sweet potatoes were nice, crispy and generous. The mustard inflected rutabega puree was lovely but inadequate. The meat was riddled with gristle and passed onto the human garbage disposers in the group.

Considering the hit and miss nature of the menu and the lacking cocktails, we went elsewhere for our nightcap. The service was friendly, albeit not very attentive.  

I am really disappointed that this place has 4 stars on Yelp. I am not a fan and would not encourage others to come.
author: Stephanie B.

description: What an overpriced ugly patch of food arrived at our table. Two entrees were inedible and tasted like Major Sysco's sauces.  The charcuterie was skimpy and pricey.  The drinks were also pricey for pedestrian mixes and standard wines (think Trader Joe's).  The mussels were fair but had an odd red cabbage addition which made the frites soggy.  The pork chop was covered in gallopy sauce.  The wait staff is clearly stretched with the number of tables they have to serve.  The brussels sprouts were very good-- the highlight of the meal.  If you decide to go, make sure you are downstairs where it is less likely to be 85 degrees, and you have a chance to skip out after a drink and small plate.  Basically, this place is an affront to quality Bay Area dinign and drinking.
author: Shelly D.

description:
I moved here from Chicago almost a year ago and I've spent more time in this establishment than any other. The staff is probably my favorite part. Super attentive and make you feel at home.
Food is great, they also have my favorite happy hour in the city from 5-7pm everyday and all day on Sundays now I believe. During they offer five or six different app/shared plates that are delicious, especially for the price and all their daft beers are $4. Their full menu is great as well!
author: Ryan P.

description:
This was the perfect place for my girls and I to pregame for Ali Wong (who was amazing by the way)!! Hopwater, down the street, was way too crowded, so I'm glad I spotted Aliment's happy hour sign (5-7PM) posted outside.

Service was just great. All the staff made me feel very welcomed and comfortable. We must have sounded like fresh 21 year old girls ordering shots of jameson, but they didn't seem to judge us, haha ;)

On top of the shots, we also got the paloma, the old fashioned, and the blush. The paloma tasted like juice, haha... tasty, but not as worth it like the latter 2 drinks, which were strong, yet sweet. For snacks, we got fries, wings, and brussels sprouts. The "fish sauce caramel" on the sprouts tasted amazing! Would definitely recommend.
author: Lincy H.

description: Happy hour listed as 7 pm, but need to get here earlier as the waitress stated they cut off food "before then". Honestly not the nicest of service, but good food and cocktails.
author: Meghan L.

description:
Came here for a girls night dinner and was very pleased by the meal.

We started with the Brussel sprouts and beet salad.  The beet salad looked like a piece of art but it was a bit too sweet for my palette.  The brussel sprouts were delicious.

For our main dish, we decided to go with the fish and the wild boar.

The fish was great, absolutely beautiful presentation and tasted wonderful.  The smoked snow was kind of odd but the puree was yum.

The wild boar covered in bacon... Yassss.

Overall great neighborhood spot that I will frequent again.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
Super friendly staff. Like. SUPER. Like. Cooler than cool.

Waltzed in unexpected. The place has that kind of curbside appeal. Almost boujie but still quaint and inviting. 

We were immediately treated to a tour of the place. They have the main foyer/dining area; a back room and a mezzanine level that overlooks the entrance and bar.

 We had a few brews and kicked it with the staff who schooled us on a few other local venues and current events. Sffunandcheap.com. 

Didn't dine in but the Menu looked fabulous. Definitely worth a stop in. 

Indoor seating only. Superb service. Beyond solid bar.

CHEERS!!!
author: Ethan P.

description:
Jose made our night!  It is our anniversary night and we were looking for a good local place to enjoy dinner out. What we found was more than amazing. The food was perfect. The beer recommended by my new friend Jose was the best and went perfectly with the dinner selection. I had the burger and my wife had the fried chicken. Both were fresh and were exactly what we wanted. If that wasn't good enough,  the was an assume 80's mix playing over the sound system and a cheesy episode of the original Star Trek with William Shatner playing on a TV.  It all made the night memorable.   

Overall - the food surpassed expectations and the service was the BEST!!! Thank you
author: Sean A.

description: Cool spot and friendly staff (they let me change my reservation by an entire hour) but mediocre food at best. A good pro is that I was able to make reservations the day of on Open Table on a Saturday night, and that it's walking distance from Union Square. Maybe this place is better for drinks and small snacks, but I ordered the underwhelming Australian barramundi with high hopes. The corn purée was the highlight of my dish, but the fish tasted bland. The pink quinoa was a nice touch, but also was tasteless to me. I didn't think the bacon went well with the dish either. The meal was expensive ($27, but with tip and tax came out to be $33 for my portion). Not a place I need to come to again.
author: Victoria L.

description: If you are going to a show at the Masonic, come here first! It is delicious. Great cocktails as well. We order a bunch of items and the server timed it all well and gave great recommendations.
author: Jessica B.

description:
The Popcorn Infused Crème Brûlée was amazing!! Was a super interesting dessert that's an experience to eat. You scoop a spoon of creme brulee, and then scrap it against the wooden tray that has popcorn dust and a raspberry compote drizzled on it. One of my favorite desserts.

For dinner itself, I got the gnocchi which was subpar. There wasn't a lot of it and it wasn't that fluffy/good, either. They didn't even add the ridges, it was just chunks of dough.
author: Patricia P.

description:
Great restaurant. Amazing customer service.  Had a lovely bartender, forgot her name but she made us a perfect cocktail according to requests and was willing to make another if we did not like it.  
Servers name was Luka, he made sure we liked our food (which we loved).
Ordered the steak burger (I asked to replace fries with sweet potatoes and they did so) and my sister ordered the Korean fried chicken.  All food was amazing, gourmet, and came in great portion sizes.
author: Tara R.

description: Ailment is a classy joint with very reasonable prices for SF. The food was definitely the highlight...please do yourself a favor and get the red curry butternut squash soup and brussels sprouts to start, and then choose from the NY Strip or the Burger. Great find.
author: Carson G.

description: San Francisco and I have a love hate relationship, I love the food hate the city and SF well I don't actually know what the city thinks of me. Staying at the Sir Francis Drake for work travel led me to Aliment. Typically after a long week of travel the last thing I want to do is sit at a bar and eat. So I find a restaurant that peaks my interest and offers the ability to order takeout online. The menu here is very broad and offers some comfort food which I can use one of my cheat days on. Having skipped lunch today I ordered the spicy fried chicken and the steak burger with fries. Hey I am a growing boy in the gym 6 days a week, don't judge me. The pick up process was easy than I thought, the hostess greeted me, promptly picked up my order and away I went back into the crazy tourist area of Union Square. Once I got back to my hotel I dove into my food, the burger was cooked perfectly medium rare with tons of flavor, fries crispy and seasoned well. Oh I did also order a second meal for myself, the spicy fried chicken with crispy skin and delicious white meat to die for. I am sure everything else on the menu is equally as good and while my visits to the city are sporadic Aliment is on the top of my list. Thanks for great service and amazing food!
author: Matthew M.

description:
We waited too late to make a reservation on the Saturday night of New Year's Eve weekend, and several of our first choices were booked for the evening.  Aliment had tables available and it was close to our hotel, so we thought we'd give it a try.

I ordered a glass of a nice Chianti, and my boyfriend had a martini.  We split the cheese and charcuterie plate as an appetizer, with three cheeses, two meat selections, wheat crackers, a sweet-sour cranberry jam and hazelnuts.  I thought the plate was quite generous and delicious.

For dinner, I ordered the wild boar wrapped in bacon, with a plum sauce, and my boyfriend had the spicy Korean fried chicken. We both agreed that the boar was outstanding, while the chicken was just merely good.

The restaurant was not very busy when we arrived at 8:45 pm.  We had our choice of a table with a view of the street, or a table upstairs, overlooking the bar and downstairs. We chose to dine upstairs, and ended up having our own private dining room.

The wait staff was attentive and friendly, and the portions were plentiful.

Aliment is a solid choice for a nice dinner with interesting ingredients in Nob Hill.
author: Lynda T.

description:
Good drinks and service.

I had the fried chicken.  Although good, I grew up in the south and you simply can't beat our fried chicken, I'd give it 6 out of 10.

My cousin had the burger and fries that looked awesome. The fries were really solid.
author: Chad R.

description: Excellent service and food!  Great happy hour.  Brussels sprouts and wings are a must.
author: John M.

description: I ordered a "Bond Martini". Tony, the Bartender, delivered the perfect drink!  I can count on ONE hand the number of Bartenders that can make an obscure drink like a Bond Martini. He NAILED IT!  5 STARS!
author: Steve K.

description: Having a great restaurant requires top notch food or top notch service, you need to have at least one with the other being well above average. This place has both, the food is outstanding, we had brussel sprouts, Mac n cheese and the ricotta doughnuts. All three are must haves, with the ricotta doughnuts taking the crown. The service is also outstanding, Jose is awesome. Glad we decided to pop in, this became a SF favorite
author: Robert L.

description:
This is a restaurant created and run by people who do not care about the food that they are serving, and unfortunately, they do not have the ingredients or culinary talent to make cheap taste good.

This place is clean and nicely decorated in that typically standard, if forgettable, modern San Francisco restaurant style. This could be just about any restaurant in San Francisco that has opened in the past 5 years.

The servers are nice and attentive, even though they are clearly being stretched too far with too many tables in too many rooms and many flights of dangerous stairs to manage to. An extra star is given for their efforts.

But the food here is thoughtless and mediocre. Everything tastes as if it came prepackaged frozen from some restaurant supply store. Nothing is fresh or interesting. It's all basically overpriced, prepackaged bar food. Think Costco frozen section.

The wine list is also as if it were chosen from the bottom of some wine merchant's bargain bin. Nameless, mediocre choices abound. It's almost as if they are using Trader Joe's as their wine purveyor. This thoughtlessness is particularly offensive for the Bay Area.

Avoid this place. It won't last long.
author: J D.

description: First off, the food here is pretty darned good. If I were rating just the food, I would give it 4 or 5 stars. However, that being said, the service was terrible. Bad enough we wouldn't go back. Two of us dining, one entree cane out 10 minutes before the other. Took forever to get our waitress' attention when we needed more water, another drink, or the check. We waited a lot here. Restaurant is also extremely loud. Can't say I'd return when there are so many options in the area.
author: Thelma D.

description:
A hop and a skip away from Union Square, this cozy wine bar/restaurant can be found on the corner of Bush and Mason. The proximity to the cable car stop can bring the occasional savvy tourist, but it's through and through a local's spot. 

Sit at the bar and chat up the convivial staff for recommendations. We were on our way to another event, so we kept it light. I had the mussels with a Thai red curry sauce and chorizo. He had the crispy brussel sprouts with fish sauce caramel and toasted nori. Let's face it -- everyone in this town has done their own version of brussel sprouts but the sweetness of Aliment's version is a winner. 

During happy hour, wines are $8 and beers are $6. I had a nice classic oaked Chardonnay with a generous pour. 

Discovering a place like Aliment in my favorite neighborhood for cocktailing makes me a happy gal!
author: Janice C.

description: This place rocks.  Great service. Amazing happy hour. Beautiful bar and known for their mixed drinks. Had the green salad, salmon and a Paloma which were all 10 out of 10. Girls are very nice at bar.  Pretty busy for a Tuesday night.   Priced really well. Delighted.
author: Erin B.

description:
Me and my buddies had just finished Color Factory and were STARVING -- at this point, any kind of food would've been good. We were lucky enough to be seated immediately after coming in from the rain but everything fell apart after we ordered drinks. I had ordered a Sangria that tasted like a watered down college party drink and made me depressed each time I took a sip. My buddy had ordered a $13 drink that was the size of her palm. It was incredibly underwhelming. 

The food was expensive and incredibly bland. It's fresh but tasteless. What a waste!! We ate a NY Steak that made me feel sorry for the cow because the chef couldn't bother to season the meat properly. Their "medium rare" burger also came out incredulously raw I guess cooking meat is hard. On the plus side, their French fries tasted like real potatoes and their sweet potatoes were the f---ing bomb! ... but still not worth the price. I won't be coming back just because it was a meal that was not worth it. 

TLDR; Great atmosphere, but terribly disappointing food and drinks. Maybe good if you're hoping to break up with someone here.
author: Michelle L.

description:
My girlfriend and I were at a bar nearby. She was hungry, so we decided to check out Aliment since it was so close. We walked in without a reservation on Friday, January 20th around 6:30pm. Luckily, there was a table available by the front and we were seated right away.

Happy Hour: 5pm - 7pm
*Wings: sous vide organic wings, korean BBQ ($6)
*Mussels: shallots, chorizo, white wine, herbs ($10)
*Chimi Churri Steak Taco: chipotle aioli, aged cheddar ($8)
*Brussels Sprouts: toasted nori, fish sauce caramel ($5)
*House Cut Fries: chipotle aioli ($4)
*House Wine ($8): Red x2, White x2

We made it in time for HH. Yay! Decided to order the whole HH snacks menu. The taco plate was perfect for sharing between the two of us. One taco each. I really wanted some beef, so this satisfied my craving. My other favorite dish was the mussels. Nice beefy broth from the chorizo. And the mussels themselves were tender. The fries were good for sopping up all the drinks we were having. (I actually finished them by myself later when we decided to buy a couple more bottles to drink at home.) The wings were a good size, but I thought the flavor was pretty average. I'm not a huge fan of sweet and salty together, so I thought the brussles were okay. The wines were good for HH wines. My gf drank the two whites which were a sauvignon blanc. I drank the two reds which I believe were pinots.

Regular Menu:
*Potato Leek Soup ($10)
*De Novo Cabernet Sauvignon Alexander Valley 2014 ($13)
*Smith Story Sauvignon Blanc 2014 ($14)

My gf loves soup, so she wanted to try the soup off the regular menu. I'm more of a brothy soup girl, but this was tasty. Not too heavy for a creamy soup. After HH ended, we wanted one more glass of wine each, so my gf got another sauvignon blanc. HH is a great deal as we saved $6 per glass on her white. I decided to change it up and get a cab since I like more full bodied wines.

Please note, there is a Yelp check in offer: 15% off your happy hour 5-7pm, which we were able to use for our bill. Saved us a little more than $15 which was nice. I sometimes check in after I leave a place, so I'm glad I checked in while we were here.

Great spot for HH. They have some very nice deals. Happy we stopped by on a random rainy Friday night.
author: Elena N.

description:
I almost hate to write this review because it may become so popular, we won't be able to get a table next time. The food was superb and the customer service was outstanding! Jose, our waiter, was the best ever! Sunday's Happy Hour menu is not lengthy, but it was perfect for us. Our party of 5 shared several dishes of Mac n Cheese (with bacon), chicken wings, caramelized brussel sprouts, fries, meatballs and salad that was not on the menu, but prepared specially by the chef, just because we asked for salad. All of it was spectacular. The brussel sprouts with nori seaweed and caramelized fish sauce was to die for! My favorite dish! For dessert, we had the ricotta donuts with caramel sauce. We asked if the chef had anything chocolate, so he specially prepared a melted chocolate sauce! And the two sauces combined were divine.

I can't say enough about the staff! The ambience and atmosphere is casual, hip, with a great vibe and great music! We will definitely be back.
author: Lynn F.

description: Love this restaurant!I would recommend to all my friends. My favorite place in the area for drinks, food and atmosphere. Jose and Tony are the best, super friendly and always make us feel at home.
author: Mo L.

description: Everything worked for me. The beset salad, the cocktails expertly crafted, and especially the mussels!
author: Stephan V.

description: Such a great happy hour place! The food was tasty and the happy hour drinks prices were great! We got there on the early side and got a table up front. The staff seemed a little distracted so the service at times was not ideal but our waiter was friendly when we could grab his attention. They have happy hour food as specials as well so we split a bunch for the table.
author: Sarah F.

description: Food was pretty good, odd that we had a different menu then those downstairs. I asked for some bread to go with my muscles and there was a $4 charge... lame.
author: Tara A.

description: Food was good but staff were very slow. Our waitress was serving our table and a bunch of tables upstairs, which meant she was running up and down the stairs the whole time. We waited a while before we could get her attention for the check, and then waited another 10 mins because she forget to close out the check and just left our credit cards on the side...
author: Carolyn B.

description: The service is wonderful. We went on Wednesday at Happy Hour (5-7pm) and ordered the Brussels. They use fish sauce in them, but there's no trace whatsoever of fish. It tastes more like a honey glaze. We ordered the salmon and the tzatziki  sauce was a lovely addition.
author: Arissa C.

description: I have mixed feelings about Aliment. On one hand, happy hour there is very nice - the bar snacks are good, the beer selection is good, and the service is very friendly. But my only experience with dining there was disappointing. Our server told us that the dinner menu was entirely different from the happy hour one - we couldn't order any happy hour appetizer, even at a higher price. Even the drinks were different. It left a bad taste in our mouth, and we'll probably only return for happy hour.
author: Stephen B.

description:
First and last time dining here.

My girlfriend and I decided to try this place out after looking for a restaurant near the play we attended on Valentine's Day. The menu online looked decent enough and the restaurant seemed nice.

The restaurant looks great and the staff is very friendly and attractive. Our waitress was adorable, but she was clearly new. I had no problem with her service except for when she neglected to ask me a very important question (see below, re the boar dish).

They had a Valentine's Day menu that we passed on since it was a four course dinner with no substitutions and the selected courses chosen didn't sound all that appetizing. Also, I had my mind set on having their steak.

Shortly after seating, our waitress informed us that they were out of many items on their already small menu. Including steak. They ran out of steak. That didn't leave us very many options.

Fortunately, they had the appetizers we wanted to try, which were, in fact, appetizing. My girlfriend had her eye on the gnocchi as her main course, which they didn't run out of, so she at least got to order what she wanted. I, on the other hand, had only a few choices.

I decided to order the boar since I've never had it before and I love trying new foods. Plus I've always loved pork chops growing up. Can't go wrong with pig, right? Wrong.

When the main courses arrived, my girlfriend was presented with a large serving of gnocchi while I had the most disappointingly small serving of boar chops. For the price, I could have got a much larger steak. If they didn't run out, that is.

The gnocchi was under seasoned and it tasted off so my girlfriend sent it back after a few bites. I tried it, too. It wasn't good. Aside from the appetizers, all she ate here was their crème brûlée dessert, which she did like.

When I cut into my boar, I was surprised to see that it was cooked rare. Rare. Pig cooked rare. 

At what restaurant do they not ask you how you want your meat cooked when you order? I assumed boar, like regular pork, would come to me cooked. It didn't occur to me that I should have had to tell them how to cook it, especially since they didn't ask me how I wanted it.

I should have sent it back to the kitchen to at least be warmed up, but instead I hopped on my phone and Googled to see if rare boar was safe to eat. I got conflicting answers, but I guess it's okay. I like my steak rare, but the thought of biting into rare pig still made me uncomfortable.

I decided to try it anyway. I cut off a couple of small pieces. Didn't like the flavor, didn't like the texture, and didn't like the idea of biting off a bigger piece of undercooked pig so I just ate the salad included with my meal (salad was great) and asked for a box for the boar so that my pets at home could at least enjoy a nice meal since we weren't. Honestly, I would have rather had any cheap porkchop than their wild boar. I don't know if I'll ever order boar again anywhere.

After spending $100 on a meal, my girlfriend and I left unsatisfied and still hungry.

I would not come back here or recommend it.
author: Marcus A.

description: Got the Gnocchi here and at such a steep price-point, I was expecting 1. more quantity and/or 2. really amazing gnocchi. I got neither of these. I got a little of something that didn't taste great. I guess that's a good thing in some ways, but what did I pay so much for? It was about 10 pieces of gnocchi with roasted bell peppers, walnuts, and ricotta and some other stuff. I found it very unappetizing and probably one of the worse gnocchis I've ever tasted. We've had better gnocchi when we tried to make it at home! Anyway, yeah the gnocchi here left much to be desired and also did not fill my stomach.
author: Kavya T.

description: I would come back just for how impressed I was with the Brussels sprouts. The steak burger and fries chicken was good but not noteworthy enough to come back for. The spouts though, WOW! Plus a nice oregon bottle of Pinot nior for $50
author: Kayla S.

description: First of all, very cool, modern interior design. I was ushered in even though there were few customers inside and it was fairly late (around 9:30) and sat at the bar. First of all the bartenders are super friendly and as I was pretty sick and feeling cruddy, make me a delicious hot toddy and even gave it to me at happy hour prices (rather than the steep $13 or so cocktail prices). I only got the soup as I was minimally hungry and frankly, the menu is pretty expensive. The squash curry soup was served in a decent sized bowl and had a lovely orange colour with plenty of chunks of pumpkin (I think?) plus hazelnuts (I think) which enhanced the rich flavour. Plus the soup is dotted with pink flower petals. Great for when as I was sick as I was. I was tempted by the sauteed cauliflower but maybe next time I'm in SF. Thanks guys for the good conversation. Whilst the hot toddy didn't make me feel 100% the next day I definitely think it contributed somewhat to my recovery :)
author: Jennifer S.

description: Ahh amazing! Wasn't sure what to except but right from the beginning the service was amazing and the food was incredible! I loved that it was casual and the day I went it was just happy hour so that speaks volumes! I had the Brussels sprouts featured on the yelp page.. yes there incredible and a must try, the Mac and cheese (wow! If you like crumbs on top -a must), and the ricotta doughnut (OMG!) I mean can you go wrong?! Well if you're not lactose! ;-) I can't wait to come back for dinner, this was absolutely incredible! The service was amazing too, great staff!
author: Alejandra L.

description:
Unbelievable! The food is perfectly portioned and it is what you would expect for the high end $$ tag!
Came here on a recommendation from a friend and they did not disappoint! Perfect place to bring a first date, second date, party of five or family.. all I can say is I haven't been this satisfied in a restaurant in quite awhile.. refreshing to know there is still some talent out there.
author: David M.

description: Good, good cooking. Come for the food, stay for the food.  If you leave hungry, it's your own fault. Enjoy. Maybe just a little noisy... GET OFF MY LAWN!
author: Chris C.

description:
Love this place! Came here with some of my girlfriends for dinner and had a great time. The restaurant is modern and cozy, perfect for happy hour, dates, or girls night out!

The service was great and they were super attentive. We ordered some drinks, appetizers, and entrees. Specifically, the brussel sprouts, cauliflower, chick pea "meat balls", spicy Korean fried chicken, and the salmon cakes. Everything was flavorful, yummm. My favorites were the fried chicken and the brussel sprouts. But honestly, whatever you order will most likely be good!

I'll definitely be back and it's worth a try!!
author: Marian S.

description: Amazing Brussels sprouts. Whatever you do, just order these for the table and enjoy! I almost ordered a second but had the beet salad which was just as good, some great appetizers!
author: Rick D.

description: Only go there if you want to be fleeced.  I am a neighbor who has frequented Aliment out of convenience, but no more.  My experience is that they use every trick in the book to misrepresent their pricing.  The latest example:  they advertise "Happy Hour from 5 -7" on a billboard in front of the restaurant.  What they don't advertise is that you have to be sitting in a particular section of the restaurant to receive that price.  Of course you don't find that out until you receive the check.  I escalated it to the Manager and he said "too bad, it's always been that way" (Jose).  I just cannot continue to support a business that has deceptive marketing.
author: Christina W.

description:
Lived in the neighborhood for 9 years and like my friends & neighbors, we were all initially excited when Aliment first opened its doors to have new spot in the hood. Unfortunately, my experiences at this place have consistently been disappointing. 

I recently stopped by for dinner and after a longer than usual wait, our server made his way to take our order and apologized for the delay, which we were fine with because we noticed he was swamped. Shortly after our drinks arrived, the section emptied out. With the exception of requesting water refills a couple of times, everything was fine until our food arrived and we were suddenly being served by some other server, which we weren't fully aware of this until the end of the evening. While this isn't a big deal, it's rude to abandon a table with nothing being said to the customers. Not to mention that we weren't asked how our entrees were, which unfortunately, my burger was terribly disappointing. It was way overcooked; the bun was dense, heavy and overall flavorless. I would have shared my distain had anyone come back to check-in. On the flip side, the Brussels sprouts and gnocchi were decent. 

While our plates were still on the table and the other person in my party was still working on his food, our new server announced it was "last call for the kitchen" and asked if she could bring us dessert menus. I was little taken back given I wasn't even certain who this person was and we technically weren't done eating. When we declined, she plunked the check down on the table and came back a few minutes later to clear our plates and collect payment. Since I ended up eating less than half of the burger, I asked to take it with me and she handed a box to pack up it myself. Not the most classy move, but on par with the rest of our experience. The reason that I chose to take the leftover was to pass it on to a homeless person who was camped out front.

When we were paying our check, I asked where our server disappeared to and was plainly told that he went home. As we were leaving the restaurant, we noticed him sitting at the bar enjoying drinks and food with his buddies. Again, this isn't a huge deal but having worked in restaurants and the hospitality industry myself for several years it's courtesy and common sense to let tables know you're going home, which only takes a minute. I mean he clearly had enough time to order food and get planted at the bar. I can also appreciate the wait staff's desire to call it a night, but rushing patrons through their meal and obviously clearing the table ASAP and making us feel like we were imposing is unprofessional, especially when there's service staff is chilling at the bar. 

Due to similar experiences that I described, I've only been to Aliment a few times with the last time being about a year and a half ago. Thinking enough time had passed and there might have been a shift in management and staff I thought I'd give it try again. Sadly, I was reminded why I don't frequent this restaurant. Furthermore, I notified management the next day about this rough experience and never heard back. Needless to say, the neighborhood is all too curious to see what moves into the space next.
author: Derwood A.

description:
What a mixed bag. The service is outstanding. Amazing drinks, although super spendy $13 per cocktail for half a rocks glass. Smalls: Squash soup is amazing, although rimming the bowl with ground red pepper and lime was a bit weird--I would prefer them on the side so I can move my bowl without getting sticky. Brussels sprouts were delicious and tender while packed with flavor. For my entree I had the Barramundi. The cold couscous side salad was just weird and played next to the fish. The barramundi was overcooked and dry--not to mention small for $23 and served with really hard bacon. The fish was so tough I hard to cut it with my knife. When I pierced the thickest portion with my fork, the flesh disintegrated. The parsnip mash was delicious, though. I wish I had more than a tablespoon of it.

 My husband's medium rare steak was cold, which was odd since my fish was so hot I burned my tongue on it. The flavors were completely on point,you and the sweet potatoes were slightly crispy on the outside but melted in you mouth when you bit into them. Definitely a meal worth it's price if the steak is warm.

 My daughter's burger was amazing. One word--beer bun. So delicious! The homemade refrigerator pickles were thin, crunchy, and a delicate masterpiece. 

Finally, despite complaining to 2 separate servers about my fish, it remained on my bill. One asked if they could make me something  else, but I didn't have time to wait  I'm not one to make a scene, so I didn't push the issue. I'm not sure we'll be back despite so much of the food being delicious. That fish should never have left the kitchen.
author: Dorinda G.

description: I walked into this restaurant to ask them how late they were open. They all stared at me. After not receiving a reply, I walked out. Confused. The bartender made a rude comment to me as I was exiting. What is wrong with these people? I was about to bring an entire group of people to dine there later that night. Manners! Also, just treat people decently? What is wrong with y'all?!
author: Amber A.

description: In SF for work this week so I was trying to find placing with a good bar, solid menu and the icing on the cake would be a TV playing the Celtics game. I could not bring myself to go to a hole in the wall sports bar when I'm surrounded by such great food options. Luckily, this spot had all three. Super trendy establishment with very considerate and attentive staff. I took advantage of Happy Hour with their House Red and Brussel Sprouts. I had the Steakhouse Burger for dinner and it was unreal. It should not be missed!
author: Alexa M.

description: Average... from the reviews I expected a bit more. The mussels were OK. The charcuterie board nothing to remember about.
author: Andrea G.

description: Stopped here on a Sunday evening, happy hour menu!  Jose went out of his way to accommodate our silly requests and ALL the food was fabulous!   The drink were great, too! Will definitely come back!
author: Karri R.

description: First time here, so I ordered the Smoke Show, a mezcal cocktail and their burger which the bartender noted that they had "just perfected". The cocktail was well balanced, but the burger was an absolute standout. Can not wait to come back and try their other menu items, as I had a five minute conversation about the Mac and cheese which sounds as though it is out of this world.
author: Will W.

description:
Loved it here! Amazing wine, delicious food, and good company. The menu offers an interesting mix of cuisines - burgers to spatzel.

Our group of ladies gathered to drink rosé and champagne and fill our bellies on one of our last nights in SF. We didn't have to wait for a table, which was wonderful considering there were six of us and we were hungry! But, I'd suggest making a reservation to be safe.

We opted to order a bunch of items off the menu to share:
- Burger - really juicy and flavorful + french fries are frites-style so extra crispy
- Mac and cheese - indulgent treat. Sharp white cheddar gives it bite.
- Kale salad - topped with pepitas and parm. Delicious way to get some greens.
- Ricotta gnocchi - light and slightly crisped on the edges.
- Charcuterie board - really nice spread of 3+ meats & cheeses, along with pickles, pickled onions, bread, and mustard-y spread.

I look forward to visiting again. Great for a date night or gals night out. Crisp and clean space. Great service, and awesome atmosphere to treat yourself to wine and good food. Brunch looks good too!
author: Breanna B.

description: This place was great, and the food was delicious, and we love the location, but I have to say that it's extremely overpriced, and the serving sizes are disappointing. If you have extra cash to blow, then definitely have a date night here, but if not, I would save your money because you may leave hungry.
author: Sabra M.

description: The staff is incredibly friendly. They have a great happy hour. My friend and I got Brussels sprouts and wings and they were delicious. We also had heir cocktails and wines. They had a nice menu but their happy hour specials and service make this place 5 stars
author: Haley S.

description: Came here last week while visiting SF with a friend from work.  We had drinks, mussels and both had the steak burger.  The mussels were to die for and they kept bringing bread at no additional cost which was nice.  The burger was pretty good too but I just can't stop thinking about the mussels!
author: Rachel S.

description: This is a solid place for drinks and food. My partner is obsessed with it and has been many times with visiting friends. He would definitely give this five stars. The food was definitely good, I had the steak which was beautifully presented and we shared a Korean chicken appetizer. The staff and bartender were all super friendly and service was on point. Sounds like they change their menu around (as all great places should do) so I'll definitely be back to try out the new dishes.
author: Debra D.

description:
Nice neighborhood find. I was staying at the Fairmont hotel and this spot was a short downhill walk two blocks away.  I 

Always feel a little awkward eating alone at the bar - but thanks to Jose the bar manager and and his team -  I felt like I was a regular.   Excellent, attentive customer service, recommendations and friendly  conversation.   

I had a great dinner.  Delicious stuffed chili peppers and Brussels sprouts.  Eclectic menu - my choices had excellent flavors.  The mussels looked really good too. 

I was the first customer to arrive at 5:00 when the doors opened. By the time I left at 7, the place was packed. Plenty of friendly patrons sitting at the bar to converse with.  I will return on my next visit to the area.
author: Robyn J.

description:
Over priced for the food. The odd part of the night was their staff was at the bar having fun and then one of them ran around the restaurant telling us they were locking the doors and we should "drink up". This was at 10:50pm - and he wasn't saying it in a fun way but a "get out" way. PS - they had just served us a round about 15-min before.

Uncaring staff and over-priced food. I would go elsewhere.
author: Patty O.

description:
Looking for a good group dinner spot with tons of small plate options and a private dining space? Look no further. Aliment has got ya covered.

I came in with a large group of coworkers last week and our dinner was nothing short of perfection. They sat us upstairs in our own semi-private area, and it was really nice to actually hear each other speak, which I feel like is rare in restaurants these days! 

We started off with a few rounds of small plates (and a few rounds of wine...duhzzz) and I think it's safe to say that we tried nearly everything. What was in the mix:

-Sweet and crunchy Brussel sprouts. I was a bit nervous about the fish sauce, but it added a really nice flavor.
-Kale salad with shaved parmesan
-Salad with some sort of creamy cheese (tasted like a blend of goat and ricotta) with sweet potatoes. It was dressed in a sweet brown sugar dressing which I loved. 
-Crispy chicken bites coated in ramen. So unique!
-Korean BBQ riblets in a sweet and tangy sauce
-A pot of mussels (which they originally brought out because they heard that instead of brussels, and ended up letting us keep) 

After all of that...it was time for mains. I was honestly stuffed. Although the pasta bolognese and gnocchi sounded divine I was too full for a big bowl of pasta and ended up with another small plate, shrimp and grits.

Very solid choice on my part. The smoked gouda grits were creamy and delicious, and sat beneath a heaping portion of baby shrimp and charred corn. They were absolutely not skimpy on the shrimp, and even though it was a 'small plate' it easily worked as an entree. 

Whether you are with a large group or in need of a date night spot, Aliment is a solid pick for all occasions!
author: Sara B.

description:
I fell in love at this restaurant.  Fell in love with the ambiance, customer service, cocktails, music, and their chocolate cake. I have to disagree with some reviewers who felt that this restaurant was over priced. You get what you pay for, and for the city, I felt like the prices were fine. I love the seating areas (it is a smaller restaurant so making reservations may be a good idea).  You can tell that Aliment has many regulars who frequent the establishment, so that made me feel as though there is consistency in their food and service.  Their welcoming demeanor definitely makes me want to go back for more. 
But seriously, their chocolate cake is what's drawing me back in.
author: Nikki G.

description:
The space is incredibly sleek and trendy, and reminds me so much of London cafes/gastropubs. I adore the open kitchen design so you can eat/drink at the counter, or even on the first floor dining space, and watch the chefs in action. The owners have made a brilliant use of space with the overhead loft hovering just above the bottom floor seating area, and they don't jam tables and chairs together to maximize seating. Instead, parties are placed at comfortable distances. 

The food is phenomenal. Great for sharing tapas-style, you can get a bunch of small dishes for the table (and quite reasonably priced), or opt to have your own main. I enjoy how they have turned rather bland greens such as kale, Brussels sprouts, and artichokes into really spectacular eats. They tone down raw kale by shredding and tossing in a light cream dressing, and peppering with parm cheese. They flash-roast the Brussel sprouts and drizzle them in a sweet and syrupy "fish sauce." They even have an interesting take on "chicken nuggets." They take white meat bite-sized chicken strips and batter it in a mix of crumbs and crushed ramen noodles. Water glasses are constantly refilled, and the staff are consistently chipper and accommodating. Wine selection is sparse but sufficient, and you can enjoy full bottles at reasonable prices, or enjoy single glasses with incredibly generous pours. 

Although only open for dinner, it's well worth the wait for an evening meal. Would definitely return time and time again.
author: Alison A.

description: This is a wonderful restaurant with Chef Jane and our Server, Rachel. I am a foodie from NYC. The service was great, atmosphere warm and caring as a neighborhood place should be. My boyfriend had the ricotta gnocchis which he said were the next best thing to his mother's. The fish was delicious with delicate flavors. I would highly recommend Aliment when you are in the area around the Mark Hopkins or Fairmont Hotel.
author: Gail H.

description:
This meal was really good! First we noticed the decor and we were lucky enough to get a table on the top floor with a nice view over the bar and the restaurant with a big video screen on the wall. 

The Californian red wine was delicious (sorry I forgot which one it was, maybe with Syrah). 
Having read the reviews, we wanted to taste the Brussel sprouts, they were a lot and bigger than the usual Brussel sprouts we knew. The sweet caramelized taste was very nice. 
Then we had the gnocchis, nice but not amazing as I read elsewhere. And the scallops, which were extremely good and served over some black rice. This dish was smaller than the others but as we had so many Brussel sprouts we were not hungry anymore. 
Service was nice. We will try to come back next time!
author: Anne M.

description:
Nice little joint right here with window seating with windows that actually open. I initially came here and say upstairs with the fan directly pointing at me but it was too warm in SF (imagine that) that day so I had to move to a diff seat downstairs by the window. Now you understand my initial comment about where to sit. 

The Brussels sprouts were really good with toasted nori and some kind of fish caramel sauce that made me keep eating this dish. Did I mention that this was really REALLY good?

Foie gras meatballs kinda lacked the foie gras. I guess the mixture maybe doesn't go well together because I couldn't taste it.

Kale salad was a kale salad and didn't disappoint but wasn't as memorable as the Brussels sprouts.

I would like to try some of the other items on the menu but I wasn't too hungry on this day so I'll update when I go back.
author: Ryan C.

description:
They say the way to a man's heart is through his stomach. Well I hereby revise that to say the way to my heart is through *your* stomach. As in Felicia over there was putting a spell on me by #solo ordering a salad then burger x fries. Buuuut she proceeded to eat like 1/4 of the salad, 1/2 the yurg, and an imperceptible amt of fries. Later she got dessert but #wgaf. #byefelicia #yagone #upwardsnap

Dishes sounded fleek on paper but mostly turned out funky, not in a good way.

(^_^) Ramen Fried Chicken Bits $9
"Least off-putting dish of the meal."

(^_^) Brussels Sprouts $10
Sauce becomes intense at the bottom. #twss

(-_^) Riblets $8
Salty kimchi. Ribs 'E' for effort...

(-_-) Foie Gras Meat Balls $12
Salty. Where's the foie?

(-_v) Pastrami Slider $6
Bottom bun was nearly bagel chewiness.

Two best things of my experience were the menu illustration and when they finally switched the projector from cheesy scifi (Wing Commander, Starship Troopers) to High Noon. Also coughcutewaitresscough. :p
author: Dan B.

description: Make sure to make a reservation. You may get lucky sitting at the bar. Tried this place out recently and it was the only good place I ate around the area my hotel was at. I had the red curry butternut squash soup, the beet salad, and the ricotta gnocchi. As for the cocktail, the Paloma is the best. Pretty presentation, good quality, loved it. Loved the sever, she was very bubbly, and a great sense of humor.
author: Emily S.

description:
Whoa - this place is overpriced! I've been here three times since they've opened hoping to finally have landed a fun neighborhood restaurant and bar; what a let down. 

A friend and I came in for dinner and there were three people seated, rest of the place was empty. Bar tender had to tell us to take a seat and then yelled around the restaurant for the waitress to tell her that someone was here and needed menus. Ok... not an amazing start, but no worries. 

We order and our food arrives - totally undercooked. In fact, my table mates good was physically cold to the touch. When we flagged down our waitress her response was: "oh no, that's not good..." [long awkward silence and stares] "...did you want me to see if the kitchen could warm it back up or?" -- lady, the kitchen didn't warm it back up to begin with??

The individual entrees were grossly over priced. I came back, again, months later with another friend hoping they'd have shaped up a bit and yet again - same experience. 

Weak menu, non-service-friendly staff and inability to have a strong offering make this a place to avoid, if you're in the area.
author: A X.

description:
Aliment seriously knows how to rock a foodie's world. Their eclectic menu is full of comfort food --ranging from salads/small plates to large, extremely filling entrees!

They do have a great wine list but let's skip to the most important part, The Food:

To start, we ordered multiple small plates for the table to try which included the fried brussels sprouts {...with a sweet and caramel-y sauce that was to die for}, kale salad, roasted squash salad {loved the hazelnuts!}, Asian inspired riblets {...so tender and fell off of the bone!}, ramen crusted chicken tenders with a heavenly sweet/mustard-y sauce {these were tied with the brussels as my fav}. We probably {ok, definitely} over-indulged on the small plates because oh em gee, my tummy was satisfied after all of that. 

BUT of course, we're foodies and couldn't stop there. I ordered the Bolognese for my entree and not only was it a massive portion,  but it was very meat-y {...duh, the best kind of Bolognese!} I literally ate about half of it and had to stop, my stomach was literally about to explode. {...which is so unlike me, I'm always a member of the clean plate club.} Dear hungry men, order this dish! 

We were way too full for dessert but I am sure their desserts are fabulous as well! I highly highly recommend dining at Aliment. You will be singing from the rooftops when you leave!
author: Hailey P.

description:
Dropped by here randomly to kill time as we were waiting for Tacorea to open across the street (opens at 6 PM for dinner). And good thing we stopped by because, jeez, I found a place that does their fried brussel sprouts right! I think it might have been $6 for happy hour ($12 regular price) and the portion was HUGE! Probably twice the size of a normal appetizer. And it was fried perfectly. The 'fish sauce caramel' (as they call it!), was in fact, a savory glaze that went perfect with the 'sprouts. FUCK. So good. I'm drooling right now.

We only had a beer and the brussel sprouts, but judging by their execution of it, their kitchen seems like they can dish out delicious items. I'm itching for the next time I'm in the area again so I can eat it again and try some other items.

Props to the friendly bartender for not judging us for only getting happy hour items and still providing really great service! And to the free house-fried potato chips served in a cute li'l mason jar!
author: Emily C.

description:
This place is great. 
Great food
Great atmosphere 
Great bar
Great Phil!!!
If i could give it an extra star I would. Visited every night for the week we were in SF, either for a drink or a meal
author: Andrew K.

description:
Bad service, bad food, weak drinks... take your pick which annoys most.  Oh yeah, it's not cheap either.    

Team, you're in a neighborhood with many good bars with light snack options.  You have no room to suck this bad.
author: Chris S.

description:
We got their happy hour cocktails which are pretty good. The food seemed yummy as well but we had dinner plans elsewhere hence stuck to drinks.
The bartender was super friendly and nice. Apparently they have a new years party set up without any reservations and he was inviting us to be there.... might be fun to check it out if u have no plans ..
author: Sharmi M.

description: Great design and ambiance, no lie. Happy hour is legit as well and those brussel sprouts are cooked to perfection when the Chef handles them- time tested and well balanced. Also, I appreciate the portion size everytime! After a workout this is the place to splurge on a well deserved meal worth the price point. A fun place for locals coming up from Fidi after work or for tourists seeking a drink before shopping Union Square coming down from the Mark or Farralon. Great location and ambiance!
author: Simone N.

description: They took our party of 4 as a walk in.  The Brussel sprouts were out of this world.  Still thinking about them.  I also recommend the bread pudding and crepe brûlée.  All of their custom drinks are fabulous too.
author: Alex A.

description:
Food: EXCELLENT FLAVORS 
-Gnocchi - LOVED THIS DISH as well...do yourself the favor and add in the Pork Belly!  
-Duck Rillettes - This was by far my favorite dish at the restaurant.  It was very rich and the peaches helped balance out the gaminess of the meat.
-Brussels Sprouts - Had good flavor and people were literally fighting for this dish.
-Pastrami Sliders - Also another good selection from the menu.  Very tasty combination.
-Korean Fried Chicken - This was the only dish that I thought was just ok.  

Service: They were very attentive and nice and the top room was perfect for the 15 people in our party.

Ambiance: Couldn't be better.  Very modern decor

Overall: I would go back again specifically for the Gnocchi and Duck.  It was a great experience and going to be one of my go tos!
author: Spencer Q.

description:
Came here for dinner and everything I ordered was super spot on! I've heard great things about their brussel sprouts too which was true. I love the atmosphere and the layout of the restaurant. It wasn't that busy on a Tuesday night around 8PM but they do take reservations as well just in case. They are open Mon-Sun for dinner from 5:30 - 10:30PM. It is also decently priced too and great wine list. 

Items that I ordered: 
- Fried Brussels Sprouts w/ fish sauce caramel, toasted nori, sesame seeds
- Ricotta Gnocchi w/ english pea pesto
- Lamb Sirloin w/ tatziki, harrissa, zatar spice 

**menu always changes
author: Jenn L.

description:
Upon a recommendation by a friend, I dined at Aliment in a group of six, which turned out to be the perfect group size. We got one of each of everything except the burger, salads, and the butcher board. We also got extra of fried chicken bits, brussels sprouts, and steak, because they were our favorites of the night.

To go along with the food, we got a bottle of the Samsara pinot noir and (I think) the Alexander Valley cabernet sauvignon. Both were wonderful and went very well with each of the dishes. Service was great and everything was wonderful. Highly recommend Aliment for a tasty dinner. Recap of dishes below:

MUST HAVES:
- Fried chicken bits: Small pieces of fried chicken. Not dry, lots of flavor, great crust. I also loved the pickles.
- Riblets: Yum, so delicious! So juicy, tender, and flavorful. Arguably my favorite dish of the evening. The collard greens were great as an accompaniment.
- Steak: Perfectly medium rare. Loved the chimichurri sauce and carrot puree. Portion size is pretty big too.
- Pork belly: How can anyone turn down delicious pork belly? The kimchi was a great topping and I loved the crunch rice ovalettes.
- Foie gras meatballs: Yum yum yum. Texture was soft and there's lots of flavor. The salad on the side was extremely lackluster though.
- Brussels sprouts: 

JUST OKAY
- Mussels: Compared to the other dishes, I thought this was just okay. It was yummy but not as interesting as some of the other offerings.
- Pastrami short rib: I think the rest of the group would disagree with me and put it as a must have, but I didn't think this was as great as the other dishes. The concept was new and interesting, but the other meat dishes were better, IMO. The egg was awesome though.
- Trout cakes: Kinda like crab cakes. It was delicious, but was slightly fishy, so that's why I didn't put it in the must have category.

WOULD SKIP
- Arctic char roulade: This was perhaps the weakest dish of the evening. The fish was overcooked and there wasn't enough flavor.
- Gnocchi: There's probably better gnocchi elsewhere.
- Lamb: It's not bad, but also didn't stand out. I would skip this and save room for the other meat dishes.
author: Sherry L.

description:
I don't mind paying for good food but I left here feeling betrayed by other Yelpers.  

This place is overpriced with over salty or otherwise bland dishes.  

We had the mussels and salmon tartare for apps. The salmon tasted like plastic.

The entrees consisted of scallops and chicken breast dish and were too salty. 

Fire the cook or teach him how to cook please.  They also  ran out of cocktails and desserts.  

Go elsewhere for better value.
author: Nicolas N.

description:
We came here for a quick drink before our dinner reservation down the street, upon the recommendation of the hostess at that restaurant.

Sat at the bar at this cute establishment.  I wasn't feeling any of the drinks at the moment, so I grabbed a glass of Malbec. It was quite tasty.  He got a titos and soda.  Our bartenders were attentive and not intrusive so we enjoyed our time at the bar until dinner.  Looked tasty.
author: Milee S.

description:
Steak was burnt and unevenly cooked, brussel sprouts were icky sweet, this was quality I'd expect at my little brother's dorm priced at $50/person. Don't even get me started on the dated decor and fluorescent lighting.

I don't usually write reviews but I really felt like I got fleeced here.
author: John M.

description: Brussels sprout is definitely the highlight! The drinks look so tasty but didn't get a chance to try it! We had fried chicken which is tender and flavorful! Love the ambience, intimate and chic.
author: Sylvia L.

description: $26 for an "entree" of diver scallops that was literally gone in 3 bites? Feels like highway robbery. On top of that, as a large group, we had very slow and mediocre service because our tip was already automatically added to the bill. Was really hoping for a better SF dining experience to show my friends from out of town, and unfortunately, Aliment missed the mark on service, pricing, and overall sizzle. Hoping for some improvements because it's a nice space!
author: Andy L.

description:
The only good thing here is the Brussels sprouts.  

We ordered steak and wild boar for entrees.  The steak came out looking blue rare, even though it was asked for medium well.  The boar wrapped with bacon looked good on first glance, but when I cut into it with a knife it looked as rare as the steak.  At first I thought maybe it was OK and bit into the center, but the meat was literally raw, so I had to send it back.  After a while a woman who was not the waiter showed up and said something about the boar being prepared sous vide (lol) and that it's 'usually served rare, but if you want us to heat it more we can do that'.   As I'm sitting there I'm thinking wouldn't it be great if you could ask your guests if they want their meat defaulted to dripping blood.  Anyway, after they cooked it some more and re-served it the waiter started coming back every five minutes to ask if it's OK.  Towards the end I was still working on the salad on the plate, and mid-chew while my utensils were down the guy came by and took the plate, asking if he had permission but not waiting for a response, causing me to immediately lose what remained of a paltry appetite.  That pretty much sums up the night right there.
author: Tommy Q.

description: Came in for dinner with my family of four and loved it!  We're all foodies and appreciated the menu and dishes.  We had chickpea meatballs and stuffed peppers as an appetizer and loved them both.  Our mains were unique and well prepared.  Great service, I would recommend a visit here to friend and family.
author: John B.

description:
We got lucky with our Sunday reservation - we had the 2nd floor to ourselves, so it was like a private room, which was nice.  There was a bathroom on the floor, too, which was convenient.  

We started with a bunch of cocktail orders, but two of the drinks we requested were unavailable because they didn't have the ingredients. It was disappointing, but they were really nice about letting us choose alternative drinks and not charging us for them!  

Drinks that we did end up getting:
- George's dragon: strong on the vinegar and ginger, but interesting  
- Caipirihna de framboesa: a little sweet for me, but you can taste the cachaca, which is nice  
- Marley in the mountains: interesting combination of flavors, but I'm not a huge fan of the singani 63

Food: 
- Brussels sprouts: with fish sauce caramel. The brussels sprouts were nicely roasted, and the sauce was a good mix of savory and sweet. I liked this a lot
- Chickpea meatballs: good texture, and the harissa glaze, feta, and tomato chutney had lots of flavor
- Korean fried chicken: good sauce, but I wish there were more of it. The breast meat ended up kind of dry, but it was a really big portion
- Ricotta gnocchi: definitely add pork belly for texture and flavor; the gnocchi was very pillowy, but it would have been nice to have a sear on it for some extra texture. It's also a big portion, and I think it's better for sharing
- Salmon cakes: the salmon itself was fine, but I liked the stuff underneath more - sunchoke puree, roasted mushrooms, beets, salsify
- Kurobuta pork chop: good flavor but unfortunately dry

I would get the brussels sprouts and chickpea meatballs again - I think the appetizers were the highlight.  Overall, portions were big, and the value is pretty good, but none of the mains were amazing. 

I was worried we would get ignored since we were the only people on that floor, but our server was great about checking in, refilling water, etc.
author: Marilyn H.

description: Came here for dinner on a Thursday night with some friends. The menu isn't big, which would explain why ALL FOUR OF US got the gnocchi. Ha. Never have I ever, but I really wanted it! pork belly gnocchi?!?! YES, please! Sadly the dish wasn't as good as I was expecting, just good, not great. We started with the brussel sprouts which were delish! The place is very cute and has a fun ambiance, some rowdy dudes pounding beers at the table behind us, but overall it was a nice time!
author: Ally T.

description:
A coworker and I decided to try this place out. We were in search for a light dinner and stumbled across this restaurant. 

The decor is nice, it's cozy,  there appeared to be 2 levels of seating.  I say cozy because the tables are pretty close to one another so having a conversation with those in your party can be a bit of if a challenge. But overall it was nice. 

In terms of food, it was delicious but portions were small for the price. I have to say the brussel sprouts appetizer was one of the best I've had.  The sweetness of the sauce balanced well with the slight bitterness from the brussel sprouts.  The chicken roulade was good,  the chichen was a bit dry but the flavors were good.  

This isn't a place to try if you're hungry,  but worth trying if you want a lighter meal.
author: Geneva L.

description: Love this place. I can't wait to go back. The staff was amazing and hilarious. The food was friggin awesome. The service was outstanding. We were there to see a show at the Masonic and the bartender put Morrissey on for us!!! It was all such a great experience. I will be back for any and all shows at the Masonic. Love this place.
author: Nancy R.

description:
What happened to customer service? Apparently, there is 1 star worth at this restaurant. 

I called the restaurant to find out about some items on the menu...

When I called to check the menu options, I was told the menu online was very detailed - okay, strike one, brush off my questions. Finally, I get an explanation of the chicken. Next, I ask if there can be an accommodation to the salad. Basically, I just need salad leaves and vinaigrette and nothing else, easy and fast right? I am told no accommodation can be made, the explanation being that this is a "busy restaurant" with no time to accommodate individuals. Strike two - here's my Yelp review. 

I'm so disappointed by the rude customer service, especially from a host. I've had accommodations made at 2 Michelin star restaurants - this place needs to step up their customer service game.
author: Irina R.

description:
Wow, the brussel sprouts here were amazing, probably the best I've ever had, but that's probably the only thing I can really rave about.

Upon walking in, I was really pleased with the ambiance of this restaurant. It has an open ceiling, dim lighting, and rustic furniture, giving it a very nice and comfortable vibe for dinner. We ordered: 3 brussel sprouts (lol, yes, they were that good), mussels, fettuccine, and pork tenderloin. The pork was very disappointing - bland and not cooked well. Surprisingly though, the roasted vegetables that came on the size were cooked to perfection, and was definitely everyone's favorite part of the dish. If I based my review on the ambiance and the food, I probably would have given 4 starts overall, but well, let's talk a bit about the service that night.

Upon ordering our drinks, our waitress put in all our drink orders, along with a martini that one of my friends ordered. Whatever drink came out was not a martini, so my friend nicely mentioned what liquors he was expecting to be in it and the waitress responded with "I know what a gin martini is made with." Seriously? I don't know what sort of training she went through but from my experiences, you never talk to a customer like that in the food business. Strike 1.

We also received bread that was really fresh and went well with the sauce the mussels came with. When we asked the waitress for a second order of bread, she did this really big hesitant sigh, looked at us for a second like she didn't want to give us more bread, then turned towards the kitchen and left. We thought it was odd but she did bring us a second basket of bread so we brushed it off. We finish up eating, and when the bill comes, I look through it and see a charge for extra bread, $4. If you're going to charge us for bread, at least tell your customers, and not just mischievously slip it in the bill. Strike 2.

So this last part was what really just put me over the edge. I rarely give a place 1 star but this waitress gave us one of the worst dining experiences I've ever been through. When she handed us the bill, she also said, "Oh by the way, I took off the gin martini, it's on us." We all thought it was a very nice gesture as that's what a lot of places do occasionally when they mess up on an order. I look over the bill, and the gin martini is still there, so we call her back over and point out that the martini was still charged. She goes "Oh I meant the first martini that was sent back to the bar, I know you didn't drink it but we still made you 2 drinks." Are you kidding me? Throughout my years and years of dining/bar experiences, I have never heard of anything like this. Why would you say you're comping the drink when the customer didn't even drink it........? Unbelievable, Strike 3.

I really thought a restaurant like Aliment would have had better service, but it was truly a huge disappointment and I unfortunately will not be coming back here. Aliment, please do something to change the way your waitresses/waiters are trained as it really is hurting the business.
author: Angela K.

description:
I was excited to check out this restaurant and was having a nice evening out with my family. Unfortunately, I don't think I've had a meal worse than this in my life. Everything we had was borderline flavorless and the things that weren't were overcooked. I understand a kitchen falling short, but even if they were cooked appropriately the food was just bad. Do not waste your money. 

The restaurant itself looked and was hoping for the best but was seriously let down. 

Our server was so nice and charming, we didn't want to complain. He was genuinely the highlight of our meal. He was Irish and took great care of us.
author: Claire W.

description: Aliment was a great restaurant to visit since they were so close to our hotel, but also because the food was delicious! We ordered the Brussel Sprouts and the Ricotta Gnocchi with Pork Belly and perfect for the both of us.
author: Leslie M.

description:
Wow, I really wanted to like this place based on the décor, but the food was extremely (extremely) disappointing. The NY strip - horrible. Fatty, tough, and thin. The salmon cakes - so salty that we could only finish one. The burger - burnt on the outside. The muscles were decent, but that's the only compliment I can give on the food.

On a positive - the service was extremely good! If not for the wait staff and decor, certainly a one star restaurant.  Sorry, but the overpriced food and cocktails is hard to get over.
author: J J.

description:
This place has a lot of potential. The ambiance and drink selections are great. The service is great. Food is great. 

I only take issue with the price and portion sizes. Plates are designed to share, but you need to order lots of food to feel truly full. We ordered lamb, burger and shrimp and grits and were hungry a few hours later. That combined with drinks (beers) topped $90 bucks The food was great, but not great enough to justify such a small portion for the price. I would expect this of a restaurant billed as more "fancy", but Aliment seemed to be too laid back to be in that price bracket. Maybe I didn't quite know what I was getting into. Would be a great spot for just drinks and/or a snack.
author: Kathryn P.

description:
Nice dinner spot that is borderline expensive (entrees are within the $15-$18 range) but definitely worth it. The gnocchi, burger and brussels sprouts were quite good. The fries, however, were not.
