One very important tip: Don't sit in the upstairs back room. It's hot, stuffy and far removed from the energy downstairs. Make a reservation to avoid ending up in this closet.
author: Nick K.

description: Ate here for the first time. The steak burger was yummers. And their spicy chicken was amaze balls.
author: Darrell D.

description: Loved the innovative menu that was every bit as tasty as it sounded when I read it. Also love that the menu was short. They do maybe 4 or 5 small plates and about the same number of main courses and everything we had was awesome. So they focus on a few dishes and do them all really well. Portion size was generous which I appreciate especially when it's on the pricey side. The service was friendly, informal, and attentive. I really have nothing negative to say except that they should find a new IPA for their tap rotation as Pine Street was pretty bad especially in NorCal where there are so many great ones (Lagunitas, Big Daddy, etc.). I will come to Aliment now every time I'm in town.
author: Richard Y.

description:
Wonderful neighborhood restaurant. For dinner, we had the following items:

Brussel sprouts- really crunchy and flavorful 

Mussels- huge order and probably could be an entree. Tons of chorizo and pickled red cabbage was a nice touch

Pork chop- very tender. The sauce that accompanied it was amazing 

Fried chicken- this was my least favorite, a little dry but it was still not bad. 

Chocolate cake- great way to finish off our meal after all the savory food 

I will be back since I live close by
author: Christine S.

description: Went in on a whim and was so pleasantly surprised. The wait staff were nice and helpful and made me and my friend feel really welcome. Then we tried the happy hour menu and got 4 dishes; peppers, the sprouts, the fries and the DONUTS! The donuts were amazing. My friend said they were like little hugs in your mouth and I agree.
author: Adaobi N.

description:
Came here with a group of 9, since we wanted to go to a nearby bar. 
Service: Good.
Ambiance: Comfortable since we were sitting upstairs with 4 other tables. 
Food: Brussel sprouts were delicious with a hint of fish sauce. Sounds strange but it was good with also a hint of sweetness (maybe from honey?). I got their famous fried chicken which the portion was HUGE and I thought the sauce was too overwhelming, heavy and salty. I was quite disappointed with this dish. I think they should give more of their sides (kimchi) since they gave us a little-itty bitty of it - it would probably help out with the saltiness of the sauce. I also tried their pork chop which was tender and delicious. I'd get that over the fried chicken by far! We tried getting their ice cream, but unfortunately, it was too frozen to be served.

Come back? I don't know.
author: Hey Y.

description: Came for dinner and the tail end of Happy Hour: Brussels Sprouts were amazing! Mussels Very good, Mac and cheese delicious, beet salad very good. Service was excellent  Bread pudding highly recommended!
author: C K.

description:
Straight to the food!

The Pastrami Short Rib had a nicely cooked egg. 6 minutes must be the magic number. Good way to start. The Bolognese was disappointing. Surprisingly received rigatoni pasta. Liked the slight heat but didn't find anything special about the sauce and it's all about the sauce! The Pork Shank was the better entree. It came with spaetzel and mustard greens making a nice rounded plate and i'd order it again. Desserts were just okay. House Made ice cream didn't have strong flavors coming through. Refreshing with the Flourless Chocolate Cake though! 

Overall, mixed feelings about Aliment. Menu sounds great. The food was either amazing or a complete miss though. The prices feel higher than they should be.
author: Samantha L.

description: I saw this place in June when I walked by it during a trip but didn't get a chance to stop in. So today I was in town again and made the stop. WOW. Amazing bar and bartenders who make you feel special and real pros. Kitchen and food equally amazing food. This is THE place. You won't go wrong. A lot of specialty cocktails, great craft local brews and lots of good meat-based meals. Everything made fresh in an open kitchen with quality ingredients you can taste. Don't hesitate on this one and I don't give such glowing reviews easily.
author: Zanku A.

description:
We were walking back home when we passed this place. We decided to stop by and share couple dishes here. 

The most memorable are:
- Kale salad
- Gnocchi, which were like little pieces of heaven. Luckily I also had a fresh jar of truffle salt that I just bought at the Ferry Building, and we indulged on this rich fatty flavour. 
Thankfully it was shared between two people which I think was perfect!

Dinner for two with a glass fo beer and a glass of wine was just about $70.
author: Anelya S.

description:
I came here with a friend before heading to a Josh Groban concert together, and I couldn't have asked for a better dining experience before our magical musical adventure. From the moment I walked in and took a seat at the bar, the bartender was extremely attentive, always making sure that I had a drink or appetizer in front of me while I was waiting for my friend.

We ordered the brussel sprouts, which had toasted nori and fish sauce caramel. Probably one of the godliest-tasting brussel sprouts I've ever had! SO GOOD. Would totally come back just to have these again. My friend and I split the Ricotta Gnocchi with pork belly and Lamb Sirloin with zatar spice. Both were amazing. I liked being able to share smaller plates rather than order large portions of food. Between the two of us, these three dishes (plus wine) were enough for a modest dinner so we weren't stuffed before the concert. 

Overall excellent service and food!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
My friend and I decided to come here since it was 3 blocks away from the Masonic which is where we saw a Josh Groban concert (really good by the way). 

The food here was amazing.  Between the two of us, we ordered brussel sprouts, the lamb shank, and the ricotta gnocchi with pork belly.  they were all so good.  I think the brussel sprouts were some of the best I've had.  The little asian flair they had on them were really great. The other two were great as well.  The lamb shank with the tzatziki sauce was delicious.  The gnocchi had a great texture and also the pork belly - yum! 

Overall, great place and location to eat at. Definitely should come back and try some other items. 

Protip: BRUSSEL SPROUTS.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Food's bomb in a comfort setting.

Housemade gnocchi seems time consuming. The Brussels sprouts are the real winner here. I wish I had fish sauce caramel at home..

If they have a small meat item with kimchee such as winglets or riblets, DO IT. Their kimchee is a little different , I'd have to ask the chef about it at some point.

Speaking of the chef, he's pretty involved in this restaurants day to day and is a genuinely cool dude. He knows his hockey and the food is cool.

Especially w how cold it is you guys should make a soup.

Try to get Keri as a server. She knows the menu inside and out and makes the ice cream too! 

If they aren't making beer yet keep bugging the bartender till they do it!

Also ask him for an aquavitae specialty. Their collection is impressive.
author: Edward F.

description:
I got to eat at Alimentation a couple days ago, and i'm so glad I did, despite the current star rating. Have no idea why it is only 3 1/2 stars. 

I sat at the bar and the bartenders were both very courteous and attentive. Apparently I didn't read the menu close enough and almost doubled up on the fries by ordering a side of fries with the burger (which isn't on the website menu, but was on the menu in the restaurant). Bartender pointed it out (the one that looks like Wash from Firefly) and so I ended up getting the Brussels Sprouts instead, along with the burger.

The Brussels Sprouts were very very delicious, but the burger. Oh my God that burger. It did come with a large helping of fries, but that burger. Dat burger. I ate it as slowly as possible. I don't remember everything that the menu said was on it, aside from "Bacon Jam." 

Nuff said.

Well not really, but suffice to say that if you have the opportunity to go to Aliment, and you're deciding between the burger and something else, definitely give it a shot.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I celebrated my best friends bday here and the food and service was excellent! The fries Brussels sprouts are a must here, as well as the Mussels with Chorizo. I just wish we had extra bread to soak up the broth in which the mussels were cooked in. 
Almost everyone has the pork shank and it was a unanimous YES! And YUM! The sauce is so good and the pork falls right off the bone. I had the fried chicken breast with polenta and cream corn. It was amazing! The chicken was so juicy and the polenta was amazing. This place is a must for visitors. The staff was extremely attentive.
author: Giovanni S.

description: Pleasant surprise - just picked this spot randomly because it was close to the Masonic...turns hour ....Great happy hour, good value, bold flavors, good sharing portions, good cocktails, great service and friendly staff. A perfect spot to grab a bite:drink before or after a show at the Masonic.
author: Phantom Of Yel P.

description:
I was honestly not that impressed with this place. I went with 3 other people so we tried a lot of things, and the only thing that was really good was the tomato soup that came with the grilled cheese.

Pastrami Slider- It was good but not super amazing (3.5/5)
Wings- Not a huge fan (2/5)
French Fries- wayyyy too salty for my taste. Also not super crispy (2/5)
Brussel Sprouts- these were good, good sauce, but I would like personally liked them a little crispier. However if I came here again, I would order them again (4/5)
Scallops- Didn't love the sauce or the texture (2.5/5)
Ricotta Gnocchi- I didnt' want to add the pork belly but the other people didn't- i wouldn't recommend it. The Gnocchi was fine but not amazing (3/5)

Originally we were going to try a burger, but were told that the burger can only be cooked medium well, which is way too overcooked in my opinion. I also thought it was weird that the chef couldn't cook it less, but our waitress told us that they had issues in the past of people sending it back because it was undercooked, so now the chef only cooks it medium to medium well. We couldn't even get it just medium.

Wine- we got a bottle of the malbec which was good, and I also had a glass of the house pinot at happy hour. Wine was good and not ridiculously expensive

Overall- The atmosphere is cute, though kind of hipstery for my taste. Our waitress was really nice and accommodating. The wine was good and the price was standard for SF. However, I was really under impressed with the food and wouldn't go out of my way to come back here.
author: Jenna G.

description:
With an empty stomach and high hopes of a good meal a friend of mine and I attended Aliment hoping for a night of good eats. 

Though the place is small, it does have a rather nice ambience and the staff were friendly at the start. We waited entirely too long for water, but the waitress who was watching our area was quite busy so that was understandable. 

Once we placed our order, the brussel sprout appetizer came out quickly which was really quite good. Unfortunately, this was the last thing that went right with the meal. 

While I'm not usually a burger guy in an establishment such as this, my friend told me that he'd had it before and it was a great burger.  I generally go off suggestions from those with experience, so we both ordered the same burger for our dinner. 

20 minutes after ordering our waitress returned to let us know that they were "Out of burgers."
WHO runs out of burgers?? We substituted our second best choice as we'd seen a nearby diner receiving it for her meal, so thought it might be a good substitute. 

Once the Korean Style Fried Chicken arrived, I was disappointed to find out that the only thing "Korean" about it was the incredibly spicy BBQ sauce that it was drowning in. Trying a few bits of the bird that weren't doused, I discovered that the sauce was the only thing providing it with flavor as there was no real spice to the batter the bird had been fried in. While my friend decided to settle for what was already in front of him, I decided that I wasn't going to punish myself by trying to finish this poorly executed mess. 

I politely went and found the waitress standing with one of her coworkers and explained that the meal was both too spicy and not something I could eat, and asked if she could please remove it from the tab. She suggested I take a look at the menu for a replacement, and I  settled for my third choice of salmon cakes. 

Sigh... 
Honestly this just isn't a well thought out dish. While the salmon cakes were ok, there were a lot of things going on with the dish that didn't seem to really have any connection to any other item on the plate. The small mushrooms were fine, but seemed an odd pairing with the fish as they weren't prepared together or in the same fashion. There was an interesting starchy root vegetable that was plated with this, but it was cold compared with the the rest of the ingredients and seem to only serve the function of visual interest, while totally lacking flavor or preparation. There were huge wedges of what smelled like smoked beets but tasted like something dumped straight out of a can, and all of this sat in a lukewarm puddle of sunchoke sauce, which again seemed to be in no way related to anything else on the plate. 

Unfortunately the hopeful name of Aliment is a complete misnomer. In this case Ailment is much more apropos. There's a lot of great food in San Francisco. If you're looking for a nice meal, and you pass this place, do yourself a favor and keep walking.
author: Travis R.

description: Hands down, the coolest spot on Bush st. Easily the best burger I've had in SF and exceptional drinks. Happy hour at the bar can't be beat. If you're in Nob Hill, it's a must visit.
author: Chris B.

description: Small restaurant, was put on the 2nd floor that had a very low ceiling, felt claustrophobic. Bland pork chop with nothing on the side that cost $27. Very overpriced.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Good happy hour, but it's limited to the bar and front window area. You cannot order happy hour at the tables, even if you have a reservation. I don't love that to be honest. 

The food was four stars. ambience three stars. 

I would be back for happy hour but they should definitely not be so stingy with the seating!!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Can I say - BEST Brussel Sprouts I have ever eaten! Oh yes my friends, this is true!

I was able to dine here with coworkers on a Wednesday night. We sat in the upstairs dining area which was decorated beautifully! So posh!

We ordered a little bit of everything off of the menu including;
BRUSSEL SPROUTS - toasted nori, fish sauce caramel
RED CURRY MUSSELS
Korean BBQ RIBLETS
Kale Salad
RAMEN FRIED CHICKEN BITS
BEET SALAD
LAMB SIRLOIN
SHRIMP & GRITS

My favs included, yes, the brussel sprouts, Kale Salad, Chicken bits, Beet Salad, and the Lamb Sirloin.

Living in the south, we are kinda connoisseurs on shrimp and grits. These were not my favorite but still pretty damn good!

The wine selection was superb! We enjoyed a wonderful bottle of a Pino Noir which was FAB (and I'm usually not a Pino lover).

All in all great service, great food, great experience!
author: Kellie M.

description: Interesting menu, cool space, nice ambiance and excellent drinks! The upstairs is huge! Sara was lovely and juggling a very busy Friday night. My Korean chicken was delicious and their famous brusselsprouts  are awesome!! Nice night.
author: Cecilia D.

description: Sat at the bar and walked out with new friends. BEST service I've had in a long time in this city thanks to Rachel, Lucka, Jose, & Tony ta tas!!! The sangria is off the hook! The chemistry behind the bar is so inviting and welcoming. Order the brussel sprouts and make sure to hit on Lucka. He loves it.
author: Bird E.

description: Avoid at all costs. We stopped in for a cocktail and dinner and were horribly disappointed. We ordered 2 of the 5 mains - as suggested by the server (who had the personality of a wet rag) - and didn't eat one good bite. It sounded good! And my dish had a flower! The rest could have been scrapped into the trash. Never to return.
author: Brad H.

description:
Aliment was a recommendation from the concierge at the InterContinental Mark Hopkins hotel. Since it was "just around the corner," meaning two blocks away but down a HUGE steep hill, my friend and I ventured to dinner around 7pm on a Tuesday night. The place wasn't quite full yet, but by the time we left around an hour and a half later, it was packed. 

We enjoyed some local white wine, as suggested by our server, along with fresh pasta. I loved the Bolognese, while my friend tried one of the salads. And we shared the Macaroni & Cheese, which came with bits of bacon. 

The meal was very pleasant, and we were sure to tell our concierge that his recommendation was great. The walk back up the hill post-dinner was a doozy, though.
author: Krista J.

description:
After a much needed session with my 'Mane' man, we decided to grab a bite and drink at a nearby restaurant, and one that neither of us had been to (which is so rare).

Aliment is such a hidden gem in the heart of Union Square. We were both so impressed at how sleek and inviting this place was. Although we didn't have ressies (which you can make on opentable), the hostess brought us upstairs to an upstairs loft-style dining area. Also upstairs is a separate room for more seating or even private parties (at least there was one at the time we had dinner). 

So, the menu consists of lots of different small plates (chicken, foie gras, mussels, salads) along with a handful of entree selections (pasta, burger, steak, fish). Menu does seem to change based on what's in season or Chef's selections, so keep that in mind when ordering (as items may not be exactly as stated on the website). The menu items are simple, yet with surprising element. For example, there was fried chicken bites as a small plate, but they were 'RAMEN fried chicken bites.' They were crisp to perfection and the chicken super juicy. The spaghetti bolognese was amazing, but had a hint of spiciness to it (according to my dinner date). We shared the kale salad (and Hunter Pence would definitely approve)! I had the burger, which was outstanding, and one of the best in SF (in my humble opinion). Tender and mouthwatering and medium to perfection. Fries were also perfectly crisp and seasoned. Both of us weren't following our 'diet,' as we were in a lovey celebratory (and catch-up) mood!

Service is friendly and prompt. Water served upon request (for all restos now in the Bay Area due to our severe drought). Prices are reasonable and won't break the bank. Decent wine and beer selection, too!

Can't wait to return to Aliment to try more dishes.
Go on and try it for yourself! Promise you won't be disappointed!

Cheers and happy end of July!
author: Gill C.

description:
Let me start by saying I love the food, drink, and atmosphere here. However, when I went there tonight, the hostess' attitude toward an older couple completely put me off of the restaurant. 

If an older couple (or person) who has mobility issues walks into the restaurant, why would you give them the option only of climbing stairs or sitting on bar stools they have a hard time getting onto? If your booths are "reserved," and that's your policy, that's fine--but exceptions can and should be made for people who can't sit at the bar because of mobility issues.
author: Midori H.

description: Ahi Poke is suuuuper spicy, but no mention on the menu of any "spicy" ingredients. I could not eat the entire bowl, such a waste, honestly. Poke is one of my most favorite foods and I absolutely could not stand that this dish was pretty unbearable, when it came to the level of "heat". Wholly molly, I could have drank an entire pitcher of milk with this dish. This place had so much potential because it had the freshest ingredients: bok choy, Chinese long beans and ahi tuna. I made reservations through Yelp for 7:15pm and upon arrival we were seated immediately and even given a choice of tables, when we walked upstairs. The waitress was super nice, but when I told her what was wrong with my dish, she didn't seem to care and kind of blew it off; she was even surprised I said it was too spicy. I told her that I couldn't continue to eat it and felt like I was going to die because it was so spicy. Oh well. That's one of the reasons why I never really express my opinions when the wait staff asks how things were. Even though the portions were a decent size for the price I paid, I was so disappointed because I could not even finish my dish. Will I be back? Sadly, probably not.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
The ramen fried chicken bits were LIT. Def get these as an appetizer.

The food selection is better than the wine selection which is better than the beer selection, so this place is good for after work dinner/drinks with an emphasis on the dinner.

Friend and I tried the burger (which they doused with black pepper...really a bit too much) and the gnocchi. Gnocchi is A+. Entrees run on the expensive side (30+ per plate for most of them, except the ones we tried). 

It's a really nice space that's quiet enough to have a conversation.
author: Susan L.

description: The brussel sprouts were so good. I need that recipe.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Ambiance: Beautiful decor inside. We sat downstairs and had a view of the open kitchen. It's noisy because of this, but it's great to be able to see the food being prepared. I think it shows a pride in what they do and accountability for good health practices. 

Service: Service was so-so. Our waiter seemed disinterested in us once he learned we weren't going to be ordering drinks. So irritating. There was a gentleman who brought out our food though and cleared our plates who was very friendly.

Food: I think the menu changes pretty regularly which may be why it isn't up to date on Yelp. I really wanted to like the food, but it was just ok. Given the price of the food, I was expecting more.
-Macaroni and cheese: this was made with a different type of noodle. The cheese sauce was mild and could have used a bit more cheese and/or some more flavoring.
-Lamb: This was pretty tender and came with a side of tzatziki which was really complementary.
-Ramen chicken wings: I'm not quite sure where the ramen came in as these seemed like normal chicken wings. They were really crispy and quite good, but nothing special.
-Tuna salad: Mixed greens. Tuna was okay. The dressing on the salad was pretty good though.
author: Susan G.

description:
I've only been here twice. The first time was for a date, and I barely remember how the food tasted because I was super nervous aahahahhAHHaahahahh. I have a pretty big appetite, but I don't know where it went that night. Since I remembered really liking the feel, atmosphere, decor, size, whatever of this place, I came back for a second time with a friend visiting from out of town... and yummmmmm the food was yumm. I really like the brussel sprouts and lamb! The cab is great too. Make a reservation (ask for a table at upstairs balcony!!), but if the night is booked, then check out the bar for seating (first come first serve).

Connecting to cellular data here seems to be impossible (lte and 3g), so you're probably not reading this review on your phone at the restaurant. If you are, please tell me what carrier you have.
author: Annie S.

description:
Aliment totally hit the spot for me. There are about a trillion menus in SF offering small plates and New American upscale fare, but so many do such an average job of pumping out said dishes. Aliment's menu selections hit home with me and they delivered on quality. 

The menu here offers a few salads, some bar snacks, a selection of small plates and some full entrees, so there's something for everyone. I went with the wedge salad with smoked 1000-island dressing. This is a twist on the classic wedge, with three small romaine wedges grilled, then topped with a delicious smoked dressing and some fried shallots. So, so delicious. Next up, the brussels, which seem to be the house specialty. They have nori and fish sauce glaze. Perfectly cooked, insanely good. I could eat these sweet, salty, fishy morsels every day. The fish sauce is pretty light (for my standards), so don't be put off by that description. It's just a hint. I paired these with the burger. My current diet necessitates removing the bun and fries, and going with a side salad next to the burger instead. The patty is large and the meat quality very good. Great flavor, cooked a perfect mid-rare, with a nice cheese and pickles. Perfection. 

To drink, I enjoyed a nice French pink, and then a glass of Sancerre. Both worthy. Staff here is on point. Friendly, welcoming, funny. The dude behind the bar is totally enjoyable. The space itself has a night lightness to it, while still feeling cozy and intimate. 

Total for my meal including a salad, small plate and burger with two glasses of wine? $50. In SF, or anywhere, I consider that solid. Especially considering the wine clocked in at around $20-$25 of the total bill. 

Aliment is worthy of much more than the (current) 3.5-star rating on Yelp. I'll surely be back, and I'm bringing friends.
author: Don B.

description:
This place is as solid as Barbacco.  We had the meat and cheese plate and it was great.  The salmon appetizer was really good too.  The homemade pasta was delicious.  The apple turnover was a little bread-y.  The service was efficient and friendly, they have a great wine menu and food.  Our server was very knowledgeable and organized.

I'd definitely come back.
author: Chris L.

description: I just checked in to the French Inn down the street.   Was a bit parched from traveling all day from Jax Florida.  Hung up my clothes and hit the street looking fer a thirst quencher. The vibe from the street drew me in.  Tony and Rachael both greeted my wife and I on our first step in the door.   Great greeting!!!!   Ordered some local vino and the Brussels sprouts and some pork stuffed peppers.  Son!!!!   Freaking fantastic!!   I am still here and I don't want to leave.   But the city beckons.   I will be back though.
author: Ed M.

description:
Great Service! Delicious Food! Nice Ambiance!

Server was very helpful. Recommended a great bottle of wine, which was only $40. I notice servers tend to recommend the most expensive wine, not this one.  

The dishes the server recommended were phenomenal. My friend and I shared the chopped kale salad and the braised short rib. Tender and Delicious! 

My other friend ordered the Wagyu Burger, wagyu beef is high quality beef from Kobe, Japan. It is higher in monounsaturated fats, omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids and is lower in cholesterol than commodity beef. I didn't try it, but my friend really liked it. 

Dan the wine man sent over some samples of great wine throughout our meal. My friends and I were treated first class. 

The service and food were outstanding!  I will definitely be back!
author: Rachel M.

description:
they accept reservations but then they dont honor them...Friend made reservations, we arrived on time. but we weren't seated until 40 minutes later...

Their menu is superrrrr tiny. did not like that at all.

brussel sprouts were yum, but i can make these at home pretty well myself :P

thrice cooked fries were good, but not sure if they were $10 good?

pastrami sliders were most disappointing for me. Pretzel bun was yum, but the pastrami was soooooo salty, it was almost inedible. 

gnocchi was OK, pork belly was good, but not enough of it.

food was honestly nothing special, and the whole reservations thing was annoying as hell.
author: Angela C.

description:
The food quality was great. Excellent main courses.
 Service was lacking, to the point of a low review. At this price point, I think it's fair to expect better service. For example, the cocktail glasses were never cleared from the table, and they were still delivering more drinks.
Ask to sit downstairs or the terrace. The "wine room" was too noisy. We had to raise our voices to be heard.
author: Adam G.

description: I visited Aliment with a group of ten people last week and had a great experience.  We were seated upstairs and had that space to ourselves almost the entire night.  The service was good, the atmosphere was nice and the menu (although somewhat limited) was actually quite tasty.  We started out with meat & cheese, wings, brussels sprouts and mac 'n cheese - a solid introduction to this restaurant for sure!  I enjoyed the chicken roulade for my entree and really enjoyed it - moist, flavorful and downright tasty.  We finished off the meal with the chocolate cake (rich and sinful) and the rose and vanilla homemade ice cream (delicious!).
author: Jennifer S.

description: SLOWWWW Service! Barkeeps barely pay attention to you. Food is just ok! Nothing special here...
author: Madhusudhan R.

description: I had the ricotta gnocchi and the Brussels sprouts.  The gnocchi wasn't great.  It honestly wasn't flavorful.  I jealously looked at the people's food that was around me and envied it because it looked so much better.  The Brussels sprouts were pretty good though.  Sweet and crispy.  This place does have a good wine selection though and the server was really friendly.  Warning though, the upstairs level of this restaurant gets so hot and humid. I was uncomfortably hot while eating dinner.
author: Kristy R.

description:
My family and I stumbled across Ailment on a Friday evening after several failed attempts to get a table for dinner. We were able to reserve a table on OpenTable and we were seated as soon as we came in.

Unfortunately, I did not love the food and found everything to be incredibly overpriced. The menu was very small, and they didn't offer many of the dishes I saw on Yelp. We also weren't told of any specials. Between the five of us we ordered the Brussels sprouts, two burgers, pastrami sliders and tuna poke. The food was good and we had plenty to eat, but I thought everything was a bit over-seasoned and a bit over-salted.

We were so hungry by the time we found a table somewhere for dinner so it served its purpose. But I would not recommend it, nor would I return if I'm back in the city.
author: Morgan C.

description: Food is hit or miss, and wine was good, but VERY small pours for the price. We loved two of our dishes (mussels and brussels sprouts) and disliked two (pork stuffed peppers and Korean fried chicken). Everything was very overpriced for such small portions- two apps and two entrees did not fill us (2 people) up. Will likely not be going back.
author: Penny B.

description:
Pros: Food here was spot on. Drink was alright.. definitely interesting. They care a lot about their customers and do everything they can to accommodate. 

Cons: The place is small and has major acoustic issues-especially in the upstairs room. It's no fun having to repeat everything you say because it's so loud in there. Needs some fabric to absorb sound.
author: Steve T.

description: My daughter took us to this restaurant after reading the yelp reviews. I think it had 4 1/2 stars overall. This was our experience. For the three of us the bill came to 200 which included the tip. For that you would expect an exceptional meal for everyone. I ordered a medium burger and it came out burnt. My wife's fish was also overcooked. The waitstaff we had was good, Very friendly. The waitstaff and The wine earned this restaurant one star. The food really sucked.
author: Paul W.

description:
Well, the 4 stars led me in the right direction.
The service was great, the food was great! You should definitely try Happy Hour! 5-7 pm.
I ended up having the Pork Chop.....OMG!
A total yum-fest!
Phil (the handsome one) and Kevin provided A++ service at the bar (very super attentive), and, Eric and Andy created that miracle called Kurobuta pork chop!
Give it a try!
author: Roger C.

description:
Before starting our holiday shopping, my friend and I decided to grab a quick bite to eat. After browsing the countless options in the area, Aliment peaked my interest so off we went. 

We chose to split the Aliment fried chicken: Fried chicken and savory waffle balls and a side of fried Brussels sprouts 

Chicken had a good fried coating, seasoned well and moist

Waffle balls felt like they were undercooked due to being so dense and wet on the inside but couldn't tell for sure. The flavor was underwhelming but paired with the bourbon laced syrup it helped to elevate the profile of the dish 

Brussels sprouts were packed with umami flavor, courtesy of the caramel fish sauce lacquered on each petal. The portion was rather copious and easily shareable for four people 

Service was straight forward, no real complaints

Overall Thoughts

I certainly see the potential of Aliment and look forward to going back for dinner
author: Eddie W.

description:
Before coming here, I told my friends "apparently the brussel sprouts are a must" and they rolled their eyes saying "every restaurant always says their brussel sprouts are a must..." but you know what, the ones here definitely are a must! Yum! Be warned though, you'll have to be a fan of fish sauce. 

Overall I had a lovely meal - I got two small plates (japanese greens salads and the yummy chicken bits) and it was very generous portions - more than enough for one person. 

It was relatively simple to get a reservation via opentable - no hassle and lots of available slots.
author: Jennie C.

description:
Over maybe 6 visits, one bad experience. The food is usually good and with a good service (read below to the one very bad experience, I guess it happens everywhere). 

4 stars out of 5 because it is a bit over priced ($150-$200 for 4 people, including cocktails and some deserts). 

--------------

I've been to this place 4-5 times and it is usually pretty good (4 stars good).

This time we wanted to bring friends over and we ended up upstairs, with a very loud group of 20 people.
The meat was not that good, greasy, and on top of that we got the gratuity of 18% included, for 4 people!

This is not how this should work.
author: Michel P.

description:
Yesterday was my second time I was there.
At first, I celebrated my friends bday with girls only. We ordered appetizers only, and it was a great idea. Brussels sprouts - good to order
French Fries -  delicious, good to order
Chicken wings- alright, can be ordered
Cheese Plater - hmmm, hold off there and think twice to order 
Meat and cheese - not to order, nothing to share and it was not interesting at all 
Main are not great at all:
Steak - hmm, not to order
Pasta - whatever 
Gnocchi - good to order. Yummy 

Haven't tried anything else. 

Wine selection is good enough, but nothing special.
author: Jenna F.

description: I'd totally give the place 5 stars if the restaurant didn't throw away my leftovers by accident instead of boxing them up.  However the fried brussel sprouts are so delicious.  I'd come back just for that.
author: Becca S.

description: All three of us loved our first visit to Ailment.  We had all walked by it before yet we had never been in.  From the bartender to our server to another worker, they all treated us VERY well.  We will certainly be back! I love getting consistent service from every staff member we encountered.  That is a huge plus!  Thanks Ailment staff and especially Jose - you rock!
author: J J.

description:
Alright, went here last Friday and it was pretty good.  Overall it was a very fun place to try out with a large group because we got to try pretty much everything on the menu.  So let me just go down the list and talk about what we got.

Melon salad- delicous, its more of a salad with melons in it, but really good.  Mussels- didnt try the actual mussels bc im not a fan of shellfish, but the sauce was bomb, and it was a huge bowlful.  salted cod cakes (comes with 2),  ricotta gnocchi (small serving, very good), baby back riblets, butlers steak, kurabuta pork belly, kale salad (little overdressed, but really good), pastrami short ribs (very peppery/salty and good), grilled rack of lamb (3 pieces), fried brussel sprouts (very sweet, but delish).  

Anyway was not disappointed with any of our choices.  We also got some wine, which was nice high pours but only complaint there was that the price of a bottle is the same price as 4 glasses, so there isnt really a point to getting a bottle.  We got one of each dessert, the chocolate cake and the rhubarb tart.  Chocolate cake was a little bland, rhubarb tart was on point.  All in all would recommend to others.
author: Sonia S.

description:
I had passed by this place many times on my way to work. I was intrigued by the fact that it was Michelin recommend. So when my friend came into town from the Midwest, I thought I would give this place a shot and get us a reservation (thank you OpenTable!). 

When I got to the restaurant, I was greeted, but not with the warmest greeting, more of aloof I am a Michelin recommend you are lucky to be here. #annoying #strikeone

The waitress brought us our menu, and told us the specials. Nothing very exciting, nothing I haven't heard or seen before. 

Anywho, I ended up order the brussel sprouts as an appetizer, and the mushroom risotto as my main dish. My friend got their beef dish. 

The bruises sprouts came out in a quick time length. They were good, but at little too sweet, and could have been a bit crisper. 

On to the food. My risotto was way too cheesy, and bit a mushy, the mushrooms were not cooked fully, some were too soft, some too hard....a big epic fail. For ~$25, it was a major disappointment. 

My friend enjoyed her beef dish, but she wasn't writing home to her mom by any means. 

As for the cocktail/wine list. Nothing exciting. Our white wines that were suggested to us with our dishes were nothing to shout about. Another disappointment. 

Bottom line, don't waste your time or money coming here, you can do way better.  And when it comes to Michelin recommend, I am starting to wonder. The last two places I went to, didn't hold up to that level, so perhaps you should not either;)
author: Sonia A.

description:
I was looking for a solid brunch spot this past weekend for our party of four.  Aliment was every bit of awesome you could expect.  Rather than "bottomless" mimosas, they do "topless" mimosas.  Our server was on it too!  

To start, we ordered the french fries which came with a jalapeno aoli and smoked ketchup.  I loved the jalapeno aoli.  It's a tastier alternative to ranch.  The smoked ketchup was also pretty tasty and definitely unique.  The fries were light and flavorful free of grease.

I ordered the fried chicken with waffle balls.  Unfortunately, I ate too many fries and couldn't finish it, but I had no problem passing off the leftovers to others at our table.  The fried chicken was white meat, had a light flavor and was free of grease.  It came with  a light arugula salad and waffle balls topped with powdered sugar to dip in some molasses.  They tasted a lot like beignets- sooooo good.  

My bf ordered the braised short rib hash with potatoes, greens and slow cooked eggs.  I can't comment on it.  Because he ate the whole thing before I considered trying it.  Apparently, it was good!

The other two ordered the smoked fish benedict and continental breakfast.  Both of them enjoyed their food.  The continental breakfast was pretty large.  From what I remember observing, it came with some salami, granola with blueberries, fruit, and cheeses.  The presentation on a chop block was pretty cool.

As for the venue itself, it is very spacious with high ceilings, and the decor is very minimalist with white walls, brown tones and that carbonized wood textured look- very chic.  They had a makeshift fireplace on the wall going with a projector.  It was a nice touch to the atmosphere.  

I'd totally come back again for brunch if not lunch or dinner.  The service is excellent.  The people are friendly, and the food is unique, yummy, healthy and prepared with care.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Good stuff and delish food! I really like the concept of sharing plates! The decor is your typical sf coolness however so was also the service. A bit posh-ish but oh well. 

The carrot pure with the steak was super good!
author: Alexander P.

description:
Two friends and I decided to try Aliment, and we're so glad that we did! 

The restaurant serves their plates tapas style, so they have an array of small played and a handful of big ones. Between the three of us, we split three plates: the fried brussel sprouts, mussels, and gnocchi. The brussel sprouts and gnocchi are considered small while the mussels are big. The server recommended that each person order two small plates or one big one, but the three of us were actually quite full after splitting these three. I would advise you to order a few and keep going if you want. 

In less than ten minutes, we received our small plates. I don't think I've ever gotten y food that quickly, even at McDonald's or a fast food restaurant. The brussel sprouts were amazingly crisp on the outside, flavored well with the fish sauce. There was a healthy amount to split as well. 

The gnocchi had a great flavor as it had this zesty aioli on top and a lot of Parmesan cheese. But seriously, there were only a few gnocchi pieces and it was way too small for our liking. 

The mussels, as expected, had the most. There was a large portion of mussels cooked with chorizo in this spicy broth. It was mild, and went well with the two pieces of wheat bread on the side. 

We also split a rhubarb tart ($9) for dessert and it wasn't too sweet at all! They added a little bit of vanilla ice cream and mint garnishes on top. It was the perfect sweet note to end our meal on. 

Overall, our experience was great. The servers were kind and attentive, and the atmosphere was relaxed. It is on the pricier end, but if you come with a friend or two, you can split a good amount while enjoying diverse plates.
author: Jane H.

description: Happy hour appetizers reasonably priced and delicious.  Known for their Brussels sprouts and chickpea meatballs. Great service all around.
author: David J.

description:
Really all around disappointing and overpriced. 

My girlfriend insisted we go for dinner despite bad reviews from other customers - but we thought maybe it would fine to find a place that wasn't great but predictable close to our new apartment. 

We ordered two dirty martinis and, after being checked for ID (seriously, do I look like I have the eyes and soul of a twenty year old?) were served something that looked almost orange. We were told it was because of the olive juice added, but it did not resemble or taste like any martini I've ever had. 

The food was the most expensive laxative I've ever ordered. I chose to order ricotta gnocchi, which looked like something out of a Chef Boyardee can and made me sick for the entire following day. My girlfriend ordered scallops which looked like they had been lazily seared and thrown on top of some seriously over-seasoned and spicy goop. 

Sitting next to us, there was a couple that seemed to have a similar reaction to their dinner. He was eating something that resembled a steak and pushed it away a few minutes after it arrived at his table.

For two entrees and two drinks, we cashed out at over $80 without gratuity. So definitely not an easy and inexpensive neighborhood eatery. Unless maybe I'm trying to call off work sick the next day.
author: Alec P.

description: Amazing service from the start.  My fiancé and I each ordered a beer, we blinked and they were at our table.  The food was phenomenal and came out within minutes after ordering.  We are new to the neighborhood and they immediately made us feel like we were at home!
author: Michelle A.

description: This place is amazing!! It's cute atmosphere and I went here with one of my good friends and we just shared a bunch of the plates. We had the fried chicken, kale salad (not a fan), shrimp and grits, brussel sprouts, and mussels. For dessert, we had the chocolate bundt cake. Holy moly best brussel sprouts ever!! They were sweet and crunchy. The fried chicken was yummy and the shrimp and grits were not too shabby. The Mussels were delicious and spicy. The dessert was yummy. I really enjoyed it here and would definitely come again. We ordered so much food and we were so full. It ended up only being around $60 for all the food we had. Not bad at all!
author: Heather S.

description:
Aliment has been on my to-eat list ever since I walked past and saw a quaint little place on Bush with a promising menu posted outside. I mean, c'mon, the place is adorable! There's just the right number of tables and the price point is not bad as well.

Our group of four were originally planning on eating at Hopwater Distribution down the street, but as the Friday happy hour crowd got thicker and thicker we had no choice but to wander out for a quieter option. Introduction: Aliment. Our group snagged a reservation for an hour later and when we got back at 8:30 our table was ready!

We ordered:
-Foie gras meatballs: Delicious! Especially on top of spaetzle!
-Duck salad: This is a cold delicious but it packs amazing flavor!
-Mussels: Ok, we've all had mussels before. But these mussels have actual MUSCLE! They're super juicy...probably the juiciest mussels I've ever had. A must!
-Kale salad: We felt the need to balance all the heaviness out with some veggies and this hit the spot. Perfect balance of lightness and cheese!

Loved everything we got. Food came out super quick and service was awesome. Simple place, awesome food, I think it will become a staple =)
author: Christina L.

description:
Everything I ate was great - especially the brussels sprouts! I was with a group and so I tried a bit of several things. The duck was very tasty, though I really felt very strongly that the dish should have come with wonton chips or something to complement the flavors. (I did ask if that would be possible, and they were super accommodating and brought me some delicious bread...then surprise-charged $4 for it so hmmm...). The wine I tried (I think it was the Tempranillo) was wonderful, and if it's an indication of the rest of their wine list, then they have a solid thing going there.
 
I do think it was oddly priced. Nothing outrageous, but still worth mentioning. Like, duck small plate for $12ish (awesome!), but a small basket of bread for a third of that? (sideeye).
author: Sarah G.

description: Sometimes you can just smell a restaurant and know it's going to be good. They have some walking seating by the front windows, which was great for a busy conference. I wound up just having a cocktail (a spicy citrus bourbon drink which was great) and the wild boar. I asked if it was like a steak and one of the servers in training said it was like a sausage. Bias slices like a tenderloin would've sounded better, but I ordered it anyway. No bread, but the meal was plenty rich in itself. Super smoky bacon and a fairly tart cranberry relish on the side. There was some... Gastrique? ... On the plate that reminded me of apple butter. I'd definitely recommend this place to others.
author: Jason N.

description: Came here last minute with some business clients, and was very happy with this decision.  The menu selection is small, but everything we tasted was well made, fresh, and delicious. We were a table of 4.  For starters, we shared the brussel sprouts, the mussels, and the beet salad. For the mains, we had the salmon, the steak, and the pork chop.  The brussel sprouts were cooked to perfection, just enough crisp and a good balance of sweet and savory.  The mussels were also fantastic, they were super fresh, great texture, and full of flavor.  As for the meats, they were all very delicious, but I especially enjoyed the pork chops. They had a surprising pop of flavor that I did not anticipate.  We had two bottles of California wine, one was "educated guess" and the other was "conundrum." If you like full bodied, fruity wine, try Conundrum.  It was blissful. And lastly, the service was great.  We never felt interrupted, but was also never neglected, and all the staff were friendly and knowledgeable.
author: Kelly L.

description: A great neighborhood restaurant with a creative seasonal menu.  Sleek style, good acoustics and great service.  We loved the food and can't wait to return to try other items on the menu.
author: Kathleen S.

description: We ate there last night and every single dish was delicious! The brussels sprout appetizer and the gnocchi entrée were our favorites. We also loved the specialty cocktails. Friendly service, great atmosphere, phenomenal food. I would highly recommend this place!
author: Kristen L.

description:
This place is the winner of 2014 Diner's Choice Awards. I like how cute this restaurant is, the bar is really nice and they have a movie projected onto a white wall. Too bad I couldnt see the movie since we were seated right along that same wall. 

Must try the Fried Brussels Sprouts with fish sauce caramel, toasted nori, and sesame seeds. I've never had brussels sprouts that had so much flavor to it! This dish does get progressively salty as you get to the bottom. Probably because of the fish sauce caramel it's soaking in. I really enjoyed it. 

The Bolognese with ground steak, italian sausage, red wine tomato sauce, house-made pasta and herbs was delicious! House-made pasta was soft and had a great consistency. The meat sauce was tomatoe-y and beefy without being too heavy. 
I had the Butler's Steak with carrot puree, broccolini, king trumpets, fried lemon and fried potato croquettes. The portion was huge, a lot of steak! I was a bit disappointed when the waitress didn't allow any substitutions (swap out the potato croquettes for more broccolini) and they didn't have iced tea. The only non alcoholic beverages they had that night were sodas. The steak was cooked to a perfect medium rare, was a bit too salty but balanced out with the sweet carrot puree. I'm not sure what's up with the potato croquettes because mine were very cold in the center! Both of them tasted like it was refrigerated, then taken out and recooked but didn't get warmed up fully. It kind of ruined my dish. No bueno. 

Overall, the food was leaning towards more on the saltier side. The service was good, the wait staff were attentive to our table and kept our water cups refilled.
author: Janny S.

description: Came here for a light dinner before catching some live jazz. We ordered the beet salad, Brussel sprouts, and bolognese. Love the decor, and loved the food even more. We sat in the loft area, which was nice. Very friendly & attentive service.
author: Jonathan G.

description: While in san Francisco me and my fiance we walking to a different restaurant and we happen to see the quant little place with a good menu and fun atmosphere and im so glad we did. The food was excellent and so was the service. We will be back and it highly recommend. Great drinks as well!
author: Ethan W.

description:
This restaurant is located in Nob hill.

(Rating: +++ is perfect)
Atmosphere+++:

Service++:
 Courteous, but depend on a server

Value+:
A little bit expensive
_________________
Food

Local smoked fish benedict
++:
Although it was apparently so cute and the bread was so crispy and the eggs were so creamy, the smoked  salmon was more salty than I expected.


Burger and fries+:
The burger was average taste.
It was unfortunate that Fried was raging cold.
author: Hiromi S.

description: This is a restaurant that tries to be innovative but sorely misses the mark. The ambiance is cold and stark, the service is lackluster, and the menu lacks complexity, comfort, or standard fare. An order of red curry mussels was uneventful to be called Thai. The salmon cakes was replaced with an Australian white fish that had all the moisture cooked out, leaving a mouth feel of leather. The Kurobuta pork chop was only moderately better, was accompanied by ponzu sauce, chili's and miso butter. Just the ponzu sauce would have been sufficient. Dessert was a chocolate cake with whipped cream on top. A more dynamic version would have been a chocolate lava cake. This restaurant needs to redefine what they call themselves as "chef driven." I'd say it was more like the chef hit a telephone pole.
author: Richard B.

description:
This place is just okay.  If you go here: order wine and the gnocchi sans pork, it's great!  If you try to mix it up and go outside that small window though, the food and the selection is not very good.  Cocktails are so-so. Beer options are almost non-existent. Meat dishes rely too heavily on butter and salt. Even the scallop dish - while the addition of curry spices is interesting, it's not all coming together perfectly just yet.  Even the gnocchi, while delicious, relies too much on butter and cheese to make up the flavor profile.  
The staff are friendly but inconsistent in their understanding of the wines they serve. 
There is a woman who works here regularly, however, who is a real star.  I'm ashamed to say that I have forgotten her name.  If you're served by her, she makes it a very nice experience and she knows quite a bit about their wine offerings.
author: Amy K.

description: I had the ricotta gnocchi here and my husband had the Bolognese spaghetti. They were just ok. The oxtail starter was disappointing and did not taste too good. I love oxtail so I thought it was a waste of delicious meat. The Mac and cheese is actually pretty good here. Our server for the night was very nice and patient with us but one of the others girls working there seemed very scatter brained and kept bringing me another table's food and drinks. I left feeling regretful like I should have chosen a different restaurant for dinner for my few days in SF.
author: Lisa H.

description:
Sigh, I really wanted to like this place...

My husband and I tried this restaurant for the first time last night. We thought why not? The decor is lovely, there are beautiful hardwood floors, a modern statement lighting fixture when you walk in and fresh flowers at each table. We live across the street and pass by everyday so after taking a look at the menu we decided to make a reservation.
 
I had high hopes but unfortunately the food was lackluster and failed to excite me, here's what we ordered:

Ricotta Gnocchi was the worst! I've had great potato gnocchi before but correct me if I'm wrong, is the texture of gnocchi supposed to be wet and mushy? It had no "body"or flavor so it seemed like maybe they were boiled for too long...I really don't know but we barely touched the plate. Sadly, we also wasted $4 to add pork belly to the dish. 

Beet and Arugula Salad w/Quinoa was excellent. The saving grace of the night. But really? The salad was the best dish? Laughable.

The Bolognese was nothing to write home about but at least it was edible and they didn't skimp out on the meat...there was A LOT of meat sauce but it was surprisingly bland. You'd think that when you pay $18 for a single serving of pasta it'd blow your socks off or something! I can make better pasta at home so why bother coming back? 

The service and staff were good so that's why I choose to rate 2 stars. 1 star for the salad and another for the nice waiter and guy who seated us at our table. Maybe the chef/kitchen staff were having a bad day...but I have no sympathy because if people are paying $18-22 for a plate of pasta, you better make it worth it! 

Bottom line, if you know how to cook with fresh homemade ingredients or know what good food is supposed to taste like you will be sorely disappointed here.
author: Sueann W.

description:
Aliment's Ailment:

Seriously, guys? Yep, you're cute, but that's not enough. You're in San Francisco, after all; you've got to try a little harder...

The food is above average, but when the bartenders are more in love with themselves than with the dishes, and their jobs, it ruins everything...So much potential. The 'hood wants this place to work, and the chef deserves support, but the service thwarts all, drops the ball...That is Aliment's ailment.

(Spaghetti Bolognese hits the spot; brussel sprouts--good, but so trendy that it's boring already...I must note that there is an amiable, attentive waitress who is an exception to the problemmatic service I encountered.)
author: Robin's Hood X.

description: Mediocre food and terrible service. We definitely expected better based on other reviews. Gnocchi had very little taste. They messed up our order, took forever to actually serve us, and left us waiting for 15 minutes for the bill in an otherwise nearly empty restaurant.
author: Caitlyn B.

description:
I really wanted this place to be better than it was, but sadly the food has yet to impress me. I first visited Aliment a couple of months after it opened back in 2013 and then again a few months ago. When I originally visited, I simply chalked things up to the place being new, but fast forward two years and I still felt that the food, especially considering the price, was underwhelming.

That said, the decor is indeed modern and very appealing. I especially like the view from the upstairs dining area. The service was also great: the staff was extremely friendly and attentive. But, that only makes it all the more disappointing that the food doesn't live up to the rest of the package.
author: Rodney G.

description:
What a great meal!

We happened upon this place after asking a bartender at a local watering hole where to find good apps/small plates close by. 

We ordered off the reasonably priced happy hour menu, and shared the mini grilled cheese and the bacon and eggs. We also shared a squash salad.

Service was attentive and quick. The mini grilled cheese was actually much larger than we expected. It came with a fantastic cup of tomato soup for dipping! The bacon, though, was really the highlight of the meal. House-made, perfectly salty, and thick. Yum!

We finished with the rose ice cream for dessert; absolutely unexpected and delightful. 

If we had more time in SF, I'd absolutely be back! I can't recommend it enough!
author: Jourden V.

description: Great place ! Very interesting menu. The brussel  sprouts are to die for. Also the vibe of the restaurant is great. Highly recommend
author: Becca S.

description:
Went to Aliment last night with a couple of friends after hearing about their good happy hour specials. We sat down only to discover that the specials are only available at the bar, we decided to move but the manager was really accommodating and said they would serve us from a table. We literally had 1 of everything on the happy hour menu and we were not disappointed. While all of the dishes were great our group was a huge fan of the mussels, Brussels sprouts, and the deviled eggs!

There weren't many other patrons when we arrived at 5:45 but I could see it being a tight fit if it was a little more crowded. Otherwise the service was generally good and the drinks were strong!
author: Christy H.

description: Great surprise spot. Brussel sprouts and Korean fried chicken we're great. The bartender made me a gin version if a sazarec with a touch of brown sugar. Great service, friendly staff, and great food.
author: Chandu C.

description:
Get it now before it's gone: Ramen Fried Chicken Bits! Way tastier than I expected. The chicken meat felt like biting into an edible pillow. The exterior was crunchy due to the short pieces of ramen. The contrast of these two textures made me wish I had a bottomless stomach. Never wanted to stop eating this dish! But now that I hyped it up, maybe your expectations will be too high. Do yourself a favor and pretend you never read my review.

The Riblets (Korean BBQ and kimchi) was decent. The meat was aight and the kimchi was aight, aight? 

The Kale salad was topped off with toasted pepitas, parmesan, and avocado vin. More than anything, this dish was cheesy. It's a salad made for people who want to like healthy food but can't stand it. So marry that nutritious kale with handfuls of cheese! But me personally, less cheese please. 

The Lamb Sirloin with tatziki, harrissa and zatar spice was my second favorite dish after the Ramen Fried Chicken Bits. 

Interior was not too loud, thus a good spot for carrying out conversations. The design was pretty simple. Nothing fancy. Once you have a bite of that Ramen Chicken, you won't notice anything else anyways!
author: Mina O.

description:
I go there early and let the lady know I'm with so and so party and she said "ok do you want to be seated?" And I said no I'll wait at the bar. And when they all arrive?  She says there is no reservation?  Hello?  It's confirmed in yelp app and we show her. She has an attitude.  Downhill from there. 

Server was very nice but food was just ok. The Brussels sprouts was too fishy and sweet, salads were ok (beet and butter lettuce) and hangar steak small serving and flavorless.  Gnocchi meh. The mussels and fried chicken were good.  Just so-so experience.  We all eat out a lot in the city and elsewhere so service and food will be scrutinized.
author: Ina K.

description: Great little restaurant on Bush and Mason. Just what i expect and appreciate about the city of San Francisco.  Classy, hip, attentive service.  The Korean Fried Chicken with those super lemony micro greens were simply additive. An effortless evening out.
author: Karen B.

description:
I went here tonight for dinner. The restaurant itself was really cute, and the service was really good. I enjoyed the flavor of the food, but I must say that everything I tried was overly salty (and I generally enjoy a little extra salt on my food too). 

Brussel Sprouts (4.5/5) - Being Vietnamese, I LOVE fish sauce, so this was great for me. I am used to the saltiness of fish sauce, but it was definitely overwhelming in this dish. Aside from the saltiness, the flavor was very good though.

Pork Chop (3.5/5) - The pork chops were nice and juicy, which generally is hard to achieve for pork chops. I wasn't the biggest fan of the eggplant and salad on the side though. The eggplant was too soggy for my taste, and the dressing on the salad was pretty acidic. Although the pork chops were cooked very well, once again it was a little too salty for me. 

I also tried some of my friends Foie Gras Meatball from her Carbonara dish. I didn't try any of the noodles, but the meatball was very good. It makes me wish that I had ordered that dish instead.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
Amazing food and nicely priced. Beautiful, modern rustic setting for a casual meal. 

Only strike against this restaurant is the noise. We sat down and were next to a loud party. When they left it was great, only to return to a deafening roar when the next large party was seated.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Great food, nice decor, interesting menu and very reasonably priced. 

- Brussel sprout: everyone isn't lying, these are delicious. 
- foie gras meatballs: good flavor, not as foie gras-y as I'd like
- Pastrami Short Rib: interesting, but did skew slightly dry. Worth a try though! 

Menu changes frequently, will definitely go back. 

Corkage $25.
author: Diana W.

description:
Came to Aliment back for a quick dinner and really dug the atmosphere. I ordered the lamb meatballs, brussel sprouts and chocolate cake - the second of which was just superb. My friend got the bolognese which I found slightly undersalted and a tad too acidic.

I like Aliment but it lacks a certain je ne sais quoi that makes it stand out from the fine dining frenzy that is San Francisco. Good meal, but there are comparable restaurants nearby that can probably do it better.
author: Kristy N.

description:
What can I say about Aliment?  If you a want a great meal with some of the freshest ingredients around in a chic and yet friendly setting, go to Aliment!  This a true gem of a neighborhood restaurant, the neighborhood being Nob Hill in my opinion, but you can get a different answer depending on who you ask.

I was the first one that arrived from our party.  It was me and three others from SF Foodies (Meetup Group).  We had a 7pm dinner starting with the wonderful Fried Brussel Sprouts which this restaurant is known for (we ended up getting THREE orders throughout the meal!)  The menu on these reads "fish sauce caramel and toasted nori, sesame seeds"  WOW!  I also started with a glass of the Sancerre, as well as some Streak Fries, which were wonderful!  We ordered a cheese plate for an appetizer too, which was nice but very little bread was brought out.  No bother, I asked for more bread and it was brought very quickly, and I believe a third bunch brought out without anyone asking.  I've had better cheese plates (i.e. Bistro Boudin) but it certainly wasn't bad.

For the meal we had exactly six choices to choose from.  I wished there were more choices, but there were a few I could have had, so it's not like I couldn't find something.  I ordered the Pork Chop ("spaetzle, mustard greens and apple ginger glaze") and it was A) HUGE and B) AMAZING!  Two others at my table ordered the same and the fourth had the Monkfish.  The dinner was extremely delicious and the restaurant in general was wonderful!  Our dessert choices were extremely limited (I think four options?) but I choice the ice cream which was pretty good.

I'll be back as it's pretty close to my apartment and I am looking forward to it!
author: Jordan M.

description:
If you're looking for a moderately priced, seasonal, hip meal in the Nob Hill/Union Square area, Aliment's the place.

Good beer, great food, friendly service, nice decor. Trendy, modern. The kitchen's open to the dining room and bar, so you can see other diner's delicious foods being prepped as you browse the menu. I ordered up a grilled Kurobuta pork chop with sauteed long beans, rice cakes and bacon. It was delicious. Like "touch my food and die" delicious - grilled perfectly to order and seasoned well.

The draft beers are limited to a four-tap rotation. If those aren't your thing, there's another couple dozen craft selections in standard and large-format bottles plus wine and cocktails.

Full service is available at the marble bar-top. It wasn't crazy busy when I stopped in, but I could see if getting loud when packed, 'cause it's all wood, high ceilings, and hard surfaces.

My server/bartender was friendly, on the spot when needed, and knew the menu and drinks by heart. A solid meal with two beers came in at around $36 plus tax and tip. Pretty darned reasonable for downtown SFO. Aliment's definitely on the list for repeat visits whenever I'm in town.
author: Rob N.

description: Aliment is bound to cure any ailment.  It's a small place even with seating upstairs, but it's a great backup when you don't want to wait for Sons & Daughters or pay the hefty price. Try their pastas and you should be satisfied.  Save room for their ice creams especially the butter pecan =P
author: Jenny L.

description:
A friend suggested this place for dinner, because it was a good location between the two of us, and the menu had a good eclectic mix of things everyone loves.

We started with a few pastrami sliders for the table, the pastrami was grilled and crispy on the edges and on a really tasty pretzel bun. Can't go wrong there. He got the seared Scallops over some kind of grain. I couldn't personally tell you how they were because he wouldn't share them - but I would venture to say they were pretty good. I got the Bolognese because if that's on a menu I'm usually gonna get it, but that said for a self-proclaimed Bolognese connoisseur it was pretty damn good for a non-italian joint. There was some interesting herb combination in there I couldn't put my finger on, but I was pretty into it.

The portions on both of our meals were pretty small for the price point, but what was on the plate was really solid.
author: Jenna G.

description: We just happened to come across this place looking for brunch without a crowd. After eating I found myself shocked there wasn't a crowd. The service was pleasant and the food was stellar. Great decor too. Will go again on my next visit!
author: Tammy D.

description:
Aliment is a hipster-ish spot, with lots of delicious bar bites, small plates, a few great entrees, and a huge selection of wines, bubbles, beer, and now a cocktail menu too!

It was one of my go-to dinner spots (especially when I have friends visiting from out of town), mostly because I used to live down the street and it was super convenient to get a reservation, but also because we've never been disappointed by the food. The staff is always very friendly, and you usually don't have to wait more than an hour for a table without a reservation. The entrees are around $20-40 each, but everything else is pretty much under $20. It's best to go family style and get a wide variety of the smaller plates to share here.

They've revamped the menu a bit, but my go-to dish is definitely the ricotta gnocchi (option to add pork belly). The mussels are also a great deal, around $15 and enough for 3-4 to share. And of course, you've got to get the Brussels sprouts! If you've ever had sprouts from Box, these are similar but a bit less oily. I wish they did take out so I could eat those sprouts every day!
author: Liz J.

description:
Brussel sprouts: so good we ordered a second round instead of dessert... Why mess with a good thing?!

Spatzel: loooove spatz, and it definitely did not disappoint! TBH it gave the one I had in Germany a run for its money.

Riblets: Good, but probably wouldn't order again.

Really wanted to try the scallops but couldn't afford them, so will have to come back with my parents so they can foot the bill. I also enjoyed the setup and interior of the restaurant - I like how it was sectioned off into 3 tiers, and table decorations were a nice touch!
author: Stephanie B.

description: I was only in San Francisco for one night on a business trip. Knowing that San Fran is famous for it's restaurants I was excited to eat here. However I took one bite of the Salmon Cakes which were so salty and disgusting I couldn't eat it. Because I was with clients I didn't feel comfortable complaining in front of them and went hungry that night. I hope in the least the chef reevaluates the recipe and thinks about the people who eat there.
author: Sara F.

description:
Went to Aliment for a weekend dinner, and was excited for the experience based on the menu. 

Came away quite disappointed. The execution in the restaurant was simply lacking. The place is decorated to match the charm of a welcoming Subway. Our drinks tasted like wine spritzers mixed with straight liquor, which probably shouldn't have been a surprise seeing as the bartender was literally wearing a shirt that read "More vodka? Why not!"

A little frustrated with this place, because some of the food was actually good. The steak burger was tasty and the brussel sprouts had an interesting flavor that showed forethought. Fish caramel sprouts do not sound appetizing off the bat, but they were excellent. A lot of the other dishes also looked good, however the gnocchi that we ordered tasted like it may have been missing a few ingredients.

If anyone in the restaurant is reading this, a few suggestions:
-Have the staff wear matching simple black t-shirts. Quick, easy fix. Some servers were dressed in a business casual way that made them tough to identify, and the bartender's shirt speaks for itself ha
-Hire an interior designer to give the place some simple color/pattern concepts. As mentioned above, fake-looking veneer wood and basic table/chairs make the place look cheaper than it should
-Decide which vibe you're shooting for. If that's happy hour, great, go for it. If that's more of a dinner restaurant, the projected TV on the wall showing ESPN2 is far more of a detractor than a benefit. You can even keep the TVs and just shut them down at a certain time, or switch to a more compelling/ambience-building channel than a B-level college basketball game that no one is watching.
-If you're offering cocktails, make sure they're well made. If not, stick to beer, wine, and well. 


This place certainly has potential and I think they could make a few quick changes to improve the experience substantially, but for now I would recommend friends to skip it. Too many great restaurants to send someone to a shaky dining experience.
author: Silas A.

description: After work, I didn't want to go home yet and needed a place to hang out and this was the perfect spot. Their happy hour from 5 to 7 pm was had good options for appetizers including the sauteed Brussel sprouts made with a fish sauce that was incredible for $5 and the mussels in a red curry broth with chorizo for $10. Enjoyed my time there and the staff was very friendly.
author: N A.

description:
We came here for dinner for a party of 6. Over all the food was good and it was not too loud that you can hear everyone at the table talk. You can park at the Stockton garage if you're driving in and it's a close walk to the restaurant up the stairs from the tunnel. 

Appetizers/Main Dishes
I ordered the pork chop dish it was a large meat portion. I read some of the previous reviews about the saltiness of the food. The pork chop was cooked well, the potatoes were REALLY salty. It felt like someone just dumped salt on the plate. If you order this dish definitely ask if you they can cut down on the salt. Other dishes that I tried were the famous brussels sprouts  as an appetizer which was pretty good and the steak dish. Overall the steak was a bit better than the pork chop.

Dessert
We got the chocolate cake which was great and in house mint ice cream.

Overall
Service was ok. It takes some time for the food to come out. Noise level, ok for 2-6 groups (reservations recommended)

Would I come back?
Yes, I would come back since it's in a good location to meet up for SF folks. I would ask if the chef can go easy on the SALT.
author: V N.

description:
I thought that brussel sprouts were over played until I had them here. They are so darn good I can probably just have an entire plate to myself. 

Five of us gals came here for an impromptu celebration of our upcoming bdays. The service was super friendly and welcoming. The menu consists of some really amazing dishes. I had the chicken which was served on top of creamed corn polenta. It was absolutely delicious!

I love places that are non-pretentious and focus on good service and good food.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Dinner for 2 at the bar.  Its a smaller spot like most of San Fran restaurants.   Menu is mostly for carnivores however my veg girlfriend was able to find a couple dishes she enjoyed (Kale Salad and Brussels sprouts).  I order off the bar snacks portion and small bites.  Overall the prices are great for the portion, considering that they also pretty fantastic.  Definitely at the top tier, go with the pastrami slider (its at least twice the size of a normal slider) and the ramen fried chicken bites.   

The hostess was quick, and our bartender was really nice and helped with options and drink selections.  Very good service.
author: Tanner C.

description: The brussels sprouts are so good they're like crack. They have a great happy hour menu with service that is fast and friendly. Wrap it up with a delicious chocolate cake and salted caramel
author: Nancy H.

description:
Ate there again, this time a very large (14 person) party.  
 
Ever eat somewhere with a large group and the *flow* of food breaks down?  
Like you order 5 appetizers, and 2 come out, and people wonder where there other 3 went, only to have them arrive with main courses.  
 
This does not happen at Aliment.  At all.  Even the mains all came out within a minute each other.  That's impressive in a large party.  
 
Well done.
author: Adam P.

description:
Definitely delicious. 
Highly recommend the Brussels sprouts, gnocchi with pork belly (if you really like pork), crispy chicken.
The restaurant had a nice vibe, staff was nice and friendly.
author: The Eastons _.

description:
Came here for dinner. It's not bad, but most of the main dishes were fairly forgettable. The one dish that stood out were the brussel sprouts, these are probably the best brussel sprouts I've ever had in my life. I never knew fish sauce caramel could elevate a boring vegetable dish to decadence. I would return for the sole purpose of getting this dish again.

I ordered the braised short ribs which were cooked well and very tender but there wasn't anything that made it memorable. Some sort of special sauce or reduction might have helped in that area but it just sort of falls flat as a well-prepared but boring dish that's frankly a bit pricey.

We finished with the yuzu cheesecake as our dessert. I'm not particularly a fan of dessert but I thought this one was not bad. The cheesecake is very soft and the tart yuzu jam on top helps to cut the sweetness. My friends were all raving about this dessert! The restaurant is beautiful, very clean and modern with a hipster vibe to it. The ambience is nice enough that you can take a date here. Overall, pretty solid dinner spot.
author: Kevin N.

description:
My Fourth time at this place - loved it! Nice interior and overall atmosphere, they have second floor and also middle floor( sort of private room for bigger companies)  Food is soo delicious - Brussels sprouts of course, salads( my fav is beats salad) and I had this smoked chicken pasta with ricotta - so good! 
Def coming back and service was amazing - Jared is the best  ( no idea how this place got lower rates - it's a very nice restaurant for sure )
author: Yulya M.

description:
I've walked past this place a ton of time and always been curious to try it. I came here with a friend for dinner a few weeks ago. The menu isn't super extensive but there were a few solid options to chose from. I got the burger and it was okay, nothing to write home about. The brussel sprouts was the best dish of the night. Our server was also very off, he had zero personality and when we asked him what his favorite dishes were he flatly replied with 'everything is good'. I get that you want to say all times are good but we asked you a question, do us a solid and tell us what you absolutely love on your menu. 

Aesthetically the restaurant is pretty cool, I like the over all lay out of it. We sat upstairs and from where I was sitting I could look over the restaurant below and the street which was cool but I probably won't be rushing back.
author: Lizzy U.

description:
Came here for a pre-Super Bowl brunch.  Space is airy and sunny.  Our server was super friendly and helpful.  We had the pleasure of sampling the braised short rib hash, fried chicken & waffle balls and the fried brussel sprouts.  Every single item was extremely tasty.

Being a fan of New American cuisine, I really like Aliment and plan to be back to try dinner some time soon.
author: Justin L.

description:
On my way to a friend's house we drove by and I said oh what is that place never seen it before....I had no clue we would end up eating here. I'm so glad we did because the food is amazing!
