I kinda don't want to draw attention to this place because I don't want to wait in a long crazy line to get in, Selfish me. We ordered a bunch of stuff to share...
1. Brussel Sprouts= BEST thing I put in my mouth, I want the recipe!! 
2. Ramen crusted chicken= Sorry, not my favorite
3. Bolognese= The meat was so flavorful and the pasta tasted home made, yumo!
4. Pork Belly Gnocchi= The night before I had "award winning" gnocchi in North Beach so I was expecting nothing fantastic here...HOLY CRAP was I wrong! It was light and fluffy with so much flavor, huge chunks of Pork Belly, AMAZING. It was seriously comparable to the award winners. 
5. Cheese Spaetzle= It was good, but I think other stuff was so flavorful, this dish was left in the dust.
6. Kale Salad= Same thing, it was ok. But others at the table loved it.
7. Scallops with Mufungo= So happy we got this at the end, This was the 2nd best thing I put in my mouth. The scallops were juicy and fresh, BEST Mufungo I've ever had! 
We even ended in a high note:
Home Made Chocolate Ice Cream and Apple Crisp, which was more like a mini apple pie= HEAVEN in your Mouth! I LOVE Ice Cream and Pie and they were ridiculous! 
I left wanting to unbutton my pants.
author: Karen T.

description:
I would give this place a 0 star if I could. It was so upsetting and disappointing because there were so many things wrong about this place. First of all, we ordered the burger medium. It came raw. When we told the waiter and he was unapologetic. We then told another waitress and her response "Well I didn't make it!" Wow....really? Of course you didn't...unless you are the chef and waitress! 

We wanted to give this place a chance so instead ordered another meal, the scallops. We received them and they were so salty. And apparently the table behind us ordered the same thing and sent them back twice. First because they were salty. Then a second time because they were rubbery. Wish we would've known!

Feeling really disappointed, we just decided to get the check. Low and behold...the burger was on the bill!!! We asked our waiter and he said they couldn't take it off. We asked to speak to a manager and first the waiter said the owner already left. We asked if a manager was here and he said the manager was at the bar and if we wanted to speak to them, we had to go to the bar. But then literally 30 seconds afterward after we asked to clarify that we had to go to the bar...the waiter then said..."Actually the manager left already." Wait...just a second ago you said he was at the bar. So obviously he was lying.

We decided to go to the bar to see if there was a manager. The bar manager Jerry was there. We explained the situation to him. Although he was nice and accommodating (he took off our wine corkage at least), he made it a point to tell us that the burger comes that way if we order it medium rare. That is fine if we order it medium rare, but we didn't.  Meanwhile our waiter was literally standing right behind us breathing down our back to see if we tipped him! Wow...the audacity! The service was horrible!!! 

We were polite about the whole situation and the staff couldn't have cared less and if we are paying for an evening out, we expect to get decent service and workers that care about the quality of their food and service. 

SF has so many options...I wouldn't waste my time or hard earned money here.
author: Cooper T.

description:
I was really disappointed with this place. I had passed it many times and it looked like a neat place to eat, the menu looked good, etc.
We ordered two appetizers, the potato leek soup and the brussel sprouts. 
Now the sprouts were very tasty, albeit a bit oily. Definitely, if you are eating here, get those. The soup was very disappointing. It was just very... bland. We only ate a few bites before giving up on it. It needed more salt for sure. (We actually sent it back and the chef agreed, but at this point we just didn't want more of it)
We also got the gnocchi. The consistency of the gnocchi was not good. It was too soft and just kind of came apart in your mouth. The sauce was also a bit bland. There were nice bits with the garlic and smoked onions, but the nice flavors didn't go throughout the sauce. You had to really get lucky to get a good bite. I only ate about half of mine.
For the price, this place is just not worth it. We paid (10 (soup) + 10 (sprouts) + 17 (gnocchi) + 21 (gnocchi with meat addition) + 5 (tax) + 12 (tip) = 75. For $75 in San Francisco, you can get MUCH tastier and higher quality food.
author: Lizzy B.

description:
Overall, I was very disappointed.

Cons:
1-Unacomidating to the point of rudness. Wanted to order the fish and asked for the sauce to the side and the waitress said that couldn't be done. Which was no big deal since we thought maybe its pre-made or something. Then we tried to order the kale salad with the dressing on the side. Again, the waitress refused. Her justification? "Our salad tastes terrible without the dressing." Then she went on to badger us about "who eats kale without dressing?!" When we brought this to the attention of the manager that salad with dressing to the side isn't a big request he doubled down on their "policy" of not serving the dressing to the side for the kale salad because it is "inedible" otherwise. This lack of accomodation is more common in Europe and I would be more accepting of it there.

2- Overall staff wasn't very friendly

3- The street its on wasn't very nice (not exactly "family friendly" ....but hey thats SanFran)

Pros:
1-Decor was nice
2-Menu seemed somewhat unique with good presentation.
author: Hamad H.

description:
Nice place and staff! Nob Hill / Union Sq can add another fine 'new american' dining option to it's list here (although I'd rank e.g. 1760 higher in my mind, just for a recent comparison).
- Tasty (but very strong flavored and heavy) fried brussel sprouts with fish oil and more. Kinda reminds me of some I've had at Luna Park. This is a big serving, and with all it's fried goodness could go a long way in filling you up.
- Very yummy mushroom salad; really loved the cheese on top as well. Even my truffle-disliking gf enjoyed it despite the truffle oil vinaigrette!
- Huge asian-flavored pork chop - tender and flavorful. Fried rice cake ovals were crispy on the edges, probably fried in the very bacon fat from the bacon bits also mixed in with the chinese string beans and rice cakes.
- Also a very tasty bolognese with a thinner flat pasta made in-house. The sausage has a bit of a spiciness to it.
author: Linus W.

description: This place was very underwhelming. The brussels sprouts were great, but everything else was meh, including their famous fois gras meatballs which were a big disappointment. Pastas were very average. Overall, overpriced and overhyped.
author: Shabnam E.

description: Mixed feelings about this restaurant. Service was good and the ambience was nice. I ordered the ricotto gnocchi and it was so salty I could not eat it. I maybe had 3 bites of gnocchi and then wasted the rest. My friend ordered the steak and loved it. The dessert menu is pretty limited- we ordered the chocolate cake with bourbon caramel and it was fine. Nothing to write home about. Honestly, with all the great places in the city, I wouldn't come back.
author: Vinitha R.

description:
If you advertise bottomless mimosas, I will be there. In my opinion, brunch just isn't the same without never ending glasses of champagne and OJ. In Aliment's case, they are referred to as topless mimosas, which makes the idea even more alluring. 

A group of four of us tried out Aliment for brunch on a Saturday and had a great time. It wasn't too loud, which brunch can sometimes be, so it was nice to be able to hear what my friends were saying. Or course, we ordered mimosas and the server did a pretty good job at keeping them refilled. Sometimes our glasses got completely empty (gasp!) but he wasn't too far behind on the refill. They don't bring pitchers and refill at your table, they actually take your glasses to the bar and refill them, which was a different mimosa experience for me, but still a fun one. 

I ordered the smoked fish benedict and really enjoyed it. Perfectly portioned and super fresh tasting. I ate every bit on the plate. My husband ordered the fried chicken and waffle balls and LOVED the chicken; and that man knows his fried chicken. He wasn't crazy about the waffle balls though. 

Our out of town friends ordered the french toast and burger. Our burger friend said it was one of the best burgers he has ever had, which I think is a huge statement! He was really excited about Aliment and can't wait to move to the Bay Ayrea. Aliment, you left quite an impression! I can't wait to return and try their dinner!
author: Liz M.

description:
We had a great brunch at Ailment a few weeks back.  We got there when it opened and didn't have a reservation but were able to get a seat right away.  My wife had the biscuits and gravy and I had the short rib hash.  Both were awesome and super tasty.  I'd recommend either of those although the burger looked really good as well.

If you're coming with a kid, please note that they don't have any highchairs.
author: Blake B.

description:
I wanted to like this place and I just couldn't.

To start, my friend asked for the differences in the white wine.  The server didn't know.   I realize not liking them, but I would hope they can describe them. 

I'm gluten and dairy free, and was disappointed there was zero substitutions.  The only item that was fit for me was an appetizer, so I ordered the scallops.  They were good. Not great, but good.

I also requested a side of a green veggie.   In my head, this should be easy, but this request couldn't be accommodated.I offered to pay for this, clearly. Didn't care what it was if it was green.  Very disappointed. 

Finally, there was a movie projecting on the big wall. It was distracting to see a picture flickering while trying to visit with a friend. 

Not worth the visit until they can be a little more flexible (i.e. serve me some peas!)
author: Amy H.

description: Tiny, but busy place right near Burrit Room. We hit this up with some friends after drinks. Definitely book ahead as it gets really busy, and be aware it is breezy by the door if you're sitting near it (they have to leave it open to air it out for the people eating on the 2nd floor, we were told). The foie gras meatballs were exotic sounding, but tasted like traditional meatballs, I couldn't really tell the difference. Mac and cheese was a standout too. I liked the pasta a lot...the meat sauce was really good. The waitstaff also is really attentive and tries to get you out as quickly as possible without rushing you, which is good too. Overall, solid place to fill up your gut for a night of more liquids.
author: Dan M.

description:
I don't review often, but I had to jump on to talk about this place. I stumbled upon is just walking down the street.

Came in here for a date with my lady (at the time). I ended up meeting and chatting to one of the owners, Eric. Instead of ordering from the menu he just took care of us. I realize that may not be everyone's choice, you can still order the dishes you want from their menu.

I've been back a few times and everything I've had has been delicious. The staff was nothing but helpful and friendly.

Their brussel sprouts are to die for!

My favorites have been

- brussel sprouts
- bolognese
- spatzle mac n cheese
- riblets
- gnocchi 

But I haven't had anything I didn't like. I highly recommend checking this place out.
author: Ryan P.

description:
We had a huge group there and called at pretty short notice (a day or two prior). What I appreciated was that they were willing to accommodate us! The service was excellent! 

We ordered the Brussel sprouts and they are to die for. The mussels were in the most amazing sauce and I loved my main of scallops with curried sauce. My mouth waters every time I think of them . Pity I can't do anything about it now as I'm from Malaysia and was only in SF for a week.

Definitely a memorable experience that is one for the books. Thank you Aliment!

PS. Their Black Widow (I think) cocktail is not to be trifled with. That drink is STRONG.
author: Grace T.

description:
Went to this place when it first opened, posted a few pics and I could tell they were still working on the menu. I was really disappointed and hoped that with time they could get it together.

Now after a few months, I decided to go back and I was presently surprised by the improvement. Their burger is fantastic, a true culinary experience and the mushroom gnocchi that my gf had was to die for. 

I'll be back! welcome to the neighborhood :)
author: Krista K.

description:
This review is for Happy Hour. I love Happy Hour at Aliment.  The food is wonderful and reasonably priced.  They have fun cocktails and high end beers at low prices.

I really enjoyed the wings and the brussell sprouts.
author: Alyssa S.

description: Called that evening for a reservation for 7 and they cheerily obliged. Service was friendly.  Had I realized they didn't have a full bar I wouldn't have wanted to go- but they have a sizable wine list and an interesting menu.  We had the beet salad and the kale salad.  Also tried their Brussels sprouts.  3 adults got their steak and 2 of us got their gnocchi.  The two kids had Mac and cheese.   Everything was rich and delicious.  I wasn't impressed with their chocolate cake and they only had 2 dessert options.  Felt like that course was an after thought- so lost a star there.
author: Madhuri K.

description:
I have such mixed feelings about this place. The first time I came here was right around when they just opened. I had the scallops, kale salad, Brussel sprouts, gnocchi, and the braised short rib. Everything was outstanding! A few weeks later I came back with someone I was dating as I was raving about it, only to be left really disappointed.

We got the oysters, pork shoulder, scallops and Brussels sprouts. The oysters were good, pork shoulder lacked flavor, and Brussel sprouts were extremely over salted!! My dude loves salt and even he thought it was way too salty. It had so much of a teriyaki like glaze on it too. We couldn't eat it! He was bummed off the pork shoulder and the sprouts that he didn't want anything else. I convinced him to get the scallops since they were delicious the first time I was there and he loves scallops. Another disappointment. It was extremely over salted as well! 

I don't know if there was a different Chef working when I was in that time but it was a total opposite experience. Really bummed because this place is literally a block away from me and I wanted to love it. 

Maybe if I work up the courage I'll try it again and update from here..... Hopefully the heavy salted chef isn't there.
author: Natassia S.

description:
Meaty entrées are where it's at, and they change seasonally. Ex: I savored a juicy hangar steak with chimichurri; crispy, caramelized forbidden rice; and charred escarole. 

This time, we tried two meatball appetizers, one izakaya style and a special. Flavors of the accompanying sauces (one was a cherry glaze?) were too strong and odd. Hubs adores the brussel sprouts, despite his intense dislike for fish sauce. My massive pork chop with an arugula salad, though, was thick, juicy, and perfectly cooked! Our knowledgeable server diligently found hoppy beer for the hubs, and looked in to see how each course was received. Dessert was beautifully plated, but the crust on the apple pie was not buttery and flaky enough. 

An upstairs loft for reservations, and the bar, booth, and window seats are on the first floor. Late in the evening, they project films against the wall. A classic 007 film starring Sean Connery was just starting as we left. 

With a shorter wait, seasonal surprises, attentive service and substantial portions, we prefer coming here rather than making our way to and through Foreign Cinema.
author: Christina L.

description: I liked the steak and fried brussel sprouts. Servers are nice. Happy hour menu is nice but you can sit only at the bar during happy hour.
author: Dohyeon Y.

description:
On a four day trip to San Francisco where my gf and I sampled a bunch of different restaurants this one was by far the worst. The restaurant wasn't exactly full at dinner time and yet the wait time for our dishes to come out (a steak dish ordered medium rare and a gnocchi dish) was about 45 minutes.  The restaurant was absurdly warm and yet the waitress came by only once to fill our water while we waited...with lukewarm water and she disappeared before we could notice and then ask for ice.  When the dishes came out, the steak was not just overcooked but nuked. The char on the outside was so severe it tasted carcinogenic and the inside was so "well" that it was just a far cry from the medium rare temperature it was ordered at. The gnocchi, my girlfriend told me was overcooked to the point that it was gummy. 
To top it all off, when there was a minor issue regarding my open table reservation being accidentally cancelled, I called to say something like the food wasn't good so at least help me get the 100 opentable points back. The manager called me a f**king loser for calling about such a thing and hung up. 

In short, stay away as there are far better places to eat in the area and you'll be treated better to boot.
author: Amir B.

description: Modern vibe at this place that seemed to be recently redone.  In a very urban setting.    Mac n cheese was good, kale chips were worth getting.  I'd go back
author: Charles C.

description: The restaurant is modernly decorated, not too big, around 10 tables and a bar. Food and drinks were very uneven - either really good ones like kale and shrimp and grits and the 5 Russians Pino. Or really bad, like the Country line Chardonnay and the steak($38) which was fatty and too chewy, so we had to cut almost a third of it off. Service was good, but nothing special. Probably won't return.
author: Masha P.

description: Ok restaurant for non special nights.
author: Nikki U.

description: Came to Aliment during a visit to SF.  It is located in Nob Hill, which means that there are a bunch of steep hills that you have to climb in order to get around.  But despite all that, Aliment is located away from all the hustle and bustle of Union Square, yet just close enough to enjoy all the sights and sounds.  I tried their pastrami burger, brussel sprouts, and chicken wings.  The pastrami burger and chicken wings were delicious.  But the brussel sprouts were to "die for!"  Absolutely loved them and couldn't stop eating them.  I would come back to Aliment just to eat their brussel sprouts.  Highly recommend this place!!!
author: Joe G.

description:
I had watched this place remodel for a little while now and was super excited to see that it'd be a nice restaurant with a bar when they were adding the finishing touches.  Once opened, they would officially be the closest nice restaurant to me -- win.  After trying it last week, though, I can't say I'm impressed.  If this was any other restaurant, I would've given them 2 stars, but since they're new, I'll bump it to 3 while they work out the kinks.

Last Friday, I had a hankering for fried chicken, so we were going to walk to Hops & Hominy.  On the way there, though, we noticed that aliment appeared to be open and were curious to check it out, so we stepped in there instead.  First impression: the restaurant looks really nice and they've obviously invested a great deal of money into it.

Our waitress (who was super sweet) heavily recommended the braised spare ribs off of their sparse menu, so I gave it a shot.  We also ordered fried chicken and spaetzle with cheese to share.

The spaetzle was sooooooo good.  Comparable to ones that I've had at really good German restaurants.  Super cheesy and delicious like a German mac n cheese.  Ugh, so good.  Unfortunately, the same could not be said about the entrees.  The food was worst than "not very good", it was kind of... gross.  My first impression: they were pretty generous portions.  Quantity doesn't mean quality though.  

The first couple bites of the spare ribs (by the way, this dish is actually boneless) were pretty tasty, but anything after that was hard to put down because it's so rich and heavy.  That dish is best served as a small shared appetizer or a family style dish, not a single person entree.  I can see why the waitress would've thought it was good if she just had a bite of it.  We ended up taking most of it to go.

The fried chicken was just not good.  We got three pieces and each were of varying moisture levels on the dryer side, and none of them tasted seasoned at all.  The fried batter was so thick that it was soggy and coming off of the chicken.  It was sticking to my teeth, too, so I ended up taking off all of the fried stuff and just eating the meat.  There was so much fried batter left over that the waitress mistakenly thought I had fried chicken leftovers and almost packed it up for me.  The worst part about the dish, though, was the bed of lettuce that it came on.  I think they were going for massaged lettuce, but it came off as soggy week-old salad.  And it wasn't even cut up or pulled apart; all of the limp leaves were stuck together.

We ordered dessert, too, which was okay.  The grand total for an appetizer, a glass of wine, 2 entrees and a dessert was $85 including tax and tip.  Pricey, but it would've been totally fine if the food was good.  At least service was good.

For the prices that they're charging, this isn't going to be a neighborhood restaurant, and for what they're actually serving, this isn't going to be a destination restaurant either.  They just opened, though, so I'm still rooting for them to make some positive changes and make a splash in the neighborhood, if only because, selfishly, I want a really awesome restaurant in the 'hood.
author: Debbie L.

description:
Went here for happy hour and had great time with my friend!! The chicken wings are so saucy with a little heat on the finish.
Drinks were great even after happy hour we stayed for more cocktails and beers

After 6:00 happy hour stops but the main menu looked so good we had to share some more dishes.
Got the burger which did not disappoint, and the brussels sprouts  because this couple next to us were eating them and they smelled like heaven!!

To finish we had some of their house made ice cream, burnt caramel was to die for! 

Over all great place will friendly relaxed service, I'll be visiting soon.
author: Jay S.

description: The food was really, really good. We had the pastrami sliders and I had the Korean style fried chicken. I removed a star because I am traveling with an 8 month old baby and they didn't have high chairs so I had to hold the baby or have her in the stroller the whole time. They do have a booster seat though for older babies.
author: Steph P.

description:
Great addition to the neighborhood. Perfect for catching up with friends or eating as a solo diner. It's a beautiful new interior with a modern style.

The food is all reasonably priced with respectable portions. I recommend the kale salad (very tasty. May be one of the best I've had). The Brussel sprouts are a great starter as well.

The halibut is probably the best entree. It is surprisingly hearty for fish

Service is fast and friendly. They check on you but don't rush you at all.

I'd come back.
author: Victor W.

description:
Aliment lived up to the positive Yelp reviews. For the cost, the quality of the food was great. In addition, the service and atmosphere were well worth the price. For a party of 2, we spent $62 before tip on three dishes, two drinks and a dessert. 

We ordered the brussel sprouts, which did not disappoint. I got the kale salad and he got the lamb, and we split a chocolate bundt cake. The kale salad was coated with a delicious avacado dressing. I can't recommend it highly enough. The chocolate cake was rich and paired with whipped cream, the combination of which was delicious. The meal portions are more like appetizer size. I recommend ordering 3 items to share between two people. 

Our server was accommodating and polite, but not overbearing. We sat upstairs on a Monday night so it was quiet enough for intimate conversation. It's a nice place for a first date or meeting with a close friend. I had no complaints and would gladly visit again.
author: Ashton N.

description: Came here for dinner at 7:30pm on a Friday. Place was pretty busy, good thing I had reservations. I had the foie gras meatballs, which were ok. I thought they would be bigger, but it was enough for me. For my main meal I ordered the burger. The patty was delicious, and the fries came out super hot and fresh. Service is good here as well. However, I wish they had an updated menu online, or at least note if it changes daily. Many of the items I wanted to order was not on their menu that night. Regardless, the food was still good.
author: Lisa T.

description:
My friends and I would have had more fun doing a fast casual drivethrough.

For appetizers, we ordered lamb, mussels, and Brussels sprouts. The broth the mussels were made in was great for dipping bread. The lamb wasn't noteworthy, but was well seasoned. The Brussels sprouts were the best part of the meal. 

For the main course, we ordered the fettuccine and pork loin. The latter was overcooked, dry and underseasoned. Can I say that root vegetables that came with the pork loin saved the dish?! The fettuccine wasn't exciting; a little less salt, and a little more flavor would go a long way. The pasta itself was a good texture. 

The one thing that stood out, in a negative sense, was the service. Right from the start, something was amiss. The waitress displayed a clear lack of communication skills and a lackadaisical attitude. I placed an order for a dirty GIN martini, but received a a drink with an orange peel in it. Upon asking our waitress why I didn't taste any gin in the drink, she asked me if I had tried it, and then justifies herself by describing the recipe and that she knows what a dirty martini is. Once she replaces my drink with a real gin martini,  it is disappointingly a mediocre one. Wouldn't you expect a place that boasts a menu of specialty cocktails that cost ~$15 to make a decent martini? Not here. 

To add insult to injury, the waitress made it sound like the restaurant was doing us a favor by saying that she took off the first drink from the bill - the drink I hadn't even ordered, and returned after one sip because it had no gin. I still paid $12 for that flavorless dirty gin martini that had an olive floating around at the bottom. Should I bring my own toothpick next time?
author: Harit N.

description:
Here for coffee and desert 

Perfect coffee and pie.   Service was good.  The reason this wasn't a five star would be the noise and atmosphere.   Little pricey but well worth the quality for food.  

I do recommend this place.  Next time I'm in for dinner.
author: Robbie S.

description: Food was fabulous. Very fast and great service. Servers are very friendly. Tried their kimchi chicken and gnocchi with pork.
author: Em Q.

description:
Went for opening night and had a great time. We ordered the scallops, spaetzle, fried chicken, hangar steak, and a few beers. The scallops were delicious and came with a spicy side. The fried chicken was great - it had a thick crust but it was crunchy and flavorful. 

They have Arrogant Bastard and Allagash White on tap, plus a few others. Overall a good dining experience and a nice addition to the neighborhood - will be back!
author: Alyssa W.

description: The brussel sprouts with fish sauce is BY FAR the best brussel sprouts dish I've ever had in my life. I'm not even exaggerating. This single dish was so amazing that I wish I ordered a second or even third order. The other food is pretty solid but those brussel sprouts man, I'm so freakin' amazed by how delicious they were. Ambiance is good, service is good, but just come and order the brussel sprouts. I promise you will not be disappointed and will be glad you did it
author: Diana Y.

description:
Cute place for small plates in nob hill. Be aware that if you make a reservation on open table for a group larger than 5 you may be put in this back upper room. When we got there at 8:45 on Saturday night we arrived and no one else was seated back there. The ambiance wasn't much so we asked to be moved to the front balcony area which was much better. The back room is secluded. 

Food wise- it's solid. The brussel sprouts are the best thing on the menu. Wedge salad is alright. Kale salad was very good. The foie gras meatballs are tasty but very small and the chicken bits are ok. All in all if you are looking for a good beer and wine selection along with solid food I would recommend it. But none of the food will blow your mind. The menu selection was also limited.
author: Yasi N.

description:
Horrible service! 

They open at 5:30. I showed up at 5:20. Rather than show some compassion and provide a welcoming feeling, the waitress sneered at me and forced me to wait outside for 10 minutes when it was freezing cold with arctic air blasting down the street. So, for 10 minutes, I stood right outside the door, shivering. 

They didn't open the door to let me in at 5:30 so I walked in then, and the waitress could barely contain her disdain. But, enough is enough. 

The guy behind the bar was a bit nicer, gave me a menu, and let me order. I ordered the duck dish. It was awful. Too much acidity and salt. My stomach was uneasy for a day after eating it. 

I'd never go back to this place.
author: Eater S.

description:
My boyfriend and I were visiting SF for the weekend and trying to find somewhere to eat for dinner. We were gonna go to Hopwater but it was very crowded and the environment just didn't look that appealing to us. Then we remember walking past Aliment on the way there and went back to try it. 

I am so glad that we chose to eat here instead! We didn't make a reservation so they seated us at the bar which was totally fine because it faced a giant window so it was very refreshing and you can people watch. 

The menu is not very extensive but everything on there was very interesting. I got a glass of wine while my bf tried their beers. He said he really liked the IPA that they had.

We ordered: 
Beet salad - it was recommended by the server. I am not a big fan of beets but the salad itself was very tasty because of their vinaigrette. There were also little fried goat cheese balls in it. 

ramen crusted chicken bits - it was very crispy and not oily at all! it's served with a chinese mustard sauce mmm

brussel sprouts - its tossed in an asian fish sauce and very crispy also! 

all the dishes were perfect for drinking. The environment is very open and comfortable. I would definitely want to come back again!
author: Jenny L.

description:
A tourist trap for sure.  Food was ok at best and way too expensive for what it was.

I think there should be a way for Yelp to show reviews based on people from SF vs. out of town!  As I am pretty sure all the reviews are from tourists.
author: Tammy S.

description: Walked in and sat at the bar, only a single couple was in there from what I could see. Bar back asked if I wanted water and I replied " no a food menu please and I would like to order a drink".....crickets for 5- 10 minutes. Bartender was too busy making A drink to engage. Waited for any sign of acknowledgment, none, so I left.
author: Luke H.

description:
The Stars do not reflex the taste! Food quality was amazing! The menu is very limited! Bread is 4$ per refill after the first bread refill and there is only 4 pieces! Our waitress was ok, seemed annoyed when asked for something! The water was luke warm and was fully from a sink. And sodas were flat! 

This is not a place to kids, or casual dining! 

Our experience was ok, very expensive, prolly wouldn't go or recommend to friend
author: Pat T.

description:
Meh. 

Overpriced & Mediocre. 

What we ordered: 
$9 Brussel Sprouts
$29 Fish (today was trout)
$17 Waygu Burger
$19 Wild Mushroom Gnocchi  
$21 Braised Short Rib

BRUSSEL SPROUTS were WAAAAY too salty. It would of been delicious had there been less sauce. I am still thirsty.

For those who don't like to see what their food is made of, don't order the FISH. It comes whole..fish, eyes, tail...everything. Quite a lot of bones in it too (they attempted to de-bone the majority). I think i spent most of my time chewing very carefully and pulling bones out of my mouth (imagine a magician pulling a endless scarf). 

According to the BF, the WAYGU was ok. Umami has a much better burger. Their fries were a cross between In-N-Out and Five Guys.

My other guests raved about the GNOCCHI and the SHORT RIB. The short ribs were super tender and the gnocchi had a lot of fixins in it. 

There are too many other cheaper and tastier options in the city to go back.
author: Michelle C.

description:
The pastrami short rib appetizer was the highlight of our dinner -- tender and packed with flavor. The brussels sprouts were good, too, but it's hard to go wrong when you soak them in butter. My roast chicken entree was a bit dry and disappointing (should have stuck with my general rule of thumb to avoid the chicken) but two other people in my party ordered the monkfish and loved it. We shared three of the four desserts, of which the chocolate cake was my favorite, although none of them were outstanding.

Dishes rated on a 1-5 scale:
Pastrami short rib appetizer -- 4
Duck bits appetizer -- 3
Brussels sprouts -- 3
Roast chicken entree -- 2
Chocolate cake -- 3
Cheesecake -- 2
Basil panna cotta -- 3
author: Jia H.

description:
We had come here when they had just opened and had a fantastic meal then. However, tonight we decided to go back and it was a rather less exciting experience.

The ambiance was the same, as expected, and the service was good, but the food was rather disappointing. We ordered the Harissa salad, which should have had some interesting spice but was instead rather bland; though the prosciutto was a nice choice. The mussels could have used a bit more broth and a bit of spice, but in the long run ended up being the most solid option. The bread served with them was described as delicious, but was the consistency of pound cake - which perhaps some dig, but I was not into. The steak looked delicious on the plate and was cooked as ordered, but was disappointingly tough and sinewy for a 28 dollar rare cooked cut. And the chicken and polenta tasted conspicuously of nothing at all.

Bummer, as I dropped a days' wages on essentially a C- meal made a C+ by service and decent wine.

Will not return.
author: Sam R.

description: This is a neighborhood gem. it's just really evident they care about the details. The food is delicious, invite the bartenders to surprise you with a cocktail with minimal instruction, and enjoy the vibe. Have the Brussel Sprouts.
author: Sumit G.

description:
I really enjoyed my experience at Aliment. My boyfriend and I checked it out on a Thursday evening and were seated immediately (we also had a reservation). There are probably about 5 booths, a few tables, and 2 sets of bar seating facing the street and kitchen. Our server was cordial and pleasant.

We ordered the brussel sprouts to share. Flavor was amazing - it was drenched in caramel fish sauce and reminded me of Vietnamese food. Also was cooked perfectly - they weren't undercooked (blech, bitter brussel sprouts) nor overcooked (crispy chips status). It's a really popular dish so when Aliment can make it at a consistent quality, it's worth trying.

My boyfriend had the pork shank and I ordered the roasted chicken. The bone of the pork shank was huge, and the meat was fall-off-the-bone tender. Rich flavor and the side of German pasta (don't remember the official term) really complemented it. The chicken was good - the dark meat was juicy and tender. The white meat portion was just a bit dry, but the flavor was still there. I also really enjoyed the chard/polenta side. The next day, the chicken leftovers were even more delicious (maybe the flavor had time to sink in?). The portions were super generous - I made 2 meals out of my entree.

Great spot for a date or small group of friends - reservations and Lyft ride recommended.
author: Brandy A.

description:
Food and service... AWESOME!!

So good.  I had the Fish, which was salmon with asparagus.  My husband had the Short Ribs!!  We will be back soon!!
author: Karri T.

description:
Go on a Wednesday night around 6:30/7pm if you are a walk-in. Sit at the bar. Order drinks. (wine or beer) 

Food:
Mussels 
Foie Gras Meatballs (to die for!) 
Pork Belly with Kimchi 

Eat!
author: Shannon R.

description: Started with the Brussels sprouts and ordered the pork chop for the entrée. Both were amazing!
author: Justin J.

description:
The food was okay here and rather pricey, but that is not the reason they get one star.

I left a 20% tip for the server. You'd think that'd be enough right? Apparently, not. I went back to check my credit card statement. Someone took the liberty of adding another $10 to their tip. If I didn't regularly check my bank statements, I would have never know.

UNACCEPTABLE

Word to anyone visiting this establishment: keep your receipt and make sure you check your bank records. Shady business going on here.
author: Eric C.

description:
Aliment is a nice hidden gem in the Union Square area. Their menu isn't large but perhaps it's because the restaurant chooses quality over quantity, as everything sounded appetizing, and it was. 

We ordered a bunch of the small dishes--the sliders and the chicken bits were our favorites. Additionally, I ordered the chicken entree and it was probably some of the most tender, flavorful chicken I've ever had--would highly recommend.

In terms of service, there only seemed to be one waiter on the top floor where we were seated, but the wait for our food was very minimal. 

If you're ever looking for healthy, farm-to-table food in this area, I would highly recommend you check this place out.
author: Peter L.

description:
Located in Nob Hill which is one of the nicer area/district of SF.  Take a taxi, park on the street, or park nearby in the Sutter-Stockton garage.  Don't be distracted by the many restaurants and shops otherwise you won't reach your final destination.  If you're on a date, consider this place since the ambiance really lends itself to a successful date and/or more dates in the future.  If you go in a small group like a double date, you'll have the extra benefit of sampling most of the items on the menu since they keep the menu fairly short so 1. won't confuse customers and 2. try to keep the quality up when needing to stock ingredients.  Overall, my group of 4 had a good time and the wine the waitress suggested went well with the food.

* Brussel Sprouts = Considered to be the best thing on the menu.  The sauce and seasoning added to it makes the brussels sprouts taste like candy.  The brussels sprout still retain it's semi-bitter taste but with the sweetness, it's like eating sweet and salty popcorn.  Now, it did seem saltier towards the bottom and when we ordered a 2nd serving, it seemed heavy too.
* Pastrami Short Ribs = Short ribs that taste like pastrami.  Sign me up.  It's a great appetizer to start the meal with.
* Duck Bits = I think of this as curry with duck meat.  While tasty, I prefer going to a Thai restaurant for my duck curry.
* Butler Steak = Medium rare and very tender.  The creamy carrot puree and potato croquettes were tasty and complimented the steak.
* Pork Chop = Felt a little dry.  The sauce didn't really help in the taste department either (aka bland).
* Halibut = Soft and flaky like a halibut should be.  Not bad.
author: Ronald L.

description: Walked in to this cool space on a Sunday at about 7pm. We were greeted and seated right away without reservations. There were a few tables eating and a couple people at the bar. The space is small but has a hip vibe and a few tables upstairs overlooking the bar and downstairs dining area. We sat along the window looking out on the street. The bartender who waited on us suggested a nice glass of wine for my girlfriend and made a Rosemary ginger soda for me as I don't drink and they didn't have any N/A beer; the soda was great. We started with the Meat & Cheese plate; it had two cheeses- Gouda and Point Reyes blue, two kinds of olives, two kinds of meat, lightly toasted bread,  some caramelized onion jam, lightly dressed arugula, and olive oil. It was very good. Next we ordered a pastrami slider, it was served on a pretzel bun but the pastrami is the star here, highly recommended! We also had the grilled cheese and tomato soup, the soup was excellent but the grilled cheese wasn't very cheesy, we liked it better with one of the pieces of bread removed. We split the Bolognese that the bartender recommended and we really enjoyed it; The pasta was cooked perfectly, and the sauce was rich with lots of meat. We had the hot chocolate cake for dessert and it was also excellent. The prices seemed a little high for the portions ($107 for 3 apps, 1 entree, 1 dessert, and 2 drinks) but everything we had was very good and we received kind and genuine service. I would definitely recommend this place and come back again!
author: Andrew D.

description: Everything is good but the brussels sprouts are amazing! Also the drink menu is pretty awesome. I love any bar that can successfully leverage a barrel aged gin in a classic style cocktail.
author: Shanna P.

description:
Brussel sprouts, Chefs Board, Pork Belly...try all of these things!

They have changed their menu to focus more on share plates but with still some bigger items (like the burger). The brussel sprouts are still amazing. The chefs board of meat / cheeses is the biggest and best I have ever seen (and everyone at my table agreed with me).

Love the atmosphere, wine & beer selection, and the new menu! They have a new back room for private parties that is amazing looking and open during dinner for overflow I think.

This place continues to impress me! Definitely recommend for a casual dinner, business dinner, or dress it up and you'll feel right at home!
author: Amber M.

description: Meh. Waiter was fantastic, as was service. Brussel sprouts were good...but if you know how to cook them, not that amazing. Ordered the chicken fettuccine. Marginal, at best. Think I found three shreds of chicken in a bowl full of overly garlic noodles...of which some were stuck together and burnt. Wanted it to be good...it wasn't. Three stars for the service...maybe 1.5 for food. Would never go back!
author: Linda L.

description: The 4 stars were mainly for the service. The staff here is very friendly and attentive. The food was good. We had a party of 10 and ordered pretty much everything off the menu. Great atmosphere and clean restaurant.
author: Chris N.

description: Absolutely awful. The only reason I'm giving two stars instead of one is because the wine is good. Was served a martini which tasted as if it were 1/2 vermouth and 1/2 vodka, sent it out and saw the bartender arguing with the waitress over it. Our dishes took a very long time to emerge and when we received our appetizer, which was duck rillettes with blini, we asked for additional blini only to be sternly told, "We don't make extra blini outside of a whole order." OK. So then the main course came, steak with chimichurri sauce and grilled vegetables. The grilled vegetables were ice cold, as if they'd been charred earlier then refrigerated. The steak itself, which we ordered medium rare, was cut into jagged chunks with raw, cold, purplish centers. We sent back the main courses and asked for more wine, which the sweet (but slightly befuddled) waitress brought and didn't charge us for the steak. Overall a very poor experience, one of the worst I've had in San Francisco in the past 14 years.
author: Shane H.

description: Restaurant is pretty price and the food was just ok. Fettuccine was too rich, I wouldn't order it again.
author: Monse C.

description:
Good visit & experience for dinner on a Monday night with Wife. She picked because of proximity to Chancellor hotel and Yelp reviews. 

Service was excellent we promptly seated up stairs. It had a nice intimate and warm setting. 

We ordered Brussels sprouts, Kale salad, and Lamb sirloin plate. Portions were small but adequate for our appetite. They served a chocolate bundt cake with whipped cream and cherries for dessert.  Very good! 

Highly recommended and I would visit again when in Union Square!
author: John N.

description: No complaints here. My husband had the steak burger and raved about it. It  had a bacon jam on it. Yum! I had the pork sliders. Unique flavor.  We left very satisfied.
author: Tanya K.

description:
Giving it 3 stars only because of the staff. Everyone was so nice and friendly. Unfortunately the food didn't measure up. The cheese/meat board was actually very good, but the squash salad was strange. The citrus dressing in combination with the squash just didn't work. The monk fish was incredibly over cooked and chewy. No real flavor. And the brussel sprouts were okay but didn't redeem the entire meal. The panne cotta was fairly bland as well.

Pretty atmosphere and very nice staff, but we'd only go back for a glass of wine and the cheese board.
author: Katie L.

description: This place is amazing! I went there for some chicken and waffles and had the best chicken I have ever had in my life! The service was phenomenal and the hostess was so sweet! I also had a few mimosas and they were on point! I 100% recommend this and will be back every week!
author: Bradly D.

description:
Decided to revisit this restaurant again yesterday after having such an incredible dinner last time. We were disappointed that the menu had changed but were open to trying new dishes. I got the bolognese and my boyfriend had the chicken with polenta. Aside from getting our drinks right away, the service was nonexistent. Forty minutes, that's right, a whole 40 minutes later...we received our entrees. No checking in while we were waiting, no apologies whatsoever. 

The food was average at best. My pasta sauce tasted like canned pasta sauce from the store. That's what kills me, how does it take 40 minutes to heat up some bolognese sauce?!?? My boyfriends chicken was extremely dry and flavorless. We were so hungry at that point we ate the food but were thoroughly unimpressed. My boyfriend suggested that they bring back the braised short ribs, and the bartender literally said that it was too much work to execute so they took it off the menu. Who says that??

I will definitely not be returning.
author: Peggy L.

description:
Walked out. The Wife was super excited about the Brussels sprouts, but we both found them disappointing. The sweetness was cloying. We both ordered the steak as our entrees, both cooked medium rare. What we got was two steaks cooked totally differently. Wife's was completely, unacceptably raw and tough inside. Mine was cooked properly, but was the saltiest thing I've ever tasted. My tongue was burning for an hour afterward. The server tried to explain that the steaks are brined, and maybe that's why they were so salty? Does anyone brine steak? 

Graciously, she offered us replacement entrees, but seeing as my taste buds were destroyed for the foreseeable future, I opted out. I'm a very understanding guest when I dine out, I understand that mistakes get made and that we are all human. But I simply couldn't trust these guys to get ice water right at this point.
author: that dude w.

description:
Hm, I don't know, I wanted to like this place but the food was just meh, nothing to write home about. My bf had been wanting to try Aliment for their famous fish sauce brussel sprouts but I was a bit disappointed. I'm vietnamese, fish sauce doesn't scare me but I found this sauce to be very salty and thick at the bottom. Def not the best brussel sprouts I've had. We also shared other appetizers but I can't remember what they were. I was looking forward to the seared scallops but it was not on the menu that day. 

We shared the steak and pork chop as entrees and while the meat itself was good, the whole dish didn't come together well enough. The food was decent but not good enough that it would make me want to come back, especially with so many restaurants to try in the city. Also the price tag is not worth the meal in this case. Maybe I just expected more from a 4 stars rest? I'm open to come back to try their brunch menu but I'll pass on dinner. 

Also, Aliment is listed as $$ but that would be for the entree alone. If you are looking for price per person with appetizers, it is def a more of a $$$ place.
author: Kim N.

description:
Sorry... I so want to like it.  The bar is great!  And really great for singles wanting a tasty meal with a glass of wine - solo.  Pero... the food isn't very delicious.  Sorry.  It's not.  The Kale salad.. was ok - just not something I'd ever ask for again.  It was kind of salty without enough astringent qualities.  I couldn't taste any of the vinegar or lemon I wanted in a salad. It was just salty.  

And the Roasted Ricotta Gnocci - should I have known it wasn't going to be good? 

Sigh.  

The "roasted gnocci" by themselves were good - they looked "roasted" I couldn't really taste a difference between "roasted" and "unroasted" gnocci I'd had.  Gnocci tastes good.  It's a thing.  Roasted or not.  

But this isn't about the gnocci, it's about the "pesto pea" or "pea pesto" or whatever.  It honestly tasted nothing like peas or pesto. I'm not sure what it was.. there were a few hard green peas but not many.  There was garlic and then there was a whole bunch of other stuff, part of it was burnt.  It was not good. NOT GOOD.  I totally ate it all.  That's what happens when your a siting by the bar solo.  The bartender was very nice and I  didn't want to disappoint him.  PS he said the Char was the thing to get, and I didn't get it.
author: amy w.

description: Strip- good, but underseasoned. In concordance with everyone else, the brussel sprouts are pretty amazing.
author: Kyle W.

description:
Solid but unspectacular for dinner... Can't decided between 3 or 4 stars
Went for dinner with my parents, who tend to be easy going but actually commented on the poor service.
The food came out pretty quickly...

Brussels sprouts -- my dad and I really liked them, but my mom thought they were a little too sweet. Don't hesitate to order
Pork belly with kimchi -- hard to go wrong here... I'd get it again
Foie gras meatballs -- good combination of flavors and texture, definitely try it
Pastrami short rib -- good but a little on the dry side... I could go either way on this one
Pork riblets -- pretty average... I'd pass next time
Smoked fish of the day -- everyone liked the first bite. The 2nd was ok. No one cared for a third... The saltiness caught up to us.
author: Mital P.

description: I'm so confused how this place has a 4 star rating. Perhaps people don't know what good food and dining should be? We walked in and were overwhelmed by a strong fish smell. Knowing it would be hard to find a table at a different restaurant on a Saturday night, we decided to give it a chance. I started with the squash salad and only half of the squash was cooked correctly. The other half was so hard. When I told a server there was a problem with the salad, he responded as if he was already aware of the problem. So why hadn't they corrected it yet? Our main server forgot our bread and the gnocchi was far too salty. I attempted to order an espresso after dinner. After everything else, I shouldn't have been surprised to find out they do not have an espresso machine. Needless to say, I will not be coming back here.
author: Sho B.

description:
This place is fantastic! The food is outstanding, while the service is good.  The wait staff is pleasant enough, but they're never very warm.  Ultimately, I come here for the food, and I'd come back again and again.  

THE FOOD:
Aliment's food is always great.  I can tell that the ingredients they use are fresh.  I've never had anything that was bad, though there are some dishes that were forgettable.  The brussel sprout appetizer is my all time favorite.  It has the perfect balance of sweet, salty and spicy.  If you're a health nut, this is not a dish you should order, because the brussel sprouts are deep fried.  But trust me, it's delicious!  They recently changed their menu to a more tapas-style, and the dishes they offer are even better than before.  

THE SERVICE:
Each time I've gone to Aliment, service has been pleasant. The wait staff is helpful but they won't win you over with charm or warmth.  

THE AMBIANCE:
The restaurant is very modern and has a very young vibe.  The open kitchen is cool.  If you can, sit at the bar and see the chefs at work.  Like most restaurants in the city, it is very loud.  You have to speak loudly to have a conversation.  

All in all, this place is great for special occasions, girls/boys nights out, and date nights.  I highly recommend it!
author: Khristine A.

description:
I really wanted to love this place, I mean really wanted to! It should be good, It looks like its good but it struggles with the food and mostly the service. 

Best of luck but I would not return.
author: Brook M.

description: My boyfriend and I eat here at least once week, so I can't believe it's taken me this long to write this. We live on the same block, and one thing about this neighborhood is much of the food is mediocre and overpriced - drawback of living in a tourist trap. Aliment, however, is one of our favorite local spots because it's consistently good and the service is above and beyond.  Definitely get the brussel sprouts, the kale salad, and the gnocchi.  And ALL of the desserts are spectacular - try the fried donut with any of the ice creams.
author: Cindy M.

description:
I live 3 blocks from here and this is our favorite place.

Food is fantastic.  We've never been disappointed with anything on the menu.

And for the price it's simply the best value we've seen which is why it's our go to place.

Plus the owner Erik lives on the block so maybe I just like running into him when he's walking his dog but I'm pretty sure it's the food.  

And the cocktails....
author: rob h.

description:
What happens when you put a techie transplant from Canada, a local bay area venture capitalist, an east coast saveur from New York, and a poet/heart plumber nurse together at a dining table? A wonderful night of conversation, stories and food.

First the conversation. I like conversations in which everyone participates, yes even when one is actively and intently listening too  And how about, people not cutting you off midway a conversation - amazing, right?

Fun-filled stories whetted our appetite. From trips to different lands to funny experiences that can only happen at work  - like how you balance work and play, literally in a house that turns into an office by day, or just because you graduated with the intent in working in medicine -- doesn't mean you won't end up as a priemer visual plan designer. Awesome!

Now the aliment, food? Yes sustenance! It was a mixture of odd pieces, each person ordered differently and shared from their plates. Here were the choices:

Starters:
Brussels sprouts. Secret ingredients - brown sugar and fish sauce. No it doesn't smell , lightly caramelized and light crispy. Seriously they must have gotten this recipe from an Iron Chef episode... the winner from all the rest.

Pork Belly: I like the fat was nicely rendered and a browned crispy top. Nicely moist, it went well with the celery slaw and julienned carrots. It could have used some more citrus.

Main Plates:
Hanger Steak: medium rare, and arrived as ordered. It came with a side of sautéed spinach. I thought it was a bit salty, but not my favorite cut of steak... it was ok
Bolognese: unpretentious and Ms. Saveur only had a few bites...
Pork Chops: Thick and a tad too done, ok but not fantastic. A plain aside of sautéed string beans looked uninspired.
Roast Chicken: the gold standard among legends, but with disappointing results in this place. Chicken was overdone, lacked juiciness and seasoning was off, a dash of thick herbed cream sauce on the side (could do without). The two sides were: creamed fresh corn (too thick and heavy) and puree of a root veggie .

Dessert:
Chocolate lava cake and fondant with mint ice cream--- deliciously decadent.loved it...

PS- Overall 2.5 stars, there is room for improvement in all the dishes as the chef brings them more cohesively together. All the dishes seemed to be off in their seasonings, I would be interested in coming back, but when the menu rotates with different selections.
author: Arissa C.

description: Delicious, attentive and courteous.  We went on a Sunday evening and it was full of nob hill oldies ... Would recommend the mussels and chocolate cake, which was a molten lava cake mmmhhh
author: Pip E.

description: Visiting from Las Vegas for a few days and this place was across the street. Wonderful dinner, great service. The pork tenderloin was amazing and the salads were wonderful. A place worth going to. Wife and I loved the entire feel of the place. We are far from snobby and really enjoyed our evening.
author: Jeff K.

description:
I brought my parents to try the food here with no real expectations, but it was ahhhmazingggg. 

Everything we had was delicious so I'm just going to go over highlights. The PEI mussels were rather light on the meat but the flavor from the sauce is divine with Aliment's self described 'delicious bread'. Even without the sauce, the bread is as they accurately labelled, delicious. 

The Seared Monkfish was delicious. Tender and juicy and served with the sweet potato hash and pork belly topped with almondine sauce makes this such a balanced plate of flavors. 

The butler steak. 8oz of cooked to medium perfection. Damn. They can cook good steak here. 

The Pork Chop... is a healthily large cut. It was so tender and flavorful and just gets amplified when paired with the apple ginger glaze sauce. The spaetzle it is served with is a great contrast for texture. 

Dessert was my favorite part of the meal. The Flourless Chocolate Cake (with brandy caramel and creme anglaise) is a solid classic dessert. 

My props though goes to the chef who came up with the Basil Panna Cotta (with black rice pudding and huckleberry jam). It was such an interesting experience eating it from the bottle vessel. But the balance of the panna cotta with the black rice texture and huckleberry jam and the mix of flavors has been the most yummy thing I have tasted in a while!
author: Jeffrey Q.

description: Nice ambiance. Food is average at best - now after our second trial. The ramen fried chicken is by far the best thing in the menu that we've tried. The wine list is ok. The cocktails are ok but cannot be compared to other places in the same price point within a 4 block radius. Pasta is uninspired (gnocchi was actually borderline inedible). Even their burger is quite average. Overall, too expensive for what it is.
author: Chintu P.

description:
I will reiterate, the brussel sprouts are like WHOA.  So damn good.  

Some of the best food I have had in the city, and they are brand new.  We also had the bolognese (pretty damn spicy! be warned! by me since the menu doesn't tell you!) and the "Butler's Steak" with peppercorn brandy sauce.  Soooo good.  Steak was cooked absolutely perfect.

Only complaints are that if I would have ordered the bolognese for myself, I'd be sore as it was very spicy without any indication on the menu.  Also, our server described the Ashtray Heart as a smoky porter that was very intense.  Really, she should have just said it tasted just like an ashtray.  Keep it real, sista!  Your patrons like it real.  Anyways, after the first disgusting sips, it went ok with the charred brussel sprouts so it was cool.  Cigarette lovers might actually truly enjoy every sip.  

The food was so tasty that they still deserve every star yelp offers.  The vibe was very rock and roll hipster, with nice lighting and a movie projected on the high wall.  We couldn't watch it because it was above our heads.  Good for the bar area though.  Maybe upstairs as well.

Good to know:
They serve food til 10:30pm every night.  Yay!
They don't have cocktails.  Only beer and wine.
author: Super L.

description: Drinks were great but fairly expensive.  Kale salad and chicken bits were great, but the mac and cheese was super overcooked, to the point that it was a pasta puree.  Waiter made a mistake on our order and he was not very polite about it, in fact, gave us a bit of attitude when we both had clearly stated what we wanted.  For about $100 a person, service was subpar and food was average.
author: R X.

description:
Doesn't matter if you have a reservation or not. If you are a couple you sit next to the restroom. We asked for an empty table in a better location that was the same size shape everything but they wouldn't seat us there. We were told that that was for a reservation. When we explained we had a reservation as well the staff was condescending and rude. We walked out of there and had a great meal elsewhere. Don't bother with this place. There are plenty of restaurants in the city that offer a good Friday night dining experience.

Another thing to note is their online menu and prices are nowhere close to what you actually see on the paper menu. Classic restaurant bait and switch.
author: Kaushick N.

description: We LOVED the spaghetti bolognese (generous serving, tender meat, fresh pasta), but the chicken could not have been more dry and the pancetta it came with was all fat. As good as the bolognese was we won't be back because of how disappointing that chicken was... Too many good restaurants in the city to go to instead
author: Nicole J.

description:
While visiting from New York this past weekend, I made a stop at Aliment on Friday afternoon for a quick drink and catch up with a friend since it was a close meeting spot for the both of us. It was the start of happy hour, but had no plans of staying for food / dinner. 

So, we met originally for a few beers and sat at the corner of the bar and after chatting with one of the Chefs, Erick, we decided to order food. We got an assortment of different items including the Brussels Sprouts (my ultimate favorite), Crispy Fried Chicken Bits and the gnocchi. All of which were so so delicious.

It was my first time to the restaurant and definitely won't be my last when visiting SF in the future. The staff was so friendly and the service was up to par! If you're looking for a fun restaurant, delicious food, cool atmosphere and great people to chat with -- Aliment is the place to go!

Coming from New York -- the city of delicious restaurants on every corner -- I must say, this blows a lot of the places I've tried in NY out of the water. I am so happy we stopped in and even happier we ended up ordering food.
author: Heather S.

description: My husband and I were visiting the city for a few days and just stumbled upon this place for dinner.  We called a few minutes ahead of time and they were able to arrange a table for three.  The food was ABSOLUTELY AMAZING.  The mac and cheese was so good, we ordered round two.  Best meal I had during our visit - hands down - and we ate at a few different places. Cocktails were delicious as well.  We will return again next time we're back for a visit.
author: Amber E.

description:
Food - 3 stars - overcooked monkfish but the rest of the dish was decent

Service - 2 stars - dude at the bar needs to learn to smile.  Ding dong, you work in the services industry, when customers smile at you, the thing to do is reciprocate in kind.  But not here.  It does baffle me why small restaurants don't take the time to get to know their customers.

Too bad, location is convenient and wanted to like this place but was underwhelmed.

Will not return, nor would I recommend.
author: Lev E.

description:
3.5 stars

Appetizers: The appetizers were great! I tried the pei mussels and the brussels sprouts. The mussels were light but very flavorful. I'm not a big fan of brussels sprouts so I was kind of hesitant to try them but I was very happy I tried them. They are rich in flavor and very addicting. I could definitely understand why people were raving about them. 

Main dishes: I ordered the steak and the boyfriend ordered the chicken. The steak was pretty disappointing, I couldn't really taste much and the side salad dressing was a little too strong for me. On the other hand, the chicken was a lot better. The chicken was juicy and the corn that came with it was very delicious as well. 

Overall, service was great but I think it was a little pricey for the food. If I were to come here again, I would probably order multiple appetizers instead of ordering a main dish.
author: Seungha L.

description:
YOU MUST EAT HERE. Here are my highlights

The brussel sprouts are amazing-- both salty and sweet...
Go early, they run out of the pastrami short ribs and they are delicious
Save room for the rhubarb pie
Bolognese is delish

Overall the music and ambiance is hip but not overwhelming.
author: Alli J.

description:
I had dinner here with my sons and their wives last night.  What a great meal!  The food was super tasty, the wines were wonderful and well priced, and the service was friendly and quick!!

Favorite dishes of mine included the brussel sprouts and that amazing short rib pastrami!  My family loved the carbonara and bolognese.  And those ice creams, spearmint chocolate chip and lemongrass lime were creamy, delicious and large portions!  

I will return here, and soon!!
author: Judy W.

description: Excellent food for an excellent price! Which is extremely hard to come by in SF. We ordered about half the menu to share with a group of 5 and everyone loved absolutely everything. Some highlights include the brussel sprouts, the mussels, the pastrami sliders, the gnocchi, and the smoked chicken fettuccine. But everything was great! Highly recommend.
author: Kristin S.

description:
Went here for dinner on the night of March 23rd (Monday).  Checked into the Mark Hopkin after a long day of traveling.  Found this restaurant was about two blocks away and decided to check it out. 

Nice little restaurant.  Seems like it would be a nice date spot.  I sat at the bar. 

What I had:  A few beers, Brussel Sprouts, and the Arctic Char. 

The beer selection is somewhat limited.  The restaurant seems to be a bit more versed in wine. 

Brussel sprouts were very good.  A bit of a different take then the usual (fish sauce added).  I do have to say the taste of the fish sauce was a bit overpowering but I still enjoyed the dish.  The brussel sprouts were cooked just right, not too mushy but not too firm. 

The Arctic Char was very good but a bit pricey (but it is San Francisco).  Had a lot of different elements going on and they were all quite delicious (pork belly and sweet potato hash.  In addition, the dish was plated very well.

Overall, the restaurant is nice and would be good for like a 2nd or 3rd date when you're sure you want to spend a bit more money than the standard coffee shop date.
author: Frank M.

description:
This pace was great.  The staff was extremely friendly and knowledgeable.  They were able to recommend what I could eat that was gluten free (which was a good portion of the menu).  

Every plate we ordered was delicious and  I could eat the kale salad everyday.
author: Hannah R.

description:
Smoke fish eggs Benedict was a fail. In fact. Worst I've had in a long long time. No hollandaise sauce. Eggs weren't runny. Bread was burnt. Not a single thing was done correctly. 

Brussels sprout was salty and sweet as hell. Water please?

Black rice that came with the fried chicken was a big wtf. 

Only decent dish was the short rib hash. 

Get a new chef with proper cooking skills and a taste bud.
author: Joshua W.

description:
I want to like you, Aliment, I really want to. If you like New American cuisine, Aliment fulfills the entire checklist - high ceilings with balcony second floor seating, unusual flavor combinations, wooden tables, unconventional lighting structures, and waiters wearing berets and golden reptile skin shoes. They were also projecting Armageddon on one of the walls in place of wall decor (We sat right under the screen, and my friend summed up our experience pretty well: "Armageddon is great, but I don't want to feel like I'm being shot at during my meal."). I had high hopes that I had discovered the new gem of New American chic in San Francisco, but the food left me with mixed feelings.

- Fried Brussels Sprouts ($9): Aliment seems to be Asian-inspired to an extent. Covered in a fish sauce caramel reduction, these sprouts are probably some of the best I've ever had. The sweet and savory, Asian and American combination is unexpected and you'll find yourself rolling the sprouts around in the sauce because you just can't get enough of it.

- Flatbread ($12): The dinner special was a burrata, kale, and tomato flatbread. Burrata is always great, no argument there.

- Seared diver scallops ($17): I ordered this as an entree, but it can be shared as an appetizer. Three large scallops lie on a thin bed of black rice, thai green curry, and pickled shallots. The scallops are topped with a very unexpectedly spicy seasoning, and there is little relief to be found in the actual scallop meat and rice. There was a lot of different flavors clashing in the plate, and none of them seemed to mesh together peacefully.

- Flourless Chocolate Cake ($9): Flourless cakes are usually an unsavory affair for me, but I really enjoyed how light this one tasted. It was topped with cream and caramel sauce.

I enjoyed my friend's dinner special linguini with shrimp and lobster ($18) much more than my scallops, but I wouldn't say it was entirely unique. My other friend described her Roasted Chicken Breast ($20) as "fancy KFC" - perhaps a little harsh, but it was nothing too special either. I came with two friends on a Saturday night and there was no wait.

Maybe the lack of impressive entrees that night unfairly marred our judgment of Aliment. But if nothing else excites you here, at least get the brussels sprouts!
author: Jessica F.

description:
I've been here a couple of times, but I wasn't wowed to the level I was hoping for. The Brussels (not "brussel") sprouts are too salty from being drowned in sauce, and the kale salad is too heavy on the dressing. It's really too bad because I live only a block away and was wishing for Aliment to live up to the standards that Sons & Daughters and Sweet Woodruff have set. I was also let down by their 2013 New Year's Eve offering: a flier on their window promised complimentary (not "complementary") appetizers and a champagne toast at midnight. But after getting clarification from our waiter at about 10pm that night, the plan was to give out hors d'oeuvres after the kitchen closed. Oh, well. I guess I'll try to make it to a happy hour (weekdays from 5-6pm) to try the other appetizers for 50% off.

Random side note: not sure why, but the restroom doesn't offer toilet seat covers despite the fact that there's only one toilet for all guests of both genders. At least it seemed relatively clean.

The verdict: eh, it's okay, but not mind blowing. I'll go again just because it's in the neighborhood.
author: Tiff T.

description: I am disappointed in myself that I didn't come here earlier. Walk by the restaurant everyday. This place is a gem. Whoever is back in the kitchen is slinging dope dishes. Everything was amazing: kale salad, short ribs, brussel sprouts, mussels, pork belly, bolognese pasta, carbonara pasta, and pretty much everything on the dessert menu BUT that chocolate ganache cake! Holy Shinto! Best cake ever.
author: Hyuk L.

description:
The Brussels sprouts are ridiculously addictive- I could have finished the entire serving on my own.
The charcuterie platter was gorgeous and delicious too; bread was perfectly charred. 
Desserts were kinda forgettable.

The sparkling cava by the glass though: gave me the absolute worse hangover I've ever had. And I only had 2 glasses!
I had a horrible headache the next day for pretty much the entire day. 
Yikes
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
aliment is a no frills establishment. i would consider the decor simple and crisp. the host and server were friendly and genuine. this leads me to believe that they just want the food to speak for itself (which it does)!   I thoroughly enjoyed my meal here and encourage anybody who just wants a good meal to find their way there!

between two we shared:

fried brussel sprouts with fish sauce caramel. nori. sesame seeds---
caramelized fish sauce? really? i honestly wasn't sure what to expect with this but i figured that screwing up brussel sprouts would be a pretty hard task, so we gave it a go. lemme tell you, these guys were so tasty! the caramelized fish sauce gave it a familiar sweetness that matched well with the bitter brussel sprout leaves. surprisingly the best dish of the night! i was popping these in my mouth like they were candy!

seared diver scallops. crispy red quinoa. green thai curry. pickled shallots---
hearty portioned, well cooked, fresh scallops in earthy curry. no complaints here!

burger on brioche. bacon jam. white cheddar aioli---
the burger itself was pretty salty however it was balanced by the bun which was extra sweet. the bread almost tasted more like a hawaiian sweet roll than a buttery brioche. overall, the flavors all worked well together. the fries look to be of the kennebec variety, which usually come pretty crispy but these were almost soggy. not a problem for me, as i actually prefer soggy fries.

braised short rib. broccoli di ciccio. turnip graten---
a simply good short rib dish. it's hard to go wrong with short rib though. 

definitely no room for dessert. i'm headed back this weekend to check out brunch!
author: Regina C.

description:
Very sexy and inviting eating establishment nestled into bush street. I like many others had passed this place several times before deciding to make a reservation. I ate there this past weekend and overall it was a great experience. 

When you come in it is very crowded and loud like you would expect from most downtown SF locations similar to Jaspers or Fly Bar. It is dark and there is loud ambiance music blaring out downstairs. It was really busy on Saturday night so i would recommend making a reservation to ensure good seating. 

We were able to eat up stairs and it was much quieter and more romantic up there. Its a great place for couples and has an upscale vibe. The staff is very nice and knowledgeable as well. 

The food was very good, Aliment is an odd mix of american food that I couldn't figure out but it was unique which with all the other eating options downtown you probably need. My date enjoyed the brussels sprouts and the spaekle and kale were amazing dishes. I really just wanted to try a bunch of things so we ordered about 4 dishes including the cobbler dessert which was wonderful. I recommend actually saving room for dessert here. 

I didn't try any of the entrees so I might need to go back and check those out. Not really a casual dining place at night so I will wait for next date night. Overall great experience and not too expensive for downtown.
author: Nick R.

description:
This review is only a reflection of the underwhelming etiquette in the salutations and greetings of this establishment - and can summed up in the dialogue exchange when entering:

server - "Hello! Please have a seat wherever you like."

me - "Thank-you.  I think I'll sit in the farthest booth that's empty."

guy behind the bar - "You waiting for someone or are you dining alone?" 

me - "Just me."

guy behind the bar - "You may sit in any of the seats at the counter (bar)."

In other words, we're not going offer you one of many empty booths that we have currently right now.  We value your patronage less than a couple (or more in a party) that may theoretically be dining so your only choice is to sit at the bar.

At this point I paused momentarily and an immediate "fuck off" flashed through my head but remained a private thought, and I politely smiled and said, "You know what? I don't feel like sitting at a bar," and simply walked out.

To the guy behind the bar:  Get it together.
author: Jordan R.

description: So delicious! Fried chicken and gnocchi blew our minds!! Will definitely come back to this hidden gem- San Francisco local
author: Kelsey M.

description:
My wife and I were in San Francisco for a long weekend and stumbled across Aliment as we were walking down to Union Square.  

Nice design, good service, great food, and a small, curated menu.  This isn't fine dining but it's not burgers and french fries either.  We had dinner - my wife had the bolognese and I had the chicken, and we split a salad to start.  We both had more than enough food, and it was all great quality.  

I'm not sure I'd make a special trip to eat here, but as others have said, this is a very good quality "neighborhood" spot which is sorely needed in the Nob Hill area.

Tip: If you are only dining with one or two other people, ask to be seated at the bar where you can watch the action in the open kitchen.  It's fun to see the culinary team at work.
author: Ben C.

description:
The best food I've had in san Francisco thus far!  I had the steak which was cooked and seasoned perfectly.
Ben's service was excellent.  
Great ambience, perfect for a date night.
author: Jason B.

description:
This place surprised me. Yes, I know it has some solid reviews, but doesn't everyone these days? 

In brief:
- Brusssel sprout appetizer was amazing. It looks like charred brussel sprouts but the flavor is anything but. A nice lemon zest sets it apart from anything I've had before. 
- Scallops in a bed of saucy quinoa were delightful but, at $4 per scallop, kind of a splurge. 
- Short ribs were INCREDIBLE. Hands down delicious. Tender as can be, in a rich wine sauce, this was one of the best slabs of meat I've had in a while. Highly recommend you just get what I got, cause you won't be disappointed. 

I wish:
- They had not run out of so much. We were eating at 8:30 and they didn't have a few menu items which is always kind of sad.
author: Jeff M.

description: UNEDIBLE! se were starving and looked un Yelp for a nice place to have dinner. I ordered the scallops, a total mess! The cook ABUSED of "lemon pepper" it was a total mistake not to return the food, i guess i ate it just because i was starving! I had to remove the crust! We ordered salmón as well, súper salty and also with a LOT of pepper. (We are mexicans and believe me, definately NOT picky eaters!) we felt robbed... I dont know if it was the da y off for the usual chef but it sucked big time!!!!
author: María R.

description:
We had a good time and tried all the dishes mentioned by other reviewers. One thing about the Brussels sprouts is that there were a lot of oil at the bottom of the bowl which can be a bit off putting, but the sprouts didn't taste super greasy. I wonder if they can drain better before loading into the dish?

The riblets were ok, not quite "falling off the bone" tender like some other reviewers said. Maybe they haven't been cooked long enough since we got there around 5:30?
