The Bolognese past was great, wish there were more noodles or bread to dip into the sauce!!

Service was great. Definitely a nice place to do intimate dinner.
author: F.H. H.

description: It was ok .. The apps were great we got the Brussel sprouts and tuna tartar . The entrees were underwhelming I had the gnocchi which lacked flavor my sister had the chicken nothing special and our friend had the bolognese which was bad . Service was awesome and venue was nice . They need a full bar
author: mahtab e.

description:
Half a block from my front door!!! Woo Hoo!  Couldn't wait for this place to open.  Knew if it was half as good as Sweet Woodruff I would eat there 2-3 times a week.

First time I went, between my friend and I we got two apps and two entrees.  Of the four plates, one was off the hook, one was very good, and the other two were very average and overpriced.  Figured it was new and that was to be expected and that they would hit their stride in time.

Second time, wanted to have some wine.  After seeing what passes there for a list I decided to bring my own.  An '07 Brewer Clifton Mt Carmel, something that I'll happily pay a corkage fee for and everyone wins.  

But $40?!?!?!  That's rapacious.  I mean, I get it it if it's Michael Minna, or Alexander's, or Fleur de Lys.  Not that I even know what those places charge, but I would understand if you had an extensive list like an elite place (Minna), the traditional list of a top end steakhouse (Alexander's), or an unusually well developed wine list (Fleur).  If a place like that chose to discourage people from bringing their own, or simply had a high price to match the high price of everything else there, I would understand.  But Aliment's "list" has a TOTAL OF SEVEN WINES!!!!   And its not like they are amazing unknown under priced gems of each varietal.

To his credit, the server appeared horrified and apologized profusely when he told me the rate.  When I replied with, "wow".  He rolled his eyes and said, "yeah, we're all really upset about it, but the owner won't budge.  He doesn't want people bringing their own wine".  He later came over and pointed to the owner and asked if I would go say something about the corkage. 

As a matter of principal, I enjoyed my wine.  And as a matter of principal, I won't be back.

One thing about this place that is obvious (and this comes through in other reviews) is that the place is a little disjointed.  It really doesn't know what it is trying to be.  Is it a neighborhood place, like a more formal version of Sweet Woodruff?  Or is it an upscale destination, like a more casual version of Sons & Daughters?  With a few tweaks, it could be amazing as the former.  It would take a major overhaul and a vision that they clearly don't have to become the latter.
author: craig F.

description:
Well! Not only did I enjoy solo dining at this sexy establishment (the Bolognese was a comforting choice, but managed to taste fresh and interesting) but a night that could have turned out tragically was saved...

I left my purse at Aliment, but didn't even realise! 

It wasn't until Divine Daniel found me at the Hotel Rex Library Bar, called out my name, that I knew anything had gone astray! He personally delivered my wallet! I was absolutely floored! Such a triumph of humanity, I say. A marvellous example of a random act of kindness!

I had less than 24 hours left in San Fran, I wouldn't have made it it back to Melbourne, Australia without my wallet.

Thank you, Divine Daniel!

PS wish that I'd had an extra few stomachs, loved my pasta but had serious food envy over other peoples meals. Very jealous of the locals!
author: Leesa L.

description:
Yelp put it perfectly: "Meh. I've experienced better".

I don't want to get into the details of the food itself, it was all fine. But the mediocre service made me feel slightly ripped off. Very over priced, definitely not worth what you are getting.
author: Nicolas M.

description: Loved the Brussels sprouts, gnocchi, wings, grilled cheese and soup and the service!!!!
author: Kim F.

description:
this place was really good! came in for dinner on a friday and was seated at the last two spots at the bar, which is perfect cuz i love seeing all the action in the kitchen.

the beer and wine selection is quite impressive. i got to try a belgian amber called 'fluffy white rabbits'...like what? is this for real?  delicious tho. there are all kinds of interestingly-named beers, so take your pick!

the small vs. big plates menu is perfect for sharing.  i'd usually go for the fries and brussel sprouts, but their version is of the steak fries variety and i prefer thin-cut instead.  also had brussel sprouts earlier in the week, so decided to skip it.  instead - we got the roasted squash salad, which was great and topped with nomsy goat cheese, and the crispy duck bits, which were a teensy salty. shrug. oh well.

for the big plate, was deciding between the pork chop or steak - ended up getting steak with black rice (interesting texture!) and a chimichurrrriii sauce (mmm!)

passed on dessert because i didnt run friday morning, BUT got glasses of dessert wine, which were good and reasonably priced i thought. cuz sometimes places charge $15 for dessert wine and thats just ridiculous.

the waiter was so nice and joked with us and was attentive enough. weee! glad i finally tried this place after passing it numerous times recently :) they also had the baseball game projected on the wall when you walk in, which was cool, haha.
author: Christina L.

description: Really, really good food prepared in unique ways. I had gnocchi and my husband had the brussel sprouts and some rib appetizer. The gnocchi is a soft-pillow type and I like a more bite-y, chewy type...but they were still good. The ambiance is nice and our waitress (wearing a septum-piercing) was delightful and the bus people were very attentive. No bread with dinner, but maybe we had to pay for bread and I might not have seen it on the menu by accident. I had a really good breakfast there and wanted to try dinner.
author: Michelle L.

description: Came back after almost a year. Ordered the coho salmon again. This time it was perfection. Salmon was perfectly cooked. The black rice crispy, flavorful and delicious! They obviously isolated the dish bc this time there was no slaw but a green sauce that perfectly complemented the dish. So yummy! I could eat the salmon every night! But I won't bc I think part of the flavor profile is a ton of butter or ghee. Still so yummy. Highly recommend the salmon.
author: Sharmin K.

description:
Nice seating upstairs, very good service, decent food but it didn't live up to the price.

the brussel sprouts were way to salty.

I had the burger and it was forgettable.
author: Matthew T.

description:
Food was mediocre.  Portions were very small and served slightly cold.  I did eat my entree, but left hungry.  Really hungry.  Like I made a sandwich immediately when I got home hungry.  Service was bad.  Bad attitudes and bad timing.  No one at our table of 6 was served at the same time.  Part of the fun of dining out is to enjoy a meal at the same time and this didn't happen.  It was 12 minutes (yes, I timed it) from the time the first entree appeared to the last.  Even more bizarre was the fact that there were a few of our group who ordered the same dish, but they came out at different times.  Staff were very indifferent about this which is what I think bothered us the most.  Staff were very socially retarded bordering on rude.

The space is contemporary, new and clean looking which is a nice change for the neighborhood.  Music was good and the majority of the crowd made the effort to look/dress nicely.  Another welcome change from dirty looking hipsters and the homeless chic look too many San Franciscans embrace.

I'll keep it on my list and maybe give it another shot.  If their service and attitudes don't improve, I'll not return again and bad mouth the place to anyone who'll listen.
author: Jeff M.

description: This place was not good. The service was very slow. The salmon was raw. The burgers were very under-cooked. There are a lot of good restaurants in the area. I recommend picking one that is not this restaurant.
author: Jai L.

description:
Cool place but underwhelming food.

This place caught my eye as I rode by and I stopped in for dinner. Everything looked great and I had high expectations, but everything I had fell short. I ordered the scallops, brussel sprouts, and apple pie. The scallops were pretty good, though nothing to write home about. The brussel sprouts were just not good; they were cooked appropriately but dressed in a sickly sweet sauce that was just completely inappropriate for sprouts. The apple pie was ok but a bit bland, and while my plate came out piping hot, the pie itself was oddly cold. I will not return.
author: DJ S.

description:
Came to San Fran for a business trip, and some friends that live in Fresno wanted to drive down and meet me for dinner. It was kind of last minute, so I chose a random place (mostly based on $$) that was close enough to my hotel (4 blocks away) that I could easily walk to and not get lost.

Aliment is a pretty cute, chic place - small dining area, so I think reservations are recommended because of that. I heard our waiter have to turn away at least one party that didn't have advance reservations (on a Sunday night!). It got a little noisy when the restaurant filled up, since it's just one giant open space.

There's a random projector playing a movie on the wall... I wasn't really sure what to think of it. I think it's a cool idea, but it wasn't very easy to actually see what was playing unless you awkwardly craned your neck to look back and up. Maybe it's mostly for the bar seating?

The food was not really memorable, which is the main reason for the 3 stars. I chose a salad appetizer and roasted chicken breast entree, and the salad was the better of the two, by far. It had some hearty mushrooms, a nice light dressing, and a poached egg on top - overall a nice combo. The chicken, however, wasn't as exciting. It was on the bone, with the skin, so it was fairly tender and moist, but there wasn't much flavor at all. The corn side that came with it was probably the best part...there was also a sauce that came with the dish that wasn't very good at all...didn't compliment any of the parts of the dish.

Mildly disappointed in my selection for dinner, but I at least got to enjoy a few hours with some friends in a nice setting. Next time I'll do a little more research ahead of time!
author: Sam S.

description:
One of my good friends was in town and knowing how much of a foodie he is, I decided to take him to Aliment. 

We had to do an early dinner at 5:30, and they had no problem seating us immediately. Wonderful decor was the first thing I noticed. Our waitress was superb. She knew all of the drinks and dishes.  She was super friendly and checked on is quite frequently. 

The food was very, very delicious. I highly recommend the Brussels sprouts!!! We had to get two orders!  Our group ordered the chicken, pork chop, bolongnese, and squash pasta. All were excellent!!  

A great time was had by all!
author: William L.

description:
Wow we just had the worst meal here.  There were 6 of us and the only meal that was ok was the kale salad.  The Pozole, the short ribbed hash, the fish Benedict and the mushroom tortilla all came out cold.  Mediocre is being nice. Hardly any flavor.  The short rib was tough.  It should melt in your mouth.  We ordered Brussels sprouts to start and they were good but had way too much salt.  

The mimosas were good.  The waiter was nice.  He forgot my friends request for ketchup when the fries we ordered to start with finally came out.  We ordered them to start along with the Brussels sprouts but they didn't come out till the entrees had been returned.   He said the food being cold was his fault.  Not sure what happened here.  

The guy at Nob Hill Grille recommended we go over there since there was no wait and the food "is amazing".  Worst thing ever.  I feel horrible since I was in charge of picking the brunch spot for friends that are visiting from out of town.
author: Jackie G.

description:
Cool looking place but thats pretty much it. Could be a better locales spot but looks like they targeted different crowd. ( i guess its not our business but maybe expectations. 
Our experience wit this place:
Our server was less interested to serve us than the bartender. 
Food was just ok! Pozole soup was worse than any random mexican taqueria's but costs you twice more. Drink menu was not interesting neither, little bit of everything nothing special. 
Its a still new business so lets give it a little time and see if things are changing.
author: Lyra S.

description:
I give the food 3 stars but the servers were so nice I decided to round up. I've passed by this place so many times and finally got to check it out last night. Love seeing new establishments pop up in my neighborhood.

Just came from yoga so opted for the kale salad, sister had the wild mushroom cappellini, and we share the brussels sprouts and a bottle of grenache/syrah blend. My favorite was the fried brussels sprouts. They were so crispy and the sauce had a sweet umami flavor to it. The kale salad was very straightforward, nothing to rave about other than the  fresh ingredients. We both thought the pasta was too sour (perhaps the cheese they used) and not what we were expecting. 

Portions were good for sharing and wine was affordable. The server let us hang around until all the lights were off then he proceeded to offer us more wine :) I want to come back and try their brunch next time!
author: Cheryl C.

description: Off work early! Great company! Amazing service! Just what I needed!!!!
author: Michael T.

description:
Summary: Long awaited opening for a total let down.

Pretzel and pub cheese - cheese congealed almost immediately. The pretzel bread was tough and lacked flavor. Chicken liver was okay, but the bread was so hard I worried my teeth would break. Lamb shank - the ricotta puree was broken, other than that it was ok.

Service was good but food was a bit odd.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Start out with the brussel spouts, mussels, go to to rigatoni, steak, chicken, unbelievably full of flavor. Pick the L'Oliveto Pinot Noir. Soooo delicious. Service is great too!
author: Early L.

description:
Let me start by saying, this is one of my favorite restaurants in SF.

The decor is so absolutely San Francisco.  The service is great.  The location is wonderful - centrally located in a great walking neighborhood.

The menu is minimal but the food is quality.  Everything I've ever eaten here was great.  The pork belly, brussel sprouts, bolognese... 

Go try it for yourself!
author: Joyce C.

description:
Overall a very good experience.  Very well designed space with main dining room (4 place tables only), mezzanine (2 place table only) and great "L" bar and window bar.
Food we had on a 10 scale (note to Yelp!)
Chicken bites:  6/10.  Tender inside which is the best attribute.  Flavor good, not as amazing as I expected per reviews.
Mac n Chees w bacon:  7/10.  Mac n cheese was very good, the bacon brought it down.  I love bacon, prob here was it needed a little more rendering, was too tough and chewy.
Bolognese:  5/10.  Good but average good only.  It tasted like a throw it together sauce not the long simmer that yield intense flavors.
Brussel Sprouts:  8/10 first bit, 4/10 last bite.  Initially very crack-like.  A few bites in the sweetness started getting too much.  At the bottom of the bowl was a awful deep pool of that sweet stuff and the pieces down there were near inedible.
Service:  8/10 no dropped balls unless lack of a coaster counts as such.
Prices:  7/10.  Not a bargain but reasonable portions and quality for a quality place such as Aliment.
author: Andrew W.

description:
I've been watching this empty storefront for the last two or three years, wondering what was going to move in. Well, the wait is finally over, and I'm underwhelmed. aliment was a very strange restaurant. The short version: okay soul food, not vegetarian friendly, good Italian wine list, great service. Somewhere between 2.5 and 3 stars. I've only been here once, and I suppose if I go back again I'll update this review.

I went here on Sunday with my girlfriend, who has strong vegetarian leanings. There's no menu outside, and no website, and generally little information available, so we treated it as an adventure. We got in and were seated by our waitress, who was very nice and very responsive. We got the menus and were a little distraught to see that not only was there only a single vegetarian option on the whole menu, but there were only two items on the menu that seemed to include vegetables at all! Thankfully, the wine list (on the reverse of the menu) is substantially longer than the actual food list. She got an imported Vermintino and I got a Sonoma Zinfandel; both were quite good, although since we hadn't actually picked food yet, they weren't particularly effective pairings.

Appetizer choices on Sunday were fried brussels sprouts in a fish sauce, french fries, or spätzle. We got the spätzle, but the kitchen got behind, so they gave us comp french fries for an appetizer and then the spätzle showed up with our main courses. Both were just okay; the fries were thick-cut but not particularly seasoned, and the spatzle tasted like macaroni and cheese with the smallest amount of what might've been fried onions.

For the main courses, my girlfriend got the potato gnocchi (the only vegetarian option on the menu), and I got the fried chicken. The chicken was pretty good, fried with a sweet barbecue sauce of some kind and all white meat (two breasts and a drumstick), but it was just fried chicken sitting on two rather sad-looking romaine lettuce hearts. No attempt at a side. I'm told that the gnocchi was okay. It came with peas and what I think were lentils.

The ambiance was nice, although somewhat odd paired with the food. Quiet with very modern decor. In general, I think it was that mismatch that bothered me all around -- upscale new american decor, wine list, and design, paired with food that really wanted to be eaten by hands instead of forks.

Price was... surprisingly high for what we got. $70 before tip for two people with one glass of wine each and no dessert.

If aliment expands their menu a bit to have some things that feel at least slightly healthy, becomes a little more inclusive to vegetarians, and actually gets some information out there, maybe I'll go back again. And maybe it'll even be a good addition to the neighborhood.
author: James B.

description: This place had a nice ambiance and good staff. We were visiting from our of town and chose this as a dinner location based on the website which was misleading. Make sure you know which are entrees and which are small plates. Maybe since we viewed the website off the cell phone we didn't get the full menu, I'm not sure but make sure you don't go there super hungry.
author: Andrea M.

description:
This place is an exemplary little neighborhood joint with a seasonal menu that makes you want to order everything on it. Luckily, they have a number of small plates, so you don't need to commit to just one dish. They also have a fantastic wine menu with selections not commonly seen. I usually sit at the bar where service has always been great. 

My favorite thing on the menu to date is the spaetzle. I also love the brussel sprouts, but will agree with other reviewers that they tend to be heavy on the sauce, so I just order them with "light sauce."
author: Sarah G.

description:
I really have mixed feelings about Aliment. It's good enough that I've gone a few times, but not good enough that I want to go there. Don't get me wrong, the food is good, but it's just not omg I have to have that again good.

Each time I go here, there is usually one dish that I'm like this is really good, but everything is else is just meh, OK. I've had steak here, the brussels sprouts, and then this amazing kit kat cheesecake (hands down the best thing I've had here). It's really hard for me to explain this place, because I do like the food, but there's something missing and I just can't place my finger on it. 

The atmosphere is great and the space is really nice. I've eaten at the booths, at the bar and upstairs and each spot is it own thing. I do love the open kitchen where you can see all that is happening

My recommendation, go for the brunch. I had a chicken and waffle that was amazing and my boyfriend had this amazing burger. This was the first time we went there and unfortunately it just hasn't lived up to that one time.

I'm really torn on whether or not I'll go back. I probably will, but this isn't a go to spot for me.
author: Sabrina D.

description:
Brussels sprout: very good
Beer: $6,00 for a half pint glass
Short rib: not good
Bolognese: not good
Price: overpriced 
Atmosphere: good
Overall: not worth coming back
author: Ramadhianto D.

description:
Surprised by the number of positive Yelp reviews here.

I love brussels sprouts, I love making them at home, and I love them in restaurants, especially at Barbacco -- yum.  I didn't really care for the brussel sprouts at Aliment.  They were, to my taste, undercooked, and tasted overwhelmingly of fish sauce -- I guess if you LOVE fish sauce it would be a good dish.

The bolognese was bland and reminded me of something that might be on a children's menu.  Chocolate cake was extremely dry; my dining companion described it as "shockingly bad".  

On the good side: prices are reasonable, portions are large, service and atmosphere are fine.  But with all the options in the Union Square area you can do a lot better.
author: Alex H.

description:
Did not get a good entry experience at this restaurant. They did not have host table or whatsoever, so we had to wait in the middle of the way while we were waiting for our table. 

They have good brussel sprouts. That's all. 

Short rib was tasteless, bolognese was tasteless, salad was okay, beer was a rip-off (they served it in a water glass and charged $6.00).
author: Natasha C.

description: The service was great and the ambiance is cool, but the chef refused to make me a simple salad of nuts and lettuce bc I can't have cheese or meat.  Lame.
author: Katy W.

description:
My friend and I met up for dinner on a weeknight -- we got there around 7:30 and easily got a table.  It got busier as the night went on but I don't think people every had to wait.  

First of the all, the portions are very generous -- so definitely don't have to order too much food especially the sides.  Everything was really delicious and would definitely go back for the food.  

The decor/ vibe of the place was a little strange -- felt like a restaurant/ bar in a hotel? The lights hanging around were really cool, but I didn't feel like the furniture matched the place.  

There was also only 1-2 servers working the night we were there, so it got kind of busy for the servers when the place had more people.  

Overall, a great local easy restaurant.  Food was yummy; good choice of beer; would go back again.
author: Imee C.

description:
One of the best meals I've had to date. 
We ordered: 
Brussel sprouts
Pork Belly
Scallops
Steak 

I have not yet developed the vocabulary to perfectly describe the strange happiness i felt upon digesting the first bite of pork belly. 
It's a decently sized piece of pork belly that is perfectly crisp on the outside and soft and tender on the inside. Like most pork belly, all layers must be eaten together, at the same time, within the same bite. 
As soon as i placed the first bite in my mouth, the fat disappeared in an instant leaving me with the question as to whether it was really there at all. 
What i guess i'm trying to say is... order it. 


I am very particular about my brussel sprouts. Extremely. 
But i must say the Brussels were done well. Not soggy or overdone on the inside. There was a slight bite to it- and the flakes and seaweed added additional texture that varied the dish. It was a bit too sweet for me, i had to scrape most of them to the side, wait for the sauce to drain and then eat them. We still finished every morsel. haha. 

The scallops were good, but not impressive. In fact, not impressive enough for me to write more about them. They were good though. 

The steak. 
Holy smokes. By the time we finished the above three starters this was the perfect finish. I'm an edge-of-the-steak person and i must admit it was perfectly charred and seasoned... oh gosh. No words. No words. 

The space itself is very well designed. The kitchen takes up about half of the restaurant which shows to me that they prioritize their food. The lady chef in the back was doing her thing and every 5 minutes i just wanted to shout, " you go girl! You go girl!" but alas, the ambiance did not allow for that type of behavior. 

I shall be coming again- as I feel it was worth the price in exchange for the amount of satisfaction my belly experienced upon our departure. Service was fine but food was better.
author: Michelle F.

description: Good food. Really unimpressive service. The waitstaff messed up our order AND our bill and never apologized or thanked us for pointing out a $60 undercharge. Thank goodness we are honest people!
author: Stacie S.

description:
I've pretty much had everything on the menu and you cannot go wrong! Everything has its own unique taste- I particularly like the brussels sprouts. 

We got to meet the owner who has a great story to tell and truly cares about your dining experience. You can tell that he is living out his passion to create perfection in the San Francisco restaurant scene. 

The ambiance is super warm and inviting. If I lived closed I would make this place a frequented one.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Dinner last night with party of 5 that included 12 year old.  Got seated quickly and service was solid.  Incredible gnocchi, with perfect texture.  Portions a little small so go ahead and get appetizer.  Solid service and quality of food.  Recommended especially if out of town at one of the closer hotels like Fairmont.
author: George H.

description: Contemporary, casual decor.  Friendly, fast service.  Eclectic menu.  We had the beet salad, duck rillettes, red curry mussels and ricotta gnocchi with pork belly.  All excellent, with the rillettes and gnocchi an 11 on a scale of 1 - 10.  The only disappointment was that two of the wines we wanted were not available, but the substitutes were just fine.  We'll be back to try some of the other interesting offerings.
author: Hal N.

description:
Good service, enticing menu, sleek modern vibe. The Brussels sprouts are as good as everyone says they are. We watched a lady come in and sit with a glass of wine while she waited for an order of sprouts to go. She said she dreams of them, and asked our server how they are made. He actually gave her the whole run down on the recipe. I eavesdropped, naturally, and will try it at home. (hint: deep fryer)

They lost stars from me by over seasoning most of the food. Although the Brussels sprouts were on point, it was almost too generous a serving, better shared with 4 people than 2. Sometimes you can have too much of a good thing.

My entree was the pastrami short rib. I conceptualized the dish in my head totally different than what it actually was, so I was disappointed by default (I imagined a beef short rib wrapped in pastrami...) The short rib was made of pastrami, and coated in an aggressive peppercorn rub. With no sauce on the plate to balance it out, I found the flavor to be too overpowering.

My boyfriend had the steak. It was a generous portion, nicely done. I tried to take his plate but he held onto it.

I might go back again to order something different, and after that, aliment will probably land closer to 4 stars. It's worth a second try.
author: Halley S.

description:
We finally came by this new addition in the neighborhood on a Friday night, and came away loving it very much : ). 

Decor: I like the modern feel of the restaurant, although the simple and minimalist approach is rather standard in Valencia now. It's still rather for restaurants to capture that modern feel in in nob hill/downtown area where a lot of restaurants are out of date. Glad to see poping up of places like Aliment and hopefully more to come. 

Dishes: 

1. Brussels Sprouts- Beautifully done. We weren't usually fans of the brussels sprout as it has a distinct smell/taste to it that we aren't usually a fan of.  In their case, the chef beautiful use a thick asian inspired sauce/ top with seaweed to blend in with the brussel sprouts and this beautifully balance the taste of it. The sprouts were boiled aptly prior to caramelized without being overcooked. 

2. Bolognese Sauce with papadelle: this is a dish we make all the time at home. I like the aliment version.  They kept it traditional without much alteration. Only thing I noticed is that they put a lot of pepper. This made it a bit firery and I would take that down if it's up to me.  The water was obviously added to the sauce (this is necessary to ensure continue cooking without drying up.  In the portion we got served, I felt the water was added not too long before it was served, therefore making it a bit too saucy.. I would say it should cook up for another 30 mins before been served after just adding water. Pretty good otherwise. 

3. Pork Chop: Pork chop was beautifully done. It's cooked to medium with all the juice perfectly kept in the chop while surface nicely seared. Not much taste to the inside, as the point is probably the freshness of the chop. Judging from the texture point of view, I said it was a dish that demonstrate solid skill.  And the potatoes were also perfectly baked with moisture inside and crispy outside. 

Will totally come back more before the crowd finds it and make it another place with long waits.
author: Fung S. O.

description:
The service was good, friendly staff with a chill vibe.  Creative dishes but it missed the mark taste wise for me. I think if you're considering this place that you should give it a shot because even though I didn't like it, you might.

The Brussels sprouts were tasty.

The spaetzl was interesting.  I grew up in Germany and this was an American interpretation, prepared like Mac and cheese (creamy cheese, bread crumbs etc).

I didn't think the ingredients went well together in the wild mushroom gnocchi. There was too much going on. The wild mushrooms by themselves were awesome though.
author: Sabrina J.

description:
I really enjoyed aliment. Wound up there on accident when hopwater was at capacity. Ordered the kale salad and the special fish app of the night, the smoked trout. Both were extremely large portions for what I was expecting at this kind of restaurant. 

The kale salad was yummy but a whole lot of the same thing. Maybe a little too much dressing. 

The smoked trout (special fish app) was absolutely incredible. Large portion of smoked trout, beets, greens, bread, and sauce. Really stellar. Probably the best thing I've eaten in the last 2 months.

Ordered the spaetzle because I can't resist. LIke a grown up mac n cheese. Very yummy, good portion size. 

Entree was the short ribs. Absolutely incredible. 2 large ribs, super tender and flavorful. Mashed potatoes were super tasty, and the greens were a perfect complement. 

Service was excellent, and the ambiance is cozy.

Price point is high, but with the portion size it beats out other similar places. I will definitely be back.
author: Monika M.

description:
I had the Brussels sprouts and Scallops as well as the Halibut. The Pot the Crème was the best I have ever had! The service was really nice.
Waiting to give the fifth star after I have tried their Brunch...
author: Bogee B.

description: Fantastic food and atmosphere.  Even with a limited menu, selections sounded great and the food my girlfriends and I chose last night for a little bachelorette get together did NOT disappoint.  Specifically, we had the spaetlze Mac and cheese, crispy Brussels sprouts, butcher board, fried ramen chicken nuggets, and beet salad. Plus of course chocolate cakes with vanilla ice cream and fudge glaze for dessert.  All were fantastic and quickly served by our attentive server.  Would happily return on my next trip to San Fran!
author: Sara W.

description:
SO delicious. Brussel sprouts and duck chips for appetizer... split the bolognese and chicken with kerry. SO good! good ambiance, nice server, pretty empty at 6 on a Sunday.

 Right near the Masonic, so a good spot to go to before a show!!
author: Christie B.

description: I moved to San Francisco about a year ago and this place has become one of my regular favorites. The food is consistently good, and so is the service. Most of the bad reviews for this restaurant seem to be from typical long-term San Franciscans who are looking for just about anything to complain about, or make themselves feel victimized.
author: Ernie S.

description:
Aliment

My husband and I just ate at this newly opened restaurant on Bush Street (between Mason & Powell). We've been looking forward to its opening, as we watched it being built over the last couple of months. The dining room itself is very well laid out for the neighborhood, with plenty of counter seating, some that looks into the open kitchen and some that look out onto Bush Street. There's also a row of booths along one wall and an upstairs dining area as well.

Aliment has a great wine and beer selection and serves yummy upscale comfort food. So far we've had the Hanger Steak and Short Ribs, both served with really interesting accompaniments. We also tried a vegetarian entree, the gnocchi, which was as satisfying as any dish a carnivore would love. The fried Brussel Sprouts with fish sauce and the house made Spaetzle, which brings the mac-n-cheese trend to a new level, we're totally amazing. They also offer fried chicken and other dishes that looked great on other people's tables.  Service was professional and friendly and prices are quite reasonable for the neighborhood. We'll definitely be back to this new, welcome, addition to the Nob Hill / Union Square area.
author: S. S.

description:
Pretty much average in every way. It's got the Edison bulbs and the wood paneling, but seems like it was done sort of half-heartedly to cash in on the trend. This place didn't really feel like someone's passion to me, just a sort of business venture (which to be fair, counts for every restaurant, but this just seemed sort of weak).

I think this place is very, very overpriced for the product. The cheapest entree item on the menu is the $16 burger. The $18 Bolognese (second cheapest) didn't have a whole lot of flavor (big noodles seem to have a way of drying out faster). 

That being said, they just opened and I'm sure the rent was gigantic, but you can't just hike up the cost when the product doesn't really match. Either that or you need to provide some serious ambience, which wasn't totally there. 

The server was very sweet and attentive. The chef said goodbye to us on the way out. All of this was appreciated, but the food was just OK and ran us a bill of about $70 for 2 entrees and 2 drinks + tip.
author: Jay C.

description:
Fine dining food at diner prices. Seriously this place is amazing!

The food was cooked to absolute perfection and tasted gorgeous. The majority of the ingredients were also made on site. Absolutely fantastic.

The only downside I had to the entire evening was that the portions were perhaps a little on the small side. Still fantastic!
author: Vlad W.

description:
3.5 stars rounded up!
I had to look it up - Aliment means: 1. Something that nourishes; food.
2. Something that supports or sustains.
Ok, now that we got that straight -- Woo, it sure took a long time for you guys to open!  My friend who lived in the apartments next to you was waiting and waiting for you to open - she finally had to move.  So when I saw that you were open for business and that your opening was also advertised on Daily Candy, I told my friend, we had to try it for dinner.  All in all, it was pretty good -- she ordered the fried chicken and thought it was all right.  I ordered the kale salad because I had been out all day at a street food festival - this was perfect to balance out the day.  And my bf got the slow-cooked beef with turnips -- I had a taste and it had good flavoring and the meat was tender.  He said some of it was overcooked and he thought for a neighborhood restaurant, the prices were a little high.  Hmm...I'd give it another try and I am curious about their brunch.
author: Maile N.

description:
Fab meal Monday evening. My date and I were both quite hungry, and shared the cheese/charcuterie (which was beautifully presented and was noticeably more chock-full of delicious bites than offered by any other restaurant in recent memory) and the pork chop. Perfect amount of food, and he's a big guy. The pork chop was seasoned perfectly for a barely-crisp exterior and was so tender and flavorful. I'm still thinking about it three days later... 

They have large booths and a bar on the first floor, but they seat couples upstairs on a little half-terrace overlooking the first level, so there's no chance you'll get stuck in a corner or next to a wild/drunk group if you're just two people looking for a place to eat, drink, and chat. Polite, unobtrusive service. 

It's been open about a year now, and I am happy to have it as a go-to spot in the neighborhood.
author: Heidi U.

description:
Aliment is a beautiful and relatively new place.  I received a nice welcome and was seated at the chef's counter.  Thank goodness the seating at the chef's counter is comfortable, something you find at so few places.  Service was pleasant, efficient, and knowledgeable of the menu.

Chopped kale salad was nice enough having as its base quite fresh kale.  However, it was a bit plain and some citrus, perhaps tangerine segments, would have livened it.

Fried brussels sprouts with a sweetish fish sauce needed nothing but my appetite.  This was a wonderful and well-portioned appetizer just made for sharing.  

Braised short rib with broccoli di ciccio was just OK.  The short ribs were tender and not too fatty but were also lacking something.  Some sort of sauce or reduction would have made this plate much more interesting.
author: David D.

description:
Review for BRUNCH ONLY:  I had high expectations, walking my Aliment every day and seeing it full during happy hour.  

Brunch was terrible.  My vegetarian dining partner had very few options, and many of the meat dishes couldn't be made without.  The eggs in the smoked fish eggs benedict were very runny, and the smoked fish was much saltier and fishier than described by the server.  The potatoes were so fried they were hard to bite into.

Hopefully, a happy hour sometime soon will change my review of this place!
author: Sona P.

description: So good! The food was completely on point and the bar tender was funny and helpful! The atmosphere was pleasant and I was seated fairly quickly! I had the Mac n cheese and the chicken (with ramen!) and seriously would go back for more.
author: Katie Andrew P.

description: Excellent service and amazing food. We ordered their famous fried Brussels sprouts and days later as I'm writing this review my mouth is watering just thinking about them. Crispy on the outside and tender all the way through. A slightly sweet and salty sauce lightly coated them. The spaetzel mac and cheese was rich and creamy. Everything we ordered was perfect. We will definitely go back.
author: Pela S.

description: Decided to try this spot for Sunday brunch, it's pretty close to home. Wasn't sure what to expect with the mixed reviews. We were seated right away, it was half full at 1pm. The waitress told us right away that they were out of two of the dishes (other yelpers had mentioned this). We each ordered the french toast as well as one continental to share...we were starving. The french toast was amazing, it was like bread pudding and the continental was a good item to share. The coffee was good...at times service was a bit slow. Overall it was nice and would go again, but they need to work on running out of items for brunch-and the brunch menu is pretty limited to start with...especially when peak Sunday brunch time is 1pm-2pm
author: Kimberly R.

description: Oh, My, God. The fried Brussels sprouts are amazing! Good service and atmosphere, though music was a bit loud. Will definitely be back.
author: Shane R.

description: Fantastic meal. Pastrami slider was an awesome way to start the meal.  I had the spaghetti bolognese which was so freakin tasty.  The squash fettuccine also got some serious Yums, oohs and ahhs.  The house made donut was a perfect way to end the meal.  Great meal at an even better price. Most entrees under 20 bucks.
author: Howie K.

description:
Not impressed.  Brought friends from out of town for dinner here and were frankly embarrassed by our selection.  The service was ambivalent (our waitress seemed put off by questions about the food and indifferent when asked for recommendations) and the food was overpriced and not very tasty.

Brussels Sprouts: I'm a huge fan of brussels sprouts, so I order them whenever they're on the menu.  These were pretty tasty, but I found them to be too oily and cloyingly sweet as you got to the bottom.  

Scallops: the scallops themselves were perfectly cooked and very yummy.  Best thing we got there.  Unfortunately, the rice they were served with was undercooked and the sauce had an odd flavor that only detracted from the dish.

Pork Chop: slightly dry (yet somehow, there was a pool of oil on the bottom of the plate) and not very flavorful.  A wholly forgettable dish.

Bolognese: If you're going to put a simple dish like bolognese on the menu, it should be really outstanding.  This one simply wasn't.  My friend left more than half of it uneaten because she, in her words, "wanted to same room for some tasty SF food".  Ouch.

Fish special: The serving was tiny (a small triangular chunk about 1.5" on each side) and while it didn't taste bad, it didn't taste good enough to warrant the $30+ price tag, either. 

Given the prices Aliment charges and how competitive the SF restaurant market is, the food and the service have got to be much better than they are.  If this one leaves the neighborhood, I won't be missing it.
author: Alisa N.

description:
I loved it!  A friend recommended the pork chops, so I ordered them, and they did not disappoint.  I ended up gnawing on the bone!

My wife had the monkfish, which was a more subtle interplay of flavors.  We traded bites, and I would order either again.

We were seated upstairs, which was strangely hot, but didn't detract from the experience much.
author: Isaac J.

description: Yammy yammy yammy fois gra meatballs in my tammy. They changed menu from regular entrees to small plates for sharing.  Last time when I been in that kind a place sharing plates was small, and I was afraid that I ordered not enough. But when first plate came it was pretty big. So we ordered 3 plates. Girl who served us was very nice and patient. Can't wait to come back again
author: Daria W.

description:
Omg! Is all I have to say. Every single dish on menu was super tasty. Perfect portions, to share among table. Food comes out whenever it's ready which makes it hard if table wants different things. It's not like a regular three course restaurant. But fun nonetheless! 

Also very fair pricing. For our party of four incl. a bottle of wine we paid $150. 

Perfect location if you're staying at either Fairmont or Mark Hopkins.
author: Cecilia J.

description:
Overall great meal. Excellent service, quality menu. Recommendation is to arrive early and grab a seat upstairs, very cozy!

Brussels are definitely a must - great portion size and very tasteful, plenty for even 3 ppl. Wagyu burger ($16) also has incredible flavor!

If you go for fish of the day, ask the price beforehand. Had a little sticker shock at $35 for the halibut. I felt the plate, while good (portion size, taste), was not outstanding. 

Will be back for the burger!
author: Anna C.

description:
Very average food, but the price is also average - so no big complaints there.  

I called a few days ahead of time to request an upstairs seating.  The man on the phone said it wouldn't be a problem, but when I got there with my guests, they stuck us downstairs by the bathroom.
author: Naho W.

description: From the moment I entered, they were friendly and happy to engage. The bartender suggested a perfect libation based on my likes/comments and was pleased to do something with what he had behind the bar. Terrific bartender! Once seated, our server was exceptional from her attitude, menu knowledge, and overall demeanor. Really like her and her style...well done! And now on to the food...very interesting, very delicious, very easy to share or not, and great portion sizes that aren't too big or too small but very appropriate for what the item is. Can't wait to go back...Cheers!
author: Dr F.

description:
Best brussel sprouts ever!
I stumbled upon this place for lunch with an out-of-town friend recently.  The place was pretty packed at mid weekend-day, but we were able to sit at the kitchen bar comfortably.  The highlight was definitely the brussel sprouts.  They add some sort of sweet-and-savory honey-like sauce, along with lemon and bacon.  The rest of the meal was pretty good, but not super memorable. 
I would definitely consider returning there to sample other dishes.  It's a good location to dine at to avoid the touristy spots around Union Square.
author: Ray H.

description: Ambience is great..Food was also spot on..The squash salad with arugula was delicious..I'm giving this 2 stars because they hardly had any vegetarian options...When I asked the waiter if they could substitute the meat in the pasta for veggies he said the chef doesn't appreciate changing his dishes around...seriously?
author: Pavitra B.

description:
Ordered:
Brussel sprouts
Fried chicken bits
Burger
Pastrami spare ribs

(Before anyone thinks I'm a massive glutton, this was for a party of 4 and we supposedly shared)

If the prices came down about 5-7 dollars per "tapas" platter, this would have easily been 5 stars.  The burger was really great and distinguished itself from other "gourmet" burgers with its use of a buttery, biscuity bun, but I have to say that the star of meal - and this is a really fucking weird thing to say - were the brussel sprouts.  Like, wow, I really need to figure out how to duplicate that recipe.

Other than that, service was really good and the rest of the food, the few tastes I had, were great.  Unfortunately, it's too expensive for me to actually go here more often than once in a blue moon, which is a real shame, as the food was really delicious.
author: Norman S.

description:
Very cool neighborhood spot.  Nothing overly trendy or hip, just great food in a comfortable setting.  

Brussel sprouts and the Mushroom Gnocchi are incredible.
author: Nicholas M.

description: We sat upstairs. The lighting was romantic and it was a great place to talk. We had the mussels (sauce was fantastio). Husband ordered 3 more servings of the bread that came with it - he loved it. Then we had the rigoatoni (pasta was perfect). For dessert: chocolate cake (perfect ending). We shares a bottle of the chennin blanc. Lovely dinner! Would definitely go back.
author: Fawn R.

description: Great restaurant. Absolutely loved the Brussel sprouts and home made ice cream. Stumbled across this restaurant and couldn't have been more pleased. Great food and service!
author: Mariah M.

description: Food is excellent, cocktails are AMAZING, ambiance is great, service is spot on! Would definitely recommend.
author: Liv L.

description: We had an excellent dinner here on a recent visit to San Francisco.  We made a reservation beforehand and were seated right away, in a cozy loft above the main restaurant.  I had the roast chicken breast which was really more like half a chicken and came with creamy, cheesy polenta and collard greens with bacon.  My mom got the bolognese and we split a side of the brussels sprouts, which were quite good--not the best I've had but still tasty.  The portions were huge and we brought home several to-go boxes.  I'm docking a star because dessert was disappointing, we ordered the chocolate cake which came with a little mini pitcher of creme fraiche to pour over it, and was topped with whipped cream I think.  The slab of cake was huge and quite dry and there wasn't much creme available to increase the moisture, so unfortunately it was sort of a letdown after our amazing dinner.  Still, I would definitely recommend for a meal and would have loved to try brunch if we were going to be there longer.
author: Maeve M.

description: Great food, great service. Took my "foodie" mother and her sister (my aunt). We all ordered different things and they were all delicious. Ended it off with their homemade ice cream. Amazing!
author: Nick S.

description:
If you are looking for a quintessential SF neighborhood dining spot, this fits the bill. I'll start with the small disappointments and move to the good stuff. First, if you are party of 6, expect tight seating. Bread is not included. We ordered some midway through the meal, but it never arrived. At least we were not charged for it. And only one menu item that was a flop, the steak. My friend said it was way over spiced. When they attempted repair, it was way under seasoned. She switched to another meal. They were very gracious and helpful about. 

Everything else was super!!! We had nice guidance on wine choices for pairing with multiple meals, friendly service at the right pace. As everyone says, the brussels sprouts are delicious! We also had the short rib appetizers. Everyone else in our party was very happy with entrees (pasta, seafood and the chicken was spectacular). I never order chicken in a restaurant, but highly recommend this dish. 
We ordered 3 desserts, all great. 
Cost: roughly $90 per person which include everything (3 bottles of wine, beer for some, all food, tip & tax).
author: C H.

description: **WORST SERVICE EVER & NO FRIED CHICKEN** Our waitress was so bad. If you plan on working during brunch hours you should really hire morning people cuz she clearly wasn't one of them. Barely acknowledged us and was just full of attitude. We had asked if they had fried chicken since clearly everyone is raving about it. Her response was "you should never go by what online tells you since it's never accurate, we change our menu every 6 months". Well then you should update your menu online. I'm giving 1 star since the pork belly hash was not bad but not worth ruining your day with Debbie downer.
author: Ruby T.

description: Great service, good ambience, good food and affordable prices. Totally recommendable this place.
author: Augusto L.

description:
All the small plates were fine, and the same goes for the dessert. If you're the type that can make a meal out of those...sure, why not? You'll leave satisfied.

But let's cut to the chase: when a "butler's steak"--more commonly known in the US as a flat iron steak--has the consistency and flavor of a finely ground sausage (and this was the case on two separate dinners), something has gone horribly wrong.

...Unless you're the sort that really likes sausage I guess?
author: Steven L.

description: We chose this restaurant because of the well rounded selection of entrees.  Our waitress recommended sharing appetizers and an entree.  We did and were not disappointed.  The mussels with chorizo was delicious as well as the scallops.  The pork belly was also good but a little too fatty. The Thai Pana cotta and walnut glazed donut were also tasty.  Service was warm and friendly.  Will revisit.
author: susan b.

description: I was expecting more from Aliment based on the fairly stellar reviews on here. The food was very good, to be sure- especially the gnocchi- but we were INCREDIBLY rushed through our dinner by a rude woman who I assume was an owner or supervisor.  We sat down and hadn't had time to look at a menu before the waitress kept coming over for our order. We placed an order for appetizers, and were asked multiple times before they came to order our mains. Throughout our meal, the woman and our waitress kept coming over MULTIPLE TIMES to try to take our plates away without asking if we were done, and when we were clearly still eating. The supervisor woman was literally standing over our table watching us eat and ready to grab the plate the second we were finished. This is the place to go if you want to dine and dash and don't mind someone hovering over you while you inhale your food- otherwise, I don't think I would recommend it. Our group of 5 was done in less than an hour, which wasn't what we were looking for on a Friday night for a nice birthday dinner.
author: Allie S.

description: First time here, we ate vegetarian tonight.   Started with the Kale salad & the Roasted Squash salad. The flavored were amazing,  followed by the Fried Brussels Sprouts  & the Anson Mills Farrotts. The taste buds were going crazy. A must try fun hipster restaurant  in Nob Hill.
author: Debra B.

description: Great spot in Nob Hill. Went for dinner with my Dad and boyfriend. Great ambiance - small place with comfortable spacious booths and an upstairs loft area with additional seating. This was one of those  nights where our eyes were bigger than our stomachs. Felt like I needed to be airlifted out of there due to excessive consumption of delicious food. Great brussels- sweet flavor gave it new twist to the usual salt and lemon taste. Meaty mussels. And bolognese that is a contender with my moms homemade. Brought my leftovers to work the following day and guiltlessly ate in front of a salivating coworker who was eating microwaved lean cuisine. Opps. Oh and the flourless chocolate cake was unnecessary but divine. Great spot.
author: Katie P.

description: We were able to reserve a table at the last minute, and got one of the best tables on the balcony. The food was awesomely prepared food and service was excellent. My date ordered the Monkfish, and I ordered the Butler's Steak. We exchanged plates halfway through, and were delighted with both. The Brussel Sprouts were very tasty as well.
author: Geo F.

description: Went there with two friends. None of us really liked anything we ordered. Everything we got had combinations of flavors none of us thought worked.
author: Jesse B.

description: Went for Sunday brunch last weekend, which in this town it's a sport akin to Olympic competition to get the revered Sunday Brunch Reservation. Thankfully for Aliment, a quaint, quiet, Nob Hill joint, I was able to snag one the Saturday afternoon prior. The food is delicious, simple, unfettered and all around delicious. The beef shortrib hash is sumptuous and the potatoes that come with are sinfully savory. All in all, what more can I ask from a place that offers bottomless mimosas, has a great space, and solid service? Perhaps if they carried me home afterwards. But that might push me over the edge ;)
author: Nina W.

description: We stopped in for dinner and loved it! From the meat and cheese appetizer, short rib entree, and apple pastry desert, we loved every bite. Great staff and atmosphere and attention to detail in every aspect of the meal.
author: Kyle S.

description: I've had nothing but good experiences at Aliment.  I've taken visiting friends here, family, and friends, and it's always been exceptional.  On my last visit I took a chance on the Shrimp and Grits. Having lived in the south for 5 years I was a little skeptical that this southern dish could be pulled off in SF.  Well, it was pulled off! Super tasty and true to its origins, a phenomenal meal.  Also don't miss the Brussel Sprouts, they're amazing.  The space is comfortable and the service was good.  Big thumbs up.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: Very few - 1 - vegetarian options. Even the green salads and side veggies are prepared with bacon salad dressing or lard, and no substitions are allowed :(
author: Katie W.

description: My wife and I were looking for a not-so-busy place close to our hotel, The Cartwright. She had the mussels, in a broth spiked with chorizo, and was fine with them. I had the monk fish, at $28, and was disappointed. The cut was tough and was poorly seasoned, if at all. For that price, I'd expect much more. Perhaps we did this place on the chef's off-night.
author: Grey E.

description: Aliment is a gem, especially since nice restaurant with a great ambiance are rare in the area. The brussel sprouts are a must! Service was great as well.
author: Jade E.

description:
A great answer to a cold evening for san Francisco.  In town for the week with the fam. and found the atmosphere warm and inviting.  
The sautéed Brussel Sprouts in the fish sauce reduction took us totally by surprise; rich and almost a smokey finish.
The Squash Salad just didn't work as the pieces were too large with no flavor.
The Roasted chicken hit the spot with the polenta, smoked chiles, and shishito relish offering balanced flavor and textures.
A great find close to the Nob Hill neighborhood to avoid the crush of Union Square tourists during the holidays.
author: S L.

description: Wonderful food, reasonably priced and with a great wine list. Finally an awesome place nearby Union Square
author: Alex A.

description: nice ambiance, courteous and kind staff. the food was tasty, a little on the salty side. interesting cocktail menu and solid menu selections. worth a try.
author: Angela W.

description: Nice space, bar area, big booths downstairs, and tables upstairs. Long list of beers, wines by glass or bottle, kind of short menu, no kids menu. Had mussels in chorizo broth and a duck appetizer which were both very nice, then monkfish and spaghetti as main (sausage in the sauce gives it a little kick, in case your kids are picky, which ours are)...huge cheesecake and a bowl of homemade mint chip ice cream for desserts ended a very nice meal...only criticism would be beer glasses were small, maybe only 12 oz, so draft beers are kinda poor value.
author: Jim W.

description: I enjoyed my dining experience! The panne cotta was an interesting combination of texture and flavors that go together well, definitely tasty... The freshly made pasta was enjoyable.  Check it out!
author: Tracy C.

description:
So, I live across the street from the restaurant and have waited quite a while for it to open.

Sadly the place doesn't warrant the anticipation.  I'd hoped that something wonderful was going to open but I've got to say the food is just mediocre.  There just doesn't seem to be any real attention to detail.

The kale salad that everybody seems to rave about was over dressed.  The grilled butter lettuce was nearly tasteless and and over charred.  The main course of braised pork shoulder was okay but not memorable.  A friend had the gnocchi which again was just okay.  Generally, the menu sounds better than it is.  Lots of verbal ambition but little attention to detail.

But the above is not surprise.  The chef spent most of his time chatting with some babes at the bar and seemed little interested in watching the fine points of the menu's execution.  He is remembered from the new incarnation of the Nob Hill Grille which at last experience gave a similar impression.

Service was just okay but again the server paid more attention was paid to the babes than the general clientele.

I had hoped that something out of the ordinary would open in the location but, alas,  this is not to be.

Too bad they didn't take the cue from places like Chow on Church Street or Toast on Polk.  Keep it simple and keep it good.
author: David H.

description: Ailment was near our hotel in union square-great location! We were so pleased with our experience at Aliment. The service was great, vibe was very down town feel (swanky hipsters) and the food was solid. I had the pork chop with chutney and my husband had the mushroom gnocchi. The price is reasonable for what you get. Would definitely come back.
author: Amanda G.

description: We read reviews on Yelp and OpenTable, so we were excited to try Aliment. But we were disappointed. The atmosphere felt more like an upscale bar than a restaurant, the menu was small, and several of the dishes you see in Yelp photos weren't on the menu. Plus the food just wasn't as good as you'd expect for a place with so many 4-5 star ratings.
author: Mark G.

description: This is the new "neighborhood restaurant" near me, so naturally I tried it right after it opened. As a previous reviewer wrote: "For the prices that they're charging, this isn't going to be a neighborhood restaurant, and for what they're actually serving, this isn't going to be a destination restaurant either." On point. The food & drinks are almost as good as the prices they are charging, not quite. The service is good yes. I would be more likely to attend/recommend this place if the menu was elevated a notch or if the prices came down to meet what they are serving. I can see myself coming here if I want to have an impromptu glass of wine with a friend, not my first choice for dinner. With that said, I hope they make some positive changes because the location is great & our immediate neighborhood can use a good beverage/dinner place.
author: Lily R.

description: Due to some confusion on our part, we made a 6:00 reservation when we had tickets to see a show at 7:00 at a theater two blocks away. With traffic and parking issues, several in our 12-person group didn't arrive until after 6:00. We explained our predicament as we were being seated, and not only did Aliment provide us all with absolutely delicious food, but they got us out in time to make it to our show. The staff members who helped us could not have been nicer or more accommodating. We all very much look forward to going back when we're able to linger, and enjoy the experience more.
author: Mike R.

description: Lots of hype but not follow through. We choose this place because it looked amazing and was a convenient location to our hotel. The service was good. The waiter was knowledgeable about the menu and drinks. The drink menu was lacking. Only a small amount of choices. It wasn't set up to pair with the menu. The food was mediocre however the Brussel sprouts were the big winner here. It was one of the best things I had on my trip to SF. However the bolognese was...bad. It looked amazing, the presentation was great, but it tasted bad. The pasta was undercooked and did not taste homemade as described. The sauce was ok. I was really expecting it to be great. The Gnocchi was really heavy and creamy. It was very rich but still lacked any flavor. The gnocchi was also undercooked. The ambience was nice. The projection movie on the wall was a nice touch. But all in all it was definitely not worth the price and the entrees were a big let down.
author: Mitch W.

description: Stopped by this fairly new Nob Hill area establishment fairly late on a Sunday night, famished after being underfed at a nearby cocktail shindig.  I was pleasantly surprised by the stylish, unpretentious gastropub fare.  All my dishes were well-executed (a "grilled little gem salad" was raw, not grilled, but tasty nonetheless), and Chef Matt was effusive in describing the restaurant's cuisine and aims.  A new but promising eatery with a nice wine list and solid service, in a nice locale, Aliment is worth a repeat visit.
author: Nate S.

description: I love the food and service at this place. They stopped offering brunch but I wish they still do. I recently went there for dinner with couple of good friends. We ordered their fried brussels sprouts, roast chicken breasts and steak. They were all delicious.
author: Alfred L.

description:
The one con that I still struggle with living in Nob Hill is the lack of good restaurants in my area. It's either chain restaurants or kitschy SF tourist traps that charge too much. I've got my hole-in-the-wall favorites that are always good for takeout (Sushi Toni tops that list!) but the closest decent restaurant is probably the Nob Hill Café. I found my neighborhood bar (Tunnel Top, a must visit for any SF resident) but I've been yearning for a good place to have a glass of wine and enjoy some quality food. 

Well, finally I have found such a place! Ailment, a new American/California restaurant just opened on Bush between Mason and Powell. The 49-seat restaurant feels small but open. Giant windows that slide open face the street and there's bar seating along it for those who like to people watch. Every day I walk by there's little vases filled with fresh flowers sitting out on it. The rest of the interior is minimalist outside of the wine wall behind the bar. 

We sat by the window and checked out the wine list. They featured a good selection of local and world wines. I just read that the managing partner comes from Nob Hill Grille and shares the chef duties with a guy coming from Blue Plate. This makes sense as the food is classic California, simple and seasonal. We started by tasting the Churchpoint oysters, which were topped with fresno chile vinegar and fennel. It had a spicy after-kick that really livened up a standard oyster. I then continued my kale obsession with their chopped kale salad, diced with toasted pepitas (squash seed), radish and pecorino. The dressing was a thick avocado and anchovy dressing, which didn't taste fishy at all. We also split the fried brussel sprouts, which were crispy but a little on the greasy side (they'd be perfect if strained a tad bit more). The sauce they're served in tasted like a mix of soy and something a little sweet/syrupy, which combined made a delicious tangy combo. Just in case we were getting a little too healthy, we also got an order of the French fries, which were standard but served with a garlic chive ranch. I'd recommend also requesting ketchup as they make their own smoky ketchup in-house that I really enjoyed and I usually hate ketchup. We stopped after appetizers and wine but their entrees were in the same genre (think hanger steak, diver scallops, fried chicken and braised short rib). 

This place offers a little something for everyone. I'd be fine dining there solo, with friends or on a date. They're also open for brunch so I'll be checking that out next!
author: Larisa J.

description: Horrible service. I had a reservation at 5:30 pm. I arrived at the restaurant at 5:25 pm, which was apparently 5 minutes sooner than their opening time (and their door was unlocked too btw so I walked in).  The beautiful waitresses were apparently very rude in such an upscale restaurant. They told my friend and I "oh we're not actually open yet" with a dismissive manner. As soon as we walked out the door, the locked the door. Then, we had to wait outside and when they opened the door, I told her that we wanted to cancel our reservation (because OpenTable won't let me cancel using the app since the reservation time has passed). She didn't bother to ask why nor to apologize. This is a disappointment despite the class of this restaurant and the yelp reviews it has got. Horrible, horrible service. I'm sorry to say, but pretty face with horrible attitude shouldn't be in customer service. Very disappointed.
author: Wesley F.

description: Good experience until we had to pay the bill. What a nightmare! I truly want to believe the waiter made a mistake and didn't realize it, but the whole thing got weird and embarrassing. We were a party of four and asked the waiter (a super charming guy btw) to put the 2 bottles of wine in a different bill. We paid that bill with cash and then the food bill with cards. But he disappeared with the cash and said we had paid only one third of the wine bill. It was surreal. To get things worse, my friend was pregnant and not feeling well bc of the food (avoid the fried chicken!). Then two tattoo guys in a near table tried to get involved, aggressively (!!), and he didn't do anything. We were not angry or screaming or making a scene, we were just trying to figure out the absurdity. At the end, we just paid again and left. I would never go back or recommend this place. Who treats customers like that?? It was really embarrassing...
author: fer e.

description: The service was pleasant and the food was delicious. We were a group of four; tried a few of their small plates and we all had a main dish as well. Brussels sprouts were the best I have ever had, Kale salad was great and so were the Scallops. Wasn't crazy about the Spaetzle. I will definitely go back to try their brunch.
author: Via Fume C.

description: The restaurant is tapas style and we ordered a bunch of dishes to share.  We ordered the crispy friend chicken bits, kale salad, gnocchi and meatballs.  It's not often that you go to a restaurant, order multiple dishes and you can't quite pinpoint which dish was your favorite. Everything we ordered had a unique balance of flavors and was delicious.  We came right before closing and they were super accommodating. The gentleman, who I believe was the manager, was very welcoming and extremely personable. Will definitely be coming back soon.
author: Anisha A.

description: Excellent restaurant ! Try the steak and the monkey fish and keep a bit for the desert !
author: Julien T.

description: Home of the topless Mimosa. Delicious Mother's Day brunch with eggs prepared Sous-Vide  for every dish. So delicious I had to find out how to make them for breakfast this morning. The short rib "hash" looked terrific and the bread pudding French toast was also great. Very nice contemporary decor, pleasantly not too loud and would return for dinner as the lighting and ambiance looks to be even better after dark.
author: Judith S.

description: I'm in love with this place. It's small and cozy with great Cali comfort food. When we got there it was packed. Received prompt service - bartender asked if we wanted a drink. Had a glass of wine and my husband had a beer and we were able to relax a bit from our 60+ hour work week.  We were seated within 20 minutes and ordered a chopped kale salad with the Aliment chicken wings.  Then more libations and decided to try the hanger steak (my mouth is watering right now just typing about it) with a side of fried brussel sprouts. Wait staff was friendly and knowledgable about the menu. Promised my husband I'd wait 2 long weeks, for him to get back from a business trip, before going back - but between me & you I'm not sure I can wait...I think the fried merquez, trout and collard greens are calling my name.
author: Mignon B.

description:
The food was excellent! I had brussel sprouts and butler's steak, cooked perfectly. 

The service was so-so. I walked in first and sat at the bar waiting for my friends. I asked if there were any non-alcoholic drinks on the menu and received a very curt "no". Also, they will not alter the dishes in any way e.g. switching out the sides.
author: Robyn G.

description:
Five stars for the gnocci. But this place is kind of hit and miss. I tried the gnocci, ribs, scallops, kale salad, chocolate torte, and cobbler. The gnocci was awesome. Ribs were great. The turnip mash?! Mmm!! Scallops were decent but oversalted. Kale salad was overdressed, soggy, too cheesy. The desserts were just OK. I would go back for more of that gnocci and that fried chicken I almost ordered.
The staff all looked like they wanted to kill me.
author: Kate P.

description: AWESOME!!  Food is delicious, service is friendly and the atmosphere is cozy but modern.  Added bonus:  open past 9:30pm!  As a NY'er, I was appalled while walking the streets of SF with nowhere still serving dinner after 9-9:30!  And fate sent me and my husband in the direction of Aliment.  We both enjoyed the homemade dishes.   Highly recommend.
author: Jane M.

description: Amazingly good, consistent food; cold in ambiance. I brought a girlfriend from out of town here, and it just lacked an intimacy. We were seated on the top floor (awkwardly distanced from the rest of the resto), but requested instead to sit at the bar. They were attentive in service and we both enjoyed the food. It was A-Ok...that's all I can really say.
author: Brianna S.

description: Delicious burger, nice atmosphere, unpretentious, great service and good beer selection. I'll definitely be back! Happy to have this in my neighborhood.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Best fried chicken in the city hands down, and the rest of the menu is pretty fantastic as well. Very attentive and friendly service too. Can't recommend this place high enough.
author: Aish F.

description: Great for pre-show. The charcuterie platter, side of greens and glasses of vino are the perfect size and delicious for two to share. Great staff and cozy setting.
author: Brian P.

description: I sat at the bar and had their strawberry cheesecake by myself (#fatkid) ... so this review is limited to the atmosphere and desert, both of which delivered.
author: Brandon A.

description: Good stuff!  Will definitely be back again!
author: Pat D.

description: The wine was pretty good and the brussel sprouts rocked my socks off. All in all, very good. Loved the fancy water carafe. Pretty expensive.
author: Adam C.

description:
The bad then the good.
Bad:  1) Aliment is probably the only restaurant in San Francisco that doesn't offer Decaf.  2)Three of our party of six had been looking forward to burgers, based on the great comments on Yelp.  We were told, at 1 PM that there was only 1 left.  We could imagine running out of daily specials, but burgers???  To make it worse, the three faced off in a burger quest.  Th two losers ordered chicken and french toast.  The waiter soon came back and said that even the one was gone.  He got hash.  3)  One of our party liked the continental breakfast as described, except for granola as she is allergic to nuts.   "Please give me a small salad rather than the granola," she said.  "Sorry, no substituting," said the waiter.  She ended up with the breakfast without granola or salad. 4)It took forever to get  served

Good:  The food that arrived was very good. ) I had the so-called Thai Fried Chicken - there was nothing even faintly Thai about it, but it was otherwise just right.  2) Two had the short rib hash.  There was nothing hashy about it - just large chunks of good meat, some potatoes and an egg .  The dish tasted good, but between this and the chicken, there's a problem with names.  3) My wife had the french toast - excellent.  4) My brother had the pisole and eggs - good, not great.  4)Sis in law, with nut allergy, liked her continental breakfast but longed for a small salad.

I'm not sure I'd go back, at least not for brunch.  We might try dinner.
author: Terry H.

description: Considering dropping in for dinner on a thursday night with no reservations and getting seated right away was a big plus. Winner of the night was hanger steak with forbidden rice and the charcuterie platter was yummy as well. we were four and each tried different dishes and the rest of them were just OK and mediocre.
author: Beril Y.

description: Loved this place. Showed up at 5:30 when it opened on a Sat night and got a seat at the window. It has a cool vibe. This is a place to share small plates, and larger plates! Had good service- server made good suggestions and the food came quickly. Enjoyed the Fried chicken bites, grilled wedge salad, shrimp and grits, and gnocchi with pork belly. Would have liked to try the brussel sprouts but hubby not a fan - next time I'll get it anyway. Had a chocolate bundt cake for dessert which was just OK. But the other stuff was excellent . I hope to return if I ever get the chance!
author: Barbara G.

description: Awesome food and atmosphere.  They had a great beer list too.
author: Kaci W.

description: I'm not sure what the 2 star reviews are all about--both the food and service and ambience of Aliment were top notch.  Although I was disappointed that they didn't have the fried chicken & waffle balls on the menu (it's on their website) but the short rib hash did not disappoint. And I was so pleased with brunch (was in SF for a conference) came back for dinner with friends and had the brussells sprouts and spaetzle (appetizer) and bolognese and was truly pleased.  The service was also good both at brunch and at dinner -- and they were showing a film on the wall (Good, Bad, and the Ugly) so I felt like I had my hipster SF experience.
author: Jennifer H.

description: It was a great dining experience on a Tuesday night, especially in the ole' neighborhood.  We shared a burger, which seems to have Asian seasonings throughout, maybe Korean Short rib flavors?  Fried brussel sprouts were a great texture and super umami, I thought just a tad salty and tasted like fish sauce.  Finally, the spaetzel.  Great texture, they seemed to be made on site or by hand or however those little nuggets of doughy heaven are made.  No need to get any of the extra toppings as it was so rich as served.  Two great beers off the very interesting selection made my evening.
author: Maya H.

description: Had a delicious dinner at Aliment.  For appetizers/sides we ordered the scallops (flavorful and well cooked), smoked black cod (tasty), brussels sprouts (yes, salty but delicious!), and beet salad (decent, nothing special).  My trout was good although the appetizers outshined my entree.  My dinner companions ordered the short rib and pork chop, and were also happy with their selections.  We finished our meal with cheesecake, which was just ok.  Service was friendly but slow (I think our server was covering almost the entire restaurant).  I will be back and can't wait to have those delicious brussels again!
author: melita s.

description: Possibly one of the most complete dining experiences I have ever had. We started with the brussel sprouts and spaetzle. Brussel sprouts had a fish caramel sauce, so we were hesitant at first; however, they turned out incredible and an absolute highlight of the meal. For our entree we had the Steak, Gnocchi, and Bolognese. The Steak was cooked to exact specification and the pickled vegetables that accompanied provided an excellent flavor contrast. We concluded the meal with the cheesecake, made entirely in house. Could not be happier with the experience and will absolutely be coming back.
author: Dylan F.

description: I'm obsessed with their brussel sprout appetizer.  The scallops appetizer and wagyu burger were yummy too but it's the brussel sprouts here that have me texting friends to see who wants to go back for the second time this week.  It's wine and beer only, fyi.
author: Katherine C.

description: I debated writing this review because I wanted to keep this secret to myself but ... This is quite a restaurant experience. I have gone to few restaurants in SF I felt for worthy of the praise that this food deserves.
author: Laurence S.

description: I had such a fun yummy dinner here last week!  The roast chicken is amazing.  The Brussels sprouts (fish sauce!) so tasty, croquette divine.  Sparking red wine made me the perfect amount of tipsy.  We had the chicken liver and merguez to start both fantastic.  Excellent addition to the sf dining scene.  One solid block north of anything super scary at night. Slightly too loud so maybe better for groups instead of romantic dates.
